Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives,

Speaker: NA
Text: Thursday, 10 December, 1942.

Speaker: NA
Text: MR . SPEAKER (Hon. W. Iff. Nairn)

Speaker: NA
Text: took tbe chair at 3 p.m., and read

Speaker: NA
Text: prayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: DEATH OF THE HONORABLE

Speaker: NA
Text: W ILLIAMHEN RY LAI RD SMITH . members

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr CUKTIir (Fremantle - Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister) - I deeply regret to inform

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members of the death of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Honorable William Henry Laird Smith,

Speaker: NA
Text: a former member of the House of Repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives and a Minister of the Crown,

Speaker: NA
Text: whieh occurred at Buwiie, in somewhat

Speaker: NA
Text: tragic circumstances, on the 21st October,

Speaker: NA
Text: The late honorable gentleman resigned

Speaker: NA
Text: from a position in the Tasmanian Rail-

Speaker: NA
Text: ways Department to contest the Denison

Speaker: NA
Text: seat in the House of Representatives at

Speaker: NA
Text: the genera] elections in. 1910, in which

Speaker: NA
Text: he was successful. He was re-elected in

Speaker: NA
Text: memiber of the parliamentary party that

Speaker: NA
Text: visited England in 1911 at the invitation

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Government of the united Kingdom

Speaker: NA
Text: on the occasion of the coronation of

Speaker: NA
Text: King George "V. He was a member of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Royal Commission on Electoral Laws

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1914, and of the Public Works Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee from 1914 to 1916 and again from

Speaker: NA
Text: 1917 to 1919. He was an Assistant

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister from November, 1916, to Feb-

Speaker: NA
Text: ruary, 1917, and an Honorary Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: from the 3rd February, 1920. He held

Speaker: NA
Text: the portfolio of Minister for the Navy

Speaker: NA
Text: from the 28th July, 1920, to the 21st

Speaker: NA
Text: December, 1921. He was defeated at the

Speaker: NA
Text: general election in 1922.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Laird Smith subsequently took up

Speaker: NA
Text: farming pursuits in the Burnie district

Speaker: NA
Text: and continued to take an active interest

Speaker: NA
Text: in public affairs, particularly in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to the organization of primary industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: He took a leading part in the formation

Speaker: NA
Text: of the now defunct Agricultural Bureau

Speaker: NA
Text: of Tasmania, and became the first chair-

Speaker: NA
Text: man of tho State Potato Marketing

Speaker: NA
Text: Board. He was also prominent in other

Speaker: NA
Text: public movements. He worked unspar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ingly in the service of his country and

Speaker: NA
Text: was held in the highest esteem by his

Speaker: NA
Text: fellows. T move-

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House records its sincere regret

Speaker: NA
Text: at the death of the Honorable William Henry

Speaker: NA
Text: Laird Smith, a former member of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives for the Division of Denison

Speaker: NA
Text: and a Minister of the Grown, places on record

Speaker: NA
Text: its appreciation of his meritorious public

Speaker: NA
Text: service, and tenders its deep sympathy to

Speaker: NA
Text: his widow and adopted sou.

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: North Sydney-Leade r

Speaker: NA
Text: of the United Australia party) - I

Speaker: NA
Text: second the motion and associate the

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition and myself

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Prime Minister's expressions of

Speaker: NA
Text: deep Tegret at the death of the late

Speaker: NA
Text: Honorable W. H . Laird Smith, and of

Speaker: NA
Text: profound sympathy with his widow and

Speaker: NA
Text: adopted son.

Speaker: NA
Text: The news of his death came as a great

Speaker: NA
Text: shock to me. During all the years we

Speaker: NA
Text: were associated I never knew 'him to

Speaker: NA
Text: be i l l ; he always seemed to me to be

Speaker: NA
Text: the embodiment of radiant health.

Speaker: NA
Text: Physically, he was a magnificent speci-

Speaker: NA
Text: men of manhood. Of all the men I have

Speaker: NA
Text: known in public life he seemed to me the

Speaker: NA
Text: one destined to outlive his contem-

Speaker: NA
Text: poraries.

Speaker: NA
Text: He was my colleague for many years,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I entertained for him feelings of pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: found esteem and warm affection. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: and out of office, I found him to be

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable and upright. He was a forth-

Speaker: NA
Text: right man-on e who spoke his mind

Speaker: NA
Text: freelyHe held definite opinions which

Speaker: NA
Text: he did not fear to declare to the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: What he believed in he fought for, and

Speaker: NA
Text: he never feared to speak his mind. His

Speaker: NA
Text: character may be summed up in the

Speaker: NA
Text: phrase-"H e faced life boldly".

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Laird Smith was as firm in his

Speaker: NA
Text: friendships as he was in his beliefs. He

Speaker: NA
Text: was no fair-weather friend; but a man

Speaker: NA
Text: who, in the darkest hour when the storm

Speaker: NA
Text: raged fiercely, was ever at one's side. He

Speaker: NA
Text: had a genial disposition. He made no

Speaker: NA
Text: personal enemies. Although he met life

Speaker: NA
Text: boldly he met it with a smile. He was

Speaker: NA
Text: a very manly man. There was nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: petty or mean about him. I n and out of

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament he served his country faith-

Speaker: NA
Text: fully and with great ability. His death,

Speaker: NA
Text: which will be deeply regretted by the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of hig State, robs me of a dear

Speaker: NA
Text: friend, whose loss I sincerely mourn.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative,

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members standing in their

Speaker: NA
Text: places.

Speaker: NA
Text: INTERNATIONAL AFFAIRS. Port

Speaker: NA
Text: REVIEW OF WAR SITUATION.

Speaker: NA
Text: MT. CURTIN (Fremantle - Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister) -b y leave-Whe n the House

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned on the 9th October I stated

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government proposed to call

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament together before Christmas.

Speaker: NA
Text: I added that, if the war situation necessi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tated it, an early sitting would be held.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I announced on the 13th November, it

Speaker: NA
Text: was decided to summon Parliament for a

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting extending over two days, in order

Speaker: NA
Text: that honorable members might hear and

Speaker: NA
Text: discuss a statement on the position of the

Speaker: NA
Text: war. As stated at the time, it is not the

Speaker: NA
Text: intention of the Government to submit

Speaker: NA
Text: any legislative proposals to Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: I now propose to give to honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers a brief review of the important de-

Speaker: NA
Text: velopments which have taken place i n the

Speaker: NA
Text: war situation since the House last met.

Speaker: NA
Text: The battle to drive the Japanese back

Speaker: NA
Text: over the Owen Stanley Range and out of

Speaker: NA
Text: the south-eastern part of New Guinea has

Speaker: NA
Text: been fought in one of tbe most difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: campaigning areas in the world. The ter-

Speaker: NA
Text: rain has been described by General

Speaker: NA
Text: MACArthur as " incredibly difficult" and

Speaker: NA
Text: presenting " almost insuperable complica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions in the maintenance of supply lines ".

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian and United States forces

Speaker: NA
Text: have had to endure extreme hardships in

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the worst tropical climates. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: addition to the strain imposed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: nature of the country and climate, these

Speaker: NA
Text: troops have had to withstand the inci-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence of malaria, though every endeavour

Speaker: NA
Text: h made to minimize the risk of thi.*

Speaker: NA
Text: illness. Finally, -under conditions to

Speaker: NA
Text: which white men do not readily become

Speaker: NA
Text: inured, these troops have had to fight

Speaker: NA
Text: against no mean foe. Nevertheless -the

Speaker: NA
Text: allied troops have fought tenaciously, gal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lantly, and, most important of all, vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: toriously. I pay a tribute to these men

Speaker: NA
Text: and totobeirdistinguished leaders, General

Speaker: NA
Text: MACArthur, Commander-in-Chief, South-

Speaker: NA
Text: west Pacific area; General Blamey, Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mander of the Allied Land Forces; and

Speaker: NA
Text: General Kenney, Commander of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Allied Air Forces. To them, to the sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinate commanders, and to the officers

Speaker: NA
Text: and men of the Australian and United

Speaker: NA
Text: States forces, Australia owes a debt of

Speaker: NA
Text: gratitude.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have said on an earlier occasion that

Speaker: NA
Text: Moresby is a vital key-point in the

Speaker: NA
Text: defence of Australia against an attack

Speaker: NA
Text: from the north-east where the main Jap-

Speaker: NA
Text: anese bases lie. Its possession by the

Speaker: NA
Text: enemy would open the way for a direct,

Speaker: NA
Text: attack on the mainland of Australia. The

Speaker: NA
Text: landward defence line of Port Moresbj

Speaker: NA
Text: is tbe Owen Stanley Range. The Jap-

Speaker: NA
Text: anese first made an effort to turn its left

Speaker: NA
Text: flank from Lae and Salamaua, but this

Speaker: NA
Text: was unsuccessful. They then launched a

Speaker: NA
Text: sea-borne attack against its rear, but this

Speaker: NA
Text: was repulsed by the Battle of the Coral

Speaker: NA
Text: Sea. A frontal attack was then attempted

Speaker: NA
Text: by way of Buna, Gona and Kokoda, but

Speaker: NA
Text: this had largely spent inself by the time

Speaker: NA
Text: it had reached Ioribaiwa. The next effort

Speaker: NA
Text: of tbe enemy was an attempt to turn the

Speaker: NA
Text: right flank by a surprise attack at Milne

Speaker: NA
Text: Bay, but this move had been anticipated,

Speaker: NA
Text: and was frustrated. Provided the flank

Speaker: NA
Text: our defence line in New Guinea is not

Speaker: NA
Text: turned by the southward advance of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Japanese in the other islands to the east

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia, the Owen Stanley Range

Speaker: NA
Text: remains the front line defence of eastern

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. We have experienced fluctu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ating fortunes in the land campaign in

Speaker: NA
Text: New Guinea. I n the early stages the

Speaker: NA
Text: fight went against us, and there wen

Speaker: NA
Text: many criticisms of the commanders' con-

Speaker: NA
Text: duct of the operations. The results pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide a complete answer, but there are

Speaker: NA
Text: one or two aspects of the operations to

Speaker: NA
Text: which I shall refer.

Speaker: NA
Text: First, the operations at Milne Bay.

Speaker: NA
Text: Plans had been drawn up by the High

Speaker: NA
Text: Command for the establishment of a

Speaker: NA
Text: strongly defended base at Milne Bay long

Speaker: NA
Text: before the Japanese landed at Gona and

Speaker: NA
Text: Buna. Tbe High Command had anti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cipated the Japanese attack on Milne Bay,

Speaker: NA
Text: and when it came we were ready. A few

Speaker: NA
Text: days of sharp fighting brought a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plete Australian victory. The Japanese

Speaker: NA
Text: evacuated such of their surviving forces

Speaker: NA
Text: as they could, while the remnants scat-

Speaker: NA
Text: tered in the jungle and have since been

Speaker: NA
Text: mopped up. The success of this operation

Speaker: NA
Text: lay in the absolute secrecy that was

Speaker: NA
Text: ensured in the movement of forces to this

Speaker: NA
Text: area. The Government was fully aware

Speaker: NA
Text: of the move. I t was known also to

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Advisory War Council.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second aspect is the counter-

Speaker: NA
Text: offensive against the Japanese. Prior to

Speaker: NA
Text: the launching of our attack from Iori-

Speaker: NA
Text: baiwa towards the end of September, we

Speaker: NA
Text: had marshalled considerable forces in

Speaker: NA
Text: New Guinea. Actually we had more than

Speaker: NA
Text: doubled the strength of the land forces

Speaker: NA
Text: that were there in the early stages of the

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign. There had also been a trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: formation in air strength, amounting to

Speaker: NA
Text: multiplication of air forces and aero-

Speaker: NA
Text: dromes. All of this was, of course, highly

Speaker: NA
Text: secret information. The High Command

Speaker: NA
Text: had drawn up plans for an outflanking

Speaker: NA
Text: movement against the Japanese, and bases

Speaker: NA
Text: were established on the north-eastern

Speaker: NA
Text: coast of New Guinea, to which American

Speaker: NA
Text: troops in considerable strength were

Speaker: NA
Text: transported by air. These troops attacked

Speaker: NA
Text: Buna from the right, whilst other

Speaker: NA
Text: American units joined up with Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Cwrtin.

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian troops in a frontal.assault. Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: of currently with this, Australian forces

Speaker: NA
Text: attacked Gona. These plans had been

Speaker: NA
Text: formulated before the critics had voiced

Speaker: NA
Text: their opinions, and, while they were urg-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing outflanking movements and the like,

Speaker: NA
Text: the High Command was pushing ahead

Speaker: NA
Text: with its preparations. As Mr Churchill

Speaker: NA
Text: recently explained, it takes considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: time to marshal forces and supplies to

Speaker: NA
Text: mount an offensive. What may appear

Speaker: NA
Text: to be a period of inaction is really one of

Speaker: NA
Text: intense activity covered by a veil of

Speaker: NA
Text: secrecy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n actual fact, had two brigades of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Sixth Division, Australian Imperial

Speaker: NA
Text: Force, not been diverted - to the defence

Speaker: NA
Text: of Ceylon on their way home from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Middle East, the Commander-in-Chief

Speaker: NA
Text: would have had these additional resources

Speaker: NA
Text: of battle-trained troops for the defence of

Speaker: NA
Text: New Guinea. Australian troops were the

Speaker: NA
Text: onlv forces readily available to meet a

Speaker: NA
Text: critical situation in the defence of a

Speaker: NA
Text: vital base in the Indian Ocean. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government readily agreed to the request

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Advisory War Council endorsed

Speaker: NA
Text: the decision. The full facts of the posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion could not be disclosed at the time

Speaker: NA
Text: without prejudicing our own interests

Speaker: NA
Text: and benefiting those of the enemy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would make these observations: I t

Speaker: NA
Text: is a misrepresentation of the spirit of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian people and the Anzac

Speaker: NA
Text: tradition to cry out when things appear

Speaker: NA
Text: to be going against us. I t is premature

Speaker: NA
Text: for critics to rush in and criticize a phase

Speaker: NA
Text: of an operation as though it were the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole campaign that was being decided.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has all the facts before

Speaker: NA
Text: it. I f it is dissatisfied with the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: manders, it will take appropriate action.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unless and until that position arises, it

Speaker: NA
Text: will place the fullest confidence in tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: commanders and the troops under them,

Speaker: NA
Text: and give them the utmost support against

Speaker: NA
Text: ill-informed or unwarranted criticism.

Speaker: NA
Text: After the Australian troops had pushed

Speaker: NA
Text: the Japanese out of Ioribaiwa they con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinued their advance without making con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tact with the enemy for ten days. The

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulty of communications, which had

Speaker: NA
Text: so greatly hampered us in the early

Speaker: NA
Text: stages in maintaining supplies and rein-

Speaker: NA
Text: forcements for the forward areas, also

Speaker: NA
Text: proved a stumbling block to the enemy.

Speaker: NA
Text: General MACArthur expressed the posire-establish

Speaker: NA
Text: tion as follows in his communique of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 8th October:-

Speaker: NA
Text: The enemy, as we expected and anticipated,

Speaker: NA
Text: bas discovered that his supply problems,

Speaker: NA
Text: vated by our constant air attacks, were

Speaker: NA
Text: possible of immediate solution. His dislodg-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment at his farthest point of advance and

Speaker: NA
Text: pursuit of his exhausted forces have been

Speaker: NA
Text: accomplished with practically no loss to

Speaker: NA
Text: troops up to the present time. The same

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties of terrain are now progressively the sick.

Speaker: NA
Text: slowing down the advance of our ground

Speaker: NA
Text: troops.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Japanese put up some resistance

Speaker: NA
Text: in the area of Templeton's Crossing, Eora

Speaker: NA
Text: Creek and Alola, but this was overcome,

Speaker: NA
Text: after stiff fighting. Kokoda was taken on

Speaker: NA
Text: the 2nd November with little or no oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition, but the enemy again endeavoured

Speaker: NA
Text: to halt our advance at Oivi, Gorari and

Speaker: NA
Text: Wairope. He was pushed out of these

Speaker: NA
Text: places and heavy losses were inflicted by

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian troops. I have just received

Speaker: NA
Text: advice - from the General Officer Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: manding that allied forces have com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely occupied the Gona area and that

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe Japanese are now pinned down in a

Speaker: NA
Text: narrow coastal strip in the Buna area.

Speaker: NA
Text: Allied air forces are maintaining con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinuous bombing and strafing attacks

Speaker: NA
Text: upon enemy ground troops and the enemy

Speaker: NA
Text: air base at Lae. The Japanese have

Speaker: NA
Text: made frequent attempts to land rein-

Speaker: NA
Text: forcements. Many of them have been

Speaker: NA
Text: repulsed by allied air forces, which have

Speaker: NA
Text: taken a heavy toll of enemy naval forces

Speaker: NA
Text: and shipping. I t is known, however, that

Speaker: NA
Text: some attempts made under cover of dark-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness, and in weather conditions unfavor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able for the effective employment of our

Speaker: NA
Text: aircraft, have been successful. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Japanese, operating in prepared defence

Speaker: NA
Text: positions, are resisting stubbornly, but

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian and American troops are

Speaker: NA
Text: gradually pressing home the attack.

Speaker: NA
Text: This operation has been notable for

Speaker: NA
Text: the manner in which it has been achieved.

Speaker: NA
Text: The original occupation of Gona and New Guinea.

Speaker: NA
Text: Buna was rendered possible because of

Speaker: NA
Text: Japanese control of the sea to the north

Speaker: NA
Text: of New Guinea. I n the absence of

Speaker: NA
Text: allied sea-power in this region, our

Speaker: NA
Text: vance has been overland and by air. Now

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have aerodromes on the northern

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the Owen Stanley Range, i t

Speaker: NA
Text: mains to be seen whether the enemy is

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to risk heavy losses against

Speaker: NA
Text: land-based aircraft in an endeavour

Speaker: NA
Text: himself again in this region.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Army battle casualties in

Speaker: NA
Text: New Guinea, excluding Rabaul, to the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1st December were 2,190, of whom 640

Speaker: NA
Text: aggrawere killed in action or died of wounds.

Speaker: NA
Text: imThe figures do not include the sick. I

Speaker: NA
Text: the speak for the whole Parliament when I

Speaker: NA
Text: offer the tribute of the nation to those

Speaker: NA
Text: our who gave their lives in its defence. The

Speaker: NA
Text: same gratitude is due to the wounded and

Speaker: NA
Text: There has been increased enemy activity

Speaker: NA
Text: in Timor, and allied air forces have

Speaker: NA
Text: maintained bombing attacks on enemy

Speaker: NA
Text: occupied areas in this island. Successful

Speaker: NA
Text: raids have been made on enemy aero-

Speaker: NA
Text: dromes, supply installations and barracks

Speaker: NA
Text: at Dilli and enemy occupied villages, and

Speaker: NA
Text: also at Koepang. Last week's daylight

Speaker: NA
Text: raid on the aerodrome at Koepang had

Speaker: NA
Text: excellent results. The enemy was taken

Speaker: NA
Text: by surprise and 21 of his aircraft, caught

Speaker: NA
Text: on the ground, were damaged or des-

Speaker: NA
Text: troyed. Japanese aircraft raided Darwin

Speaker: NA
Text: three times during the last week of

Speaker: NA
Text: November. The raids were made at

Speaker: NA
Text: night and little damage was caused.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our guerrilla forces in Timor have

Speaker: NA
Text: been doing bold and courageous work.

Speaker: NA
Text: Though the spotlight has been more on

Speaker: NA
Text: New Guinea because of the larger forces

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged, the people of Australia should

Speaker: NA
Text: not overlook the importance of Timor as

Speaker: NA
Text: a base for operations against the north-

Speaker: NA
Text: west of Australia. Timor is the counter-

Speaker: NA
Text: part in the north-west of New Guinea

Speaker: NA
Text: in the north-east. Known Japanese dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: positions and movements of their forces

Speaker: NA
Text: indicate that the enemy realizes this fact

Speaker: NA
Text: equally with ourselves. We must be pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to repulse all air and sea-borne

Speaker: NA
Text: attacks against Australia from this

Speaker: NA
Text: quarter. I t is equally important that

Speaker: NA
Text: when the time comes we should be ready

Speaker: NA
Text: and able to eject the Japanese from theix

Speaker: NA
Text: bases in this region as much as from

Speaker: NA
Text: The severe naval defeat inflicted by

Speaker: NA
Text: the American forces on the Japanese in

Speaker: NA
Text: adtbe middle of November frustrated a

Speaker: NA
Text: determined attempt to recapture Guadal-

Speaker: NA
Text: canal. Like the Coral Sea battle, it was

Speaker: NA
Text: rea victory which had great significance

Speaker: NA
Text: for the security of Australia, and I ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: our pressed to the President of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: to States of America tbe admiration and

Speaker: NA
Text: gratitude of the Australian people for

Speaker: NA
Text: the gallant deeds of the American forces.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Japanese have sought to exploit

Speaker: NA
Text: two lines of advance from bases at Rabaul

Speaker: NA
Text: and other centres in this region of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific. One was against New Guinea,

Speaker: NA
Text: which has been several times frustrated-

Speaker: NA
Text: in the attempted advance from Lae and

Speaker: NA
Text: Salamaua, in the Coral .Sea battle, at

Speaker: NA
Text: Milne Bay, and in the counter-offensive

Speaker: NA
Text: over the Owen Stanley range. The other

Speaker: NA
Text: thmst has been the attempt to advance

Speaker: NA
Text: through the .Solomons to islands in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific in order to secure bases nearer to

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe American line of communication

Speaker: NA
Text: across the Pacific. This would also

Speaker: NA
Text: assist in isolating Australia and would

Speaker: NA
Text: turn the flank of our position in New

Speaker: NA
Text: Guinea.

Speaker: NA
Text: The importance of the Solomon Islands

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Japanese plan will be evident from

Speaker: NA
Text: the heavy price they are prepared to pa.y

Speaker: NA
Text: for the recapture of the footholds secured

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Americans. The enemy is, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, still powerful, for he has naval,

Speaker: NA
Text: land and air forces of considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: strength. As he is a determined foe,

Speaker: NA
Text: we can expect that he will come again.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Americans have demonstrated a

Speaker: NA
Text: superiority on land, sea, and in the air

Speaker: NA
Text: and a capacity to reinforce their forces

Speaker: NA
Text: at Guadalcanal, which, it is hoped, is a

Speaker: NA
Text: good omen for tbe ultimate result of the

Speaker: NA
Text: conflict in the South Pacific Area.

Speaker: NA
Text: There has recently been some public

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion in the press of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations on two questions:-

Speaker: NA
Text: (i) The machinery for operational

Speaker: NA
Text: control in the Pacific;

Speaker: NA
Text: (ii) The flow of forces to the South-

Speaker: NA
Text: west Pacific Area.

Speaker: NA
Text: The grand strategy for the whole war,

Speaker: NA
Text: insofar as the British Empire and the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States of America are concerned,

Speaker: NA
Text: is determined by the Combined British

Speaker: NA
Text: and American Chiefs of Staff in "Wash-

Speaker: NA
Text: ington. They are responsible to Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Churchill and President Roosevelt. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific Ocean is a zone of American

Speaker: NA
Text: strategic responsibility, and is divided

Speaker: NA
Text: into several areas, each of which is under

Speaker: NA
Text: an American commander. In the case

Speaker: NA
Text: of the South-west Pacific Area, which

Speaker: NA
Text: includes Australia, the Government, with

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe concurrence of the Advisory War

Speaker: NA
Text: Council, agreed to a set-up under which

Speaker: NA
Text: JIfr. Curtin.

Speaker: NA
Text: General MACArthur is the Supreme

Speaker: NA
Text: Commander. He is responsible for

Speaker: NA
Text: operational strategy to the Chief of Staff

Speaker: NA
Text: of the United States of America Army

Speaker: NA
Text: as the. executive agency for the Joint

Speaker: NA
Text: United States of America Chiefs of

Speaker: NA
Text: Staff. The directive issued to General

Speaker: NA
Text: MACArthur and agreed to by the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Government specifies the objec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives which his operations will be

Speaker: NA
Text: designed to accomplish. I n fulfilment

Speaker: NA
Text: of the commitments accepted under this

Speaker: NA
Text: directive, the Australian Government

Speaker: NA
Text: assigned to the command of General

Speaker: NA
Text: MACArthur the combat forces of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Navy, Army, and A i r Eorce.

Speaker: NA
Text: [ make i t clear that tliere is the closest

Speaker: NA
Text: and most harmonious co-operation be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween the Commander-in-Chief and my-

Speaker: NA
Text: self as head of the Australian Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. There is also close and effective

Speaker: NA
Text: co-operation between the Commanders

Speaker: NA
Text: of the South-west and South Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Areas. This is demonstrated by General

Speaker: NA
Text: MACArthur's communiques on the opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of his aircraft in the South Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Area, and by the presence of H.M.A.S.

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra iu that region, when i t was

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunately sunk.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the Australian Government

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed to this unique set-up, under which

Speaker: NA
Text: it surrendered a part of its sovereignty

Speaker: NA
Text: and placed its defence forces under the

Speaker: NA
Text: control of a commander of an allied

Speaker: NA
Text: uarion, it did so, of'Course, on the clear

Speaker: NA
Text: understanding that its action would facili-

Speaker: NA
Text: tate the achievement of two results:-

Speaker: NA
Text: First, there would Ibe unified direction of

Speaker: NA
Text: the operations in the South-west Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Area under an American commander;

Speaker: NA
Text: and, secondly, the Australian Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, having placed its military re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sources under this commander, would

Speaker: NA
Text: have made the maximum contribution of

Speaker: NA
Text: which it was capable towards the achieve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the objectives laid down in the

Speaker: NA
Text: directive for the South-west Pacific Area.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having done so, it would have every

Speaker: NA
Text: right to expect that any additional

Speaker: NA
Text: strength required would be furnished

Speaker: NA
Text: from other sources.

Speaker: NA
Text: This view was based on no selfish

Speaker: NA
Text: motives. I t was dictated by the stra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tegical needs of a war with Japan. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: was warranted by the co-operation which

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian naval, land, and air forces had

Speaker: NA
Text: given in other theatres of war.

Speaker: NA
Text: I explained, in some detail, at the last

Speaker: NA
Text: secret session, the exchanges of views that

Speaker: NA
Text: had passed between. Mir. Churchill, Presi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dent Roosevelt, and myself on Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: strategy, and the needs of the South-west

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific Area in particular. Mr Churchill

Speaker: NA
Text: and President Roosevelt were unable

Speaker: NA
Text: fully to accept the views of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government on Pacific strategy, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: provision of the forces and supplies

Speaker: NA
Text: sought. However, they gave certain

Speaker: NA
Text: assurances and practical support, for

Speaker: NA
Text: which the Government is deeply grateful,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it felt bound to accept their conclu-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions in a spirit of united comradeship.

Speaker: NA
Text: The essential question confronting the

Speaker: NA
Text: Combined Chiefs of Staff in Washington

Speaker: NA
Text: is how the war can be most vigorously

Speaker: NA
Text: waged on all fronts, and the resources of

Speaker: NA
Text: the United Nations disposed to bring

Speaker: NA
Text: about the speedy and certain defeat of

Speaker: NA
Text: the enemy. The landings in the French

Speaker: NA
Text: colonies in North Africa, which .entail

Speaker: NA
Text: large demands on these resources, have

Speaker: NA
Text: now been publicly explained by the Presi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dent as having been based on a decision

Speaker: NA
Text: reached by Mr Churchill and himself

Speaker: NA
Text: during Mr Churchill's visit to America

Speaker: NA
Text: at the end of last year. A t the time that

Speaker: NA
Text: the President and Mr Churchill reached

Speaker: NA
Text: their decision to defeat Germany first,

Speaker: NA
Text: the transformation had not come over the

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific situation by the loss of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Philippines, Singapore, and the Nether-

Speaker: NA
Text: lands East Indies. We should therefore

Speaker: NA
Text: not lose sight of the significance for us in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia of the predictions of Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Churchill, during his broadcast of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 29 th November, on the duration and

Speaker: NA
Text: course of the war. Notwithstanding

Speaker: NA
Text: the concentration of Anglo-American

Speaker: NA
Text: strength against the Axis powers' in

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe, Mr Churchill said-

Speaker: NA
Text: I know nothing that has happened yet which

Speaker: NA
Text: justifies the hope tbat the war w i l l not

Speaker: NA
Text: or that bloody years w i l l not lie ahead.

Speaker: NA
Text: Predicting that the war in Europe may

Speaker: NA
Text: end -before the war in the Pacific, he

Speaker: NA
Text: brings out clearly the significance of the

Speaker: NA
Text: warning in my own broadcast on the 4th

Speaker: NA
Text: October-

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, therefore, has the task of holding

Speaker: NA
Text: the enemy until the potential becomes the

Speaker: NA
Text: reality and we can strike with all the punching

Speaker: NA
Text: power of the United Nations. U n t i l that day

Speaker: NA
Text: comes, we must hang grimly on.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n Libya, the Eighth Army is now in

Speaker: NA
Text: contact with Rommel's forces near El-

Speaker: NA
Text: Agheila. When plans were laid for the

Speaker: NA
Text: offensive against Rommel's position at El

Speaker: NA
Text: Alamein, the fact was recognized that it

Speaker: NA
Text: would he necessary to make a direct fron-

Speaker: NA
Text: tal assault on those positions, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: this might involve protracted fighting and

Speaker: NA
Text: heavy casualties. After twelve days of

Speaker: NA
Text: bitter combat, the German forces, who for

Speaker: NA
Text: once proved swifter than their Italian

Speaker: NA
Text: comrades in reaching the available trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: port, were in full flight, leaving the hulk

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Italians to their fate. The Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Ninth Division played an out-

Speaker: NA
Text: standing part in this battle, and Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Churchill and President Roosevelt, in

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulatory messages to me, have both

Speaker: NA
Text: generously acknowledged the distin-

Speaker: NA
Text: guished services rendered by the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian troops. I t will be recalled that

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Churchill announced that the total

Speaker: NA
Text: casualties sustained by the British and

Speaker: NA
Text: Allied Forces were 13,600 officers and

Speaker: NA
Text: men. The Ninth Division lost 2,740, of

Speaker: NA
Text: whom 620 were killed in action or died

Speaker: NA
Text: of wounds. To these men who have

Speaker: NA
Text: fought in distant countries for the de-

Speaker: NA
Text: fence of their homeland, we pay the same

Speaker: NA
Text: tribute as we do to their comrades in

Speaker: NA
Text: arms who have defended their country in

Speaker: NA
Text: New Guinea and in other parts of the

Speaker: NA
Text: South-west Pacific Area -

Speaker: NA
Text: Following closely on the victory of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Eighth Army in Egypt, the allied land-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings in French North Africa have exerted

Speaker: NA
Text: fresh pressure on the enemy. This new

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign has compelled Hitler to divert

Speaker: NA
Text: troops and aircraft to the defence of

Speaker: NA
Text: Bizerta and Tunis. I t has also forced

Speaker: NA
Text: him to move into unoccupied France, and

Speaker: NA
Text: has deprived him of his final hope of

Speaker: NA
Text: securing the French Fleet for the Axis.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although not a second front in Europe, it

Speaker: NA
Text: has, in President Roosevelt's words, pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: be long vided " effective second-front assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: for our heroic ally, Russia ", and its effect

Speaker: NA
Text: in relieving pressure on the Russian front

Speaker: NA
Text: should be considerable. We look forward

Speaker: NA
Text: to the time when the allied drives from

Speaker: NA
Text: east and west will achieve the final ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pulsion of the Axis from the African

Speaker: NA
Text: continent. When that is done, the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations will have fresh bases for offen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive action against the enemy, and

Speaker: NA
Text: especially against Italy. As M . Stalin

Speaker: NA
Text: has said, the allied campaign in Africa

Speaker: NA
Text: " demonstrates the growing might of the

Speaker: NA
Text: allied armed forces and opens up a pros-

Speaker: NA
Text: pect of the disintegration of the Italian

Speaker: NA
Text: and German coalition in the very near

Speaker: NA
Text: future ".

Speaker: NA
Text: The magnificent fight by the Russians

Speaker: NA
Text: is one of the inspiring things of this war.

Speaker: NA
Text: Attacked when the Germans were at the

Speaker: NA
Text: height of their military power and able

Speaker: NA
Text: to concentrate their forces on a single

Speaker: NA
Text: front, the Russians have heroically with-

Speaker: NA
Text: stood tremendous enemy pressure through

Speaker: NA
Text: two hitter campaigns. They suffered

Speaker: NA
Text: immense territorial losses, hut the

Speaker: NA
Text: Russian armies were not destroyed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Hitler underestimated Russian powers of

Speaker: NA
Text: recuperation and the strength of Russia's

Speaker: NA
Text: reserves, and our gallant ally is now

Speaker: NA
Text: striking back fiercely against the invader.

Speaker: NA
Text: Air activity on the Western Front con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinues. Whilst the British heavy bombing

Speaker: NA
Text: raids have recently been directed more at

Speaker: NA
Text: Italy than formerly, Germany and Ger-

Speaker: NA
Text: man-occupied parts in France have re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceived their share. New types of aircraft

Speaker: NA
Text: and new and heavier bombs up to 8,000

Speaker: NA
Text: lb. in weight are being employed. Ameri-

Speaker: NA
Text: can bombers are taking an ever-increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: part in raids over the Continent. The

Speaker: NA
Text: heavy raids on Genoa, Milan and Turin,

Speaker: NA
Text: which have been achieved with excep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionally low casualties on our side, are

Speaker: NA
Text: a foretaste of what Italy may expect

Speaker: NA
Text: when the occupation of the North A f r

Speaker: NA
Text: can coastline is complete. Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Empire Air Training Scheme squadrons

Speaker: NA
Text: are participating in these raids, whilst

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Sundei'land Squadron,

Speaker: NA
Text: based on Britain, is operating effectively

Speaker: NA
Text: for the protection of shipping and offen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive patrols against U-boats. Our fighter

Speaker: NA
Text: squadron in the Middle East has con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinued to add to its great reputation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Despite acute economic difficulties and

Speaker: NA
Text: supply problems, the Chinese people con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue their resistance to the Japanese. In

Speaker: NA
Text: Central China, the Chinese armies have

Speaker: NA
Text: reoccupied the territory which was occu-

Speaker: NA
Text: pied by the Japanese in June and July.

Speaker: NA
Text: A notable feature of recent fighting has

Speaker: NA
Text: been the work of the American air force,

Speaker: NA
Text: which has attacked, with success, enemy

Speaker: NA
Text: aerodromes, troop concentrations and

Speaker: NA
Text: shipping. Attacks on shipping are par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly important in view of the increas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing evidence of a Japanese shortage of

Speaker: NA
Text: shipping tonnage.

Speaker: NA
Text: ilr. Curtin.

Speaker: NA
Text: As honorable members know, I for-

Speaker: NA
Text: warded a message to Generalissimo

Speaker: NA
Text: Chiang Kai-Shek; on the occasion of the

Speaker: NA
Text: first anniversary of the outbreak of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific War, in which I conveyed to him

Speaker: NA
Text: our deep appreciation of the courage and

Speaker: NA
Text: tenacity with which the Chinese armed

Speaker: NA
Text: forces and civil population have resisted

Speaker: NA
Text: the Japanese aggressors for so many

Speaker: NA
Text: years, and our confidence in the power

Speaker: NA
Text: and determination of China, under his

Speaker: NA
Text: leadership, to wage this war to a success-

Speaker: NA
Text: ful conclusion.

Speaker: NA
Text: The strategic position of Madagascar

Speaker: NA
Text: has always made it a matter of special

Speaker: NA
Text: interest to Australia that i t should not

Speaker: NA
Text: be permitted to come under enemy con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trol. The renewed military operations in

Speaker: NA
Text: the island, which were rendered necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: by the refusal of the local authorities to

Speaker: NA
Text: allow proper measures to be taken to deny

Speaker: NA
Text: the use of the island to the Axis, were

Speaker: NA
Text: successfully concluded early in November.

Speaker: NA
Text: The occupation by the Fighting French

Speaker: NA
Text: of Reunion, which lies between Mada-

Speaker: NA
Text: gascar and. Mauritius, will further

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthen tbe position in the western

Speaker: NA
Text: Indian Ocean.

Speaker: NA
Text: Shipping continues to be a grave prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem. Whilst we look forward to a steady

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in the flow of new tonnage from

Speaker: NA
Text: the shipbuilding yards of tbe United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations, i t must be remembered, as Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: i - Churchill has recently pointed out, that

Speaker: NA
Text: the U-boat war is not diminishing but

Speaker: NA
Text: growing. Moreover, the offensive phase

Speaker: NA
Text: of our strategy creates extremely heavy

Speaker: NA
Text: demands for sea transport. I n our

Speaker: NA
Text: waters, there has been reduced submarine

Speaker: NA
Text: activity and the Australian and Ameri-

Speaker: NA
Text: can naval forces in the South-west Paci-

Speaker: NA
Text: fic area have been continuing their

Speaker: NA
Text: effective work. Enemy submarines have

Speaker: NA
Text: been active in the Indian Ocean and, as

Speaker: NA
Text: announced, surface raiders and supply

Speaker: NA
Text: ships have been sunk. Our shipping posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is that, in addition to our increased

Speaker: NA
Text: war-time industrial requirements, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have had to divert ships from normal

Speaker: NA
Text: services to cope with increased military

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements. This has placed a severe

Speaker: NA
Text: strain on our limited transport facilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has had some success

Speaker: NA
Text: in its endeavours to secure additional

Speaker: NA
Text: shipping from overseas sources, - and our

Speaker: NA
Text: own shipbuilding programme will be of

Speaker: NA
Text: material assistance; but the position is

Speaker: NA
Text: still acute. I n order to ensure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: maximum use is made of the shipping

Speaker: NA
Text: actually available, it was recently decided

Speaker: NA
Text: to establish a new department, known as

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of Supply and Shipping,

Speaker: NA
Text: which brings under a single co-ordinated

Speaker: NA
Text: direction the various agencies which are

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned with the control of shipping.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has much to be thankful for.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have felt the impact of enemy bombs

Speaker: NA
Text: on a number of our northern towns and

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney has been attacked, but we have

Speaker: NA
Text: been spared the horror of the devastation

Speaker: NA
Text: of war on our own soil. The victories

Speaker: NA
Text: won at Coral Sea, Midway Island and

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Solomons were of crucial impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance to us. There should be throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole continent a universal feeling

Speaker: NA
Text: of deep gratitude and thanksgiving for

Speaker: NA
Text: what we have so far been spared. Origi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nally, Britain stood alone between Ger-

Speaker: NA
Text: many and the world. Later the gallant

Speaker: NA
Text: Russian people withstood the full might

Speaker: NA
Text: of the German military machine. Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cently, it has been American sea-power

Speaker: NA
Text: which has been the shield between Japan

Speaker: NA
Text: and Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The immunity frbm attack which we

Speaker: NA
Text: have enjoyed has enabled our war pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction programme to proceed unhin-

Speaker: NA
Text: dered. Our greatly improved defensive

Speaker: NA
Text: position has made it possible to relax in

Speaker: NA
Text: some measure the air raid precautions

Speaker: NA
Text: originally imposed, but constant vigil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance and perfection of their training and

Speaker: NA
Text: preparations should be the aim of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Home Security Services.

Speaker: NA
Text: The production of war material of all

Speaker: NA
Text: kinds has greatly increased, so much so

Speaker: NA
Text: that it has now been thought desirable to

Speaker: NA
Text: set up in Australia machinery for the

Speaker: NA
Text: allocation of Australian munitions pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction similar to that which exists in

Speaker: NA
Text: the United Kingdom and the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States. This does not mean, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is a surplus of all classes of

Speaker: NA
Text: munitions in this country. I t does indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cate, however, that our output of many

Speaker: NA
Text: kinds of munitions is sufficiently

Speaker: NA
Text: justify the extension to Australian pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction of the pooling arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed upon between Mr Churchill and

Speaker: NA
Text: President Roosevelt in January last, with

Speaker: NA
Text: respect to British and American pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction.

Speaker: NA
Text: In some items of munitions we are

Speaker: NA
Text: within measurable distance of fulfilling

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole of the needs of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: forces. But, as fast as one requirement

Speaker: NA
Text: is fulfilled, other demands arise and must

Speaker: NA
Text: be met. We are faced with problems

Speaker: NA
Text: associated with the re-allocation of pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ductive capacity, and it will he necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: to divert our technical resources and

Speaker: NA
Text: skilled man-power from projects which

Speaker: NA
Text: have been fulfilled or whose completion is

Speaker: NA
Text: in sight, to other high priority projects.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n doing this, the Government will - be

Speaker: NA
Text: guided by the advice of its service and

Speaker: NA
Text: technical advisers, which will, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: -be related to the plan of operations for

Speaker: NA
Text: the South-west Pacific area. Tbe primary

Speaker: NA
Text: concern of the whole nation must be to

Speaker: NA
Text: supply the needs of our fighting men.

Speaker: NA
Text: This will be the essential consideration

Speaker: NA
Text: which will govern the allotment of man-

Speaker: NA
Text: power, including women, and use of our

Speaker: NA
Text: material and financial resources.

Speaker: NA
Text: As to the prospects for the future and

Speaker: NA
Text: the duration of the struggle, I would

Speaker: NA
Text: remind every Australian of the

Speaker: NA
Text: basis on which Mr Churchill

Speaker: NA
Text: reached his conclusion that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing to justify an optimistic view that

Speaker: NA
Text: the end is in sight. He referred to an

Speaker: NA
Text: enslaved Europe with all its resources

Speaker: NA
Text: at Germany's disposal. He pointed out

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Eighth Army in Africa had

Speaker: NA
Text: defeated only a few divisions of Ger-

Speaker: NA
Text: many's great army. He mentioned that

Speaker: NA
Text: the U-boat menace is not diminishing,

Speaker: NA
Text: but growing. So much for the task of

Speaker: NA
Text: defeating Germany, but what about

Speaker: NA
Text: Japan? I t , too, is master of vast terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tories with large populations and vital

Speaker: NA
Text: resources for the waging of war. Though

Speaker: NA
Text: Japan has suffered certain naval and air

Speaker: NA
Text: losses, its strength is still great. Like

Speaker: NA
Text: Germany, Japan prepared for this war

Speaker: NA
Text: for years and did not strike until it was

Speaker: NA
Text: ready to do so and considered the situa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion favorable for success. I t should not

Speaker: NA
Text: be overlooked that we are fighting the

Speaker: NA
Text: enemy at places vital to our own security

Speaker: NA
Text: and far removed from his own final ram-

Speaker: NA
Text: large to parts of defence.

Speaker: NA
Text: We must realize that we are up against

Speaker: NA
Text: a powerful fighting machine. I t is backed

Speaker: NA
Text: by a people whose training and discipline

Speaker: NA
Text: produce a national morale which will-

Speaker: NA
Text: ingly accepts the utmost sacrifice, includ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing death itself, for the national cause.

Speaker: NA
Text: Such a race can be beaten only by actual

Speaker: NA
Text: physical defeat. We, therefore, must be

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to make such sacrifices for vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory as will enable us to match and over-

Speaker: NA
Text: come a foe so thoroughly trained to the

Speaker: NA
Text: needs of total war. This is tbe prescrip-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion for victory which I adjure all Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians to observe.

Speaker: NA
Text: I lay on the table the following

Speaker: NA
Text: paper:-

Speaker: NA
Text: Review of War Situation-Ministeria l state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, 10th December, 1942.

Speaker: NA
Text: and move -

Speaker: NA
Text: That the paper be printed.

Speaker: Mr FADDEN
Text: Darling Downs-Leade r

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition) [3.43] -Th e specific

Speaker: NA
Text: reason why Parliament has been called is

Speaker: NA
Text: together for this two days' sitting was

Speaker: NA
Text: hear the statement which honorable memany

Speaker: NA
Text: bers have just been privileged to hear

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Prime Minister ( Mr Curtin).

Speaker: NA
Text: That statement sets out the problems

Speaker: NA
Text: which the Government considered should

Speaker: NA
Text: be placed before honorable members as

Speaker: NA
Text: the trustees of the people of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Consequently the House was entitled

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that the contents of the statement

Speaker: NA
Text: would set out the major problems that

Speaker: NA
Text: are confronting the Government to-day. tance

Speaker: NA
Text: On that assessment, the House must be of

Speaker: NA
Text: profoundly disappointed because the tralian

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister's review contained no

Speaker: NA
Text: reference whatsoever to the need for a strategy

Speaker: NA
Text: united Australian Army available for serOpposition

Speaker: NA
Text: vice anywhere as required, without limitathis country.

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. The House in general, and honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members on this side of the chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: in particular, must be alarmed at the

Speaker: NA
Text: action of the Prime Minister in neglectis

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to place before Parliament, which

Speaker: NA
Text: consists of the elected trustees of the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of this country, information

Speaker: NA
Text: least similar to that which he placed

Speaker: NA
Text: before the conference of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour party which met on the 17th in

Speaker: NA
Text: November last. As the Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: in his statement, has completely ignored

Speaker: NA
Text: this very important matter^ which

Speaker: NA
Text: be as disturbing to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: strategy as the right honorable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: has said it is to the High Command, I a

Speaker: NA
Text: intend to make a precise statement of the

Speaker: NA
Text: facts in chronological order, so that this to

Speaker: NA
Text: House and the people of Australia may

Speaker: NA
Text: have clearly before them the attitude that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition has persistently and connecessary

Speaker: NA
Text: sistently adopted in urging a maximum wealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: war effort for the defence of Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: since the outbreak of war with Japan.

Speaker: NA
Text: This House was called together on the

Speaker: NA
Text: 16th December, 1941, a little more than

Speaker: NA
Text: a week after Japan had invaded, and

Speaker: NA
Text: ruthlessly and treacherously attacked.

Speaker: NA
Text: British and American territory. Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia was then at war with Japan. As

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister said on that occasion,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia was " the stake in the conflict".

Speaker: NA
Text: On the 17th December, on behalf of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition, I wrote to the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister a letter, the full text of which

Speaker: NA
Text: appears in Hansard of the 1st May, 1942.

Speaker: NA
Text: I shall quote some of the more important

Speaker: NA
Text: passages from it. I said-

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . i t appears to the Opposition that i t

Speaker: NA
Text: a l l important to create an Australian army

Speaker: NA
Text: to for the defertce of the Commonwealth which

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government can employ anywhere without

Speaker: NA
Text: statutory restrictions whatsoever. Malayn

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Pacific Islands are as truly part of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's defences as are our own coastal

Speaker: NA
Text: ports. I n our opinion the Government must

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to employ as i t may wish, and as the

Speaker: NA
Text: necessity demands, any Australian troops

Speaker: NA
Text: anywhere, be they voluntarily enlisted or

Speaker: NA
Text: to raised under the Defence Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: T h e letter c o n t i n u e d -

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . The Opposition stresses the impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: of meeting the enemy outside the shores

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia as well as within, and the dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinction which must be drawn between Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: Imperial Force and M i l i t i a at the

Speaker: NA
Text: present moment may seriously hamper the

Speaker: NA
Text: of your Government and interfere, tlie

Speaker: NA
Text: feels, with the adequate defence of

Speaker: NA
Text: 'The Prime Minister himself has empha-

Speaker: NA
Text: sized the importance of meeting the

Speaker: NA
Text: enemy outside Australia. Surely there

Speaker: NA
Text: not an honorable member of this House

Speaker: NA
Text: who does not recognize and appreciate to

Speaker: NA
Text: the full that the farther from Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: at shores the enemy can be met the better

Speaker: NA
Text: will the result be for us. Therefore, I

Speaker: NA
Text: assume-an d it cannot be disputed-tha t

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to this desirable objective the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition and the Government are on

Speaker: NA
Text: common ground. I n my letter to the

Speaker: NA
Text: must Prime Minister I stated further-

Speaker: NA
Text: While having no desire to raise any contro-

Speaker: NA
Text: versial political question, but animated with

Speaker: NA
Text: sincere wish to free the hands of your Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment, the Opposition would be prepared

Speaker: NA
Text: give unanimous support to a measure

Speaker: NA
Text: amending the National Security Act in such

Speaker: NA
Text: a manner as to enable the Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: employ any of our troops i n any area vitally

Speaker: NA
Text: for the defence of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: That is evidence of a sincere desire on

Speaker: NA
Text: the part of the Opposition to co-operate

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Government in the provision of

Speaker: NA
Text: what, in its opinion, was needed at that

Speaker: NA
Text: particular time for the adequate defence

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia. Every member of this

Speaker: NA
Text: House supported a resolution which

Speaker: NA
Text: pledged the Government to take every

Speaker: NA
Text: step deemed necessary to defend the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth and its territories, to carry on

Speaker: NA
Text: hostilities in association witb our Allies,

Speaker: NA
Text: and to achieve final victory over our

Speaker: NA
Text: enemies. That pledge was given unani-

Speaker: NA
Text: mously irrespective of party affiliations'

Speaker: NA
Text: by the trustees of the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia who constitute the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of this House. I repeat, that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition was mindful of the weak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness that existed for forward planning,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly for an offensive campaign,

Speaker: NA
Text: and was motivated entirely by that con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration when I , on its behalf, wrote

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Prime Minister on the 17tb

Speaker: NA
Text: December of last year. But the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment ignored my letter, and we have not

Speaker: NA
Text: since heard anything concerning it.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the House met la3t April, the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of an army merger was pressed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister then stated that the

Speaker: NA
Text: use of Australian forces, whatever their

Speaker: NA
Text: composition, involved advice from the

Speaker: NA
Text: High Command upon military strategy,

Speaker: NA
Text: and a statement of the forces tbat were

Speaker: NA
Text: required. He said that he knew of no

Speaker: NA
Text: demand imposed by military necessity

Speaker: NA
Text: upon his Government that he had not

Speaker: NA
Text: already satisfied, and declared that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government regarded an outright

Speaker: NA
Text: Japanese attack on Australia as a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stant and undiminished danger. Yet he

Speaker: NA
Text: was prepared to countenance, the exist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence of a divided army in Australia;

Speaker: NA
Text: and, indeed, he is still countenancing it,

Speaker: NA
Text: to the detriment of the adequate and

Speaker: NA
Text: indispensable defence of this country. At

Speaker: NA
Text: the same time, the Government looks to

Speaker: NA
Text: the United Nations to provide fighting

Speaker: NA
Text: forces that will amalgamate with our own

Speaker: NA
Text: forces wherever the enemy has to Be met.

Speaker: NA
Text: I now move

Speaker: NA
Text: GOVERNMENT MEMBERS -Ah !

Speaker: Mr FADDEN
Text: I now move to the

Speaker: NA
Text: events of the 1st May.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr CURTIN.!-Th e right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman gave them a fright.

Speaker: Mr FADDEN
Text: .Som e honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members will be greatly relieved when

Speaker: NA
Text: they learn that I do not intend to move

Speaker: NA
Text: in the direction that they feared I would.

Speaker: NA
Text: They need not be frightened, because the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition is mindful of tbe necessity to

Speaker: NA
Text: place national responsibilities and con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sequences above party political con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siderations. On the 1st May, a patient

Speaker: NA
Text: but responsible Opposition, through me,

Speaker: NA
Text: moved the following amendment to the

Speaker: NA
Text: motion for the printing of the statement

Speaker: NA
Text: on international affairs that had been

Speaker: NA
Text: made by the Prime Minister:-

Speaker: NA
Text: In order that the Australian Imperial Force

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Australian Military Forces may be

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively welded into one fighting army avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able for offence as well as defence, this House

Speaker: NA
Text: is of opinion that all territorial limitations

Speaker: NA
Text: upon the power of the Commonwealth Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to employ the Australian Military Forces

Speaker: NA
Text: should be removed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Not one Minister or Labour member ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vanced a convincing reason for refusing

Speaker: NA
Text: to take the action then suggested by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition. My amendment was rejected

Speaker: NA
Text: on party lines by 31 votes to 27, witb the

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance of alleged independents, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government again took refuge in

Speaker: NA
Text: silence. The gravity of the position was

Speaker: NA
Text: becoming greater. The situation i n the

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific had deteriorated so markedly that

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney was raided, bombs were dropped

Speaker: NA
Text: on Townsville, Darwin was consistently

Speaker: NA
Text: raided, Horn Island and Port Hedland

Speaker: NA
Text: were raided and bombed. Yet tbe Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment took no action, and was not

Speaker: NA
Text: mindful of its true responsibility.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n July and August last, the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition executive twice brought be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore the Government the need, in our

Speaker: NA
Text: opinion, for the merging of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Imperial Force and the Militia

Speaker: NA
Text: into one army for the adequate defence

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia. The executive charged the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government with having deliberately

Speaker: NA
Text: evaded the issue for many months. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: merely asked that preparations be made,

Speaker: NA
Text: by amendment of the Defence Act,

Speaker: NA
Text: to enable the Government, in its wisdom,

Speaker: NA
Text: to send Australian forces wherever, in

Speaker: NA
Text: the opinion of military experts, they

Speaker: NA
Text: might be required.

Speaker: NA
Text: We now move to September, 194©, in

Speaker: NA
Text: which month Parliament re-assembled

Speaker: NA
Text: and honorable members were given a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: view of the war situation along lines

Speaker: NA
Text: similar to that made to-day; but the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government then, as i t had been on the

Speaker: NA
Text: previous occasion, and as i t was again

Speaker: NA
Text: to-day, was silent on the proposal for the

Speaker: NA
Text: establishment of one army.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n October, 1942, my colleague tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Gippsland ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Paterson) raised the matter of having

Speaker: NA
Text: one army. The Minister for the Army

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Forde) then began what subse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quently developed into a policy of evasion

Speaker: NA
Text: on a grand scale. He revealed himself

Speaker: NA
Text: as one who was completely lacking in

Speaker: NA
Text: candour, and apparently afraid to risk

Speaker: NA
Text: saying anything that might make him

Speaker: NA
Text: unpopular with his political party and

Speaker: NA
Text: supporters. Either he did not know what

Speaker: NA
Text: was going on, or he was not frank enough

Speaker: NA
Text: to place the facts before the members of

Speaker: NA
Text: this Parliament as the trustees of the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Australia. He side-stepped the

Speaker: NA
Text: issue. He had much to say about trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: fers of the Militia to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Imperial Force, and of Australia honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing its obligations to the democracies,

Speaker: NA
Text: he evaded a direct reply to a direct ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. He must have known that adoption

Speaker: NA
Text: of the proposal put forward by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition was necessary for the defence

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia and its territories.

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for the Army, he must have

Speaker: NA
Text: been in close contact with the High

Speaker: NA
Text: Command, and with other officers who

Speaker: NA
Text: were competent to give him requisite

Speaker: NA
Text: advice.

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament again went into recess

Speaker: NA
Text: without any action by the Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: give one army to Australia, as bad been

Speaker: NA
Text: consistently and persistently proposed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition. On the 28th September

Speaker: NA
Text: last, the press reported that there was

Speaker: NA
Text: reason to believe that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: had no immediate intention of welding

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Imperial Force and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Militia into one army. The Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Army said that the Militia in New

Speaker: NA
Text: Guinea had already built up a tradition

Speaker: NA
Text: that would make anv government hesitate

Speaker: NA
Text: before taking action to destroy its separ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate identity. Members of the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion are fully alive to, and appreciate

Speaker: NA
Text: to the utmost, the valiant deeds of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Militia Forces in the theatres of war in

Speaker: NA
Text: which they have served. We pay tribute

Speaker: NA
Text: to them, and honour them for their heroic

Speaker: NA
Text: actions. We owe them a debt of grati-

Speaker: NA
Text: tude. They have been in the fight to

Speaker: NA
Text: keep the Japanese forces away from Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. The memhers of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Imperial Force have the same objective.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why, then, should the Minister for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Army make a distinction between them?

Speaker: NA
Text: Ilr. Fadden.

Speaker: NA
Text: Are not all these men Australian? Have

Speaker: NA
Text: they not shown themselves ready to

Speaker: NA
Text: sacrifice their lives in the cause of

Speaker: NA
Text: liberty? Have they not been fighting

Speaker: NA
Text: alongside an allied force which may

Speaker: NA
Text: be sent to any theatre in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Japanese menace may be encountered?

Speaker: NA
Text: All this talk about Australia honouring

Speaker: NA
Text: its obligations has a hollow ring. Could

Speaker: NA
Text: anything be more hypocritical than

Speaker: NA
Text: mouthing phrases about an all-in war

Speaker: NA
Text: effort and of driving the enemy from our

Speaker: NA
Text: shores, whilst at tbe same time refusing

Speaker: NA
Text: to allow a section of the Australian Army

Speaker: NA
Text: to fight alongside the forces of other

Speaker: NA
Text: nations beyond Australian territories

Speaker: NA
Text: and, indeed, if the occasion should arise,

Speaker: NA
Text: to help their own kith and kin who are

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Australian Imperial

Speaker: NA
Text: but Force? Let us face the facts. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: powerful allies in this fight. The mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of their forces are available to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: the enemy wherever he has to be fought.

Speaker: NA
Text: Their reason for being in this war is no

Speaker: NA
Text: As different from ours, and their object is

Speaker: NA
Text: to defeat a common enemy. Many of

Speaker: NA
Text: them have known the ravages of war in

Speaker: NA
Text: their own lands. Some of them have losf

Speaker: NA
Text: their homes, their possessions, and their

Speaker: NA
Text: families. Yet, whilst we expect them to

Speaker: NA
Text: help us, the Government has so far

Speaker: NA
Text: refused to give them the maximum assist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance which would he available i f the

Speaker: NA
Text: existing limitations upon the use of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Militia were expeditiously removed. Why

Speaker: NA
Text: should we have a divided army? On

Speaker: NA
Text: what grounds can the Government pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibly justify its refusal to weld the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Imperial Force and the Militia

Speaker: NA
Text: into one force, to fight alongside the

Speaker: NA
Text: forces of our allies? These are questions

Speaker: NA
Text: which have exercised the. minds of not

Speaker: NA
Text: only the Opposition, but also the people

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia, and, particularly, our allies.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the 27-th October, the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Army, speaking as Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, made the following state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment :-

Speaker: NA
Text: There is neither necessity nor justification

Speaker: NA
Text: for conscription for over-seas service to-day.

Speaker: NA
Text: I ask the House to link that statement

Speaker: NA
Text: with what has happened since the 17th

Speaker: NA
Text: November. The Minister went on tc

Speaker: NA
Text: say-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition believes that there is one

Speaker: NA
Text: issue which would certainly split the Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: party and divide the people of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: He said further-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government's attitude has been clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: defined. I t is opposed to conscription

Speaker: NA
Text: seas service, and the introduction of the issue

Speaker: NA
Text: at this critical period does a great disservice

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: He declared that, with the changed posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion following Japan's entry into the war,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the great increase of voluntary enlist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments in the Australian Imperial Force,

Speaker: NA
Text: there was less need for conscription for

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas service to-day than there had

Speaker: NA
Text: been at any previous time. After

Speaker: NA
Text: reiterating that the Opposition was doing

Speaker: NA
Text: the country a great disservice in raising

Speaker: NA
Text: the issue, the Deputy Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: said:-

Speaker: NA
Text: This issue, i f put into effect, would

Speaker: NA
Text: destroy the Government, hut would also divide

Speaker: NA
Text: the people and bring about disunity where

Speaker: NA
Text: unity and co-operation exist.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Deputy Prime Minister's statement

Speaker: NA
Text: had at least one merit: I t was exceed-

Speaker: NA
Text: ingly frank. He admitted unshamedly

Speaker: NA
Text: that the issue was one that would split

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labour party and destroy the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. The honorable gentleman is also

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for the Army. Are we to

Speaker: NA
Text: assume that the Army leaders advised

Speaker: NA
Text: him as to the nature of the statement he

Speaker: NA
Text: made on that occasion? Are we to assume

Speaker: NA
Text: that he and the Prime Minister are at

Speaker: NA
Text: variance now, and that it is still his belief

Speaker: NA
Text: that those who advocate the unity of the

Speaker: NA
Text: forces are doing a disservice to Australia ?

Speaker: NA
Text: The Deputy Prime Minister also stated

Speaker: NA
Text: that i f the Government failed, either in

Speaker: NA
Text: its defensive or offensive preparations,

Speaker: NA
Text: then would be the time for the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: to criticize. I remind the House, how-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, that i f the Opposition remained

Speaker: NA
Text: silent until then, it would be too late to

Speaker: NA
Text: do anything, and the fate of political

Speaker: NA
Text: parties and of governments would be of

Speaker: NA
Text: little account.

Speaker: NA
Text: We come now to the memorable 17th

Speaker: NA
Text: November. The Interstate Conference

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian Labour party was

Speaker: NA
Text: sitting in Melbourne, and tbe Prime Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister was there as a delegate of his own

Speaker: NA
Text: State of Western Australia, not as Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. According to press statements,

Speaker: NA
Text: it was announced to that conference

Speaker: NA
Text: that it would be asked to agree to

Speaker: NA
Text: an amendment of the Defence Act to per-

Speaker: NA
Text: mit the use of the Militia in certain de-

Speaker: NA
Text: fined areas in the Pacific. The Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, we read, told the conference

Speaker: NA
Text: that limitations upon the use of the

Speaker: NA
Text: for over- Militia imposed by the Defence Act

Speaker: NA
Text: were hampering the war plans of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Allied High Command in Australia. We

Speaker: NA
Text: may take it for granted that, before he

Speaker: NA
Text: made the statement, he had been in con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sultation with the High Command, and

Speaker: NA
Text: was aware of official opinion. We may

Speaker: NA
Text: assume that he had been told that the

Speaker: NA
Text: change was necessary, that the merging

Speaker: NA
Text: of the two armies was essential so that

Speaker: NA
Text: our forces might be used wherever re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quired. We may also assume that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister would tell the conference

Speaker: NA
Text: as much as he was able without violating

Speaker: NA
Text: official secrets. He would reveal to dele-

Speaker: NA
Text: not only gates enough to convince them that his

Speaker: NA
Text: decision on the subject should not be

Speaker: NA
Text: questioned, and that the Labour organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: zations should support him.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the Prime Minister sought leave

Speaker: NA
Text: to introduce his motion, i t was given by

Speaker: NA
Text: 28 votes to 8, the eight in opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: including a member of his own Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, Senator Cameron, and the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Melbourne ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Calwell). The text of the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: M i n i s t e r ' s m o t i o n is as f o l l o w s : -

Speaker: NA
Text: That having regard to the paramount

Speaker: NA
Text: necessity of Australia's defence as set out

Speaker: NA
Text: in section 5 of the special resolution adopted

Speaker: NA
Text: in June, 1940, by federal conference the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government be authorized to add to the Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Act i n the definition of the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: which at present defines the territories to

Speaker: NA
Text: which this act extends the following words:

Speaker: NA
Text: " And such other territories in the South-west

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific area as the Governor-General proclaims

Speaker: NA
Text: as being territories associated with the defence

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia."

Speaker: NA
Text: As the motion contains a reference to

Speaker: NA
Text: the resolution carried in June, 1940, I

Speaker: NA
Text: shall quote the text of that resolution

Speaker: NA
Text: for the information of honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: and of the Australian people. I t was as

Speaker: NA
Text: follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: National training for defence in the terms

Speaker: NA
Text: of the present Defence Act be maintained on

Speaker: NA
Text: the highest basis of efficiency with provision

Speaker: NA
Text: for an adequate system of physical training

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout Australia, by participating i n the

Speaker: NA
Text: Empire A i r Scheme; necessary provisions for

Speaker: NA
Text: reinforcements of the Australian Imperial

Speaker: NA
Text: Force; the extent of European participation

Speaker: NA
Text: by volunteer army to ibe determined by circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances as they arise, having regard to the

Speaker: NA
Text: paramount necessity of Australian defence.

Speaker: NA
Text: No doulbt the Prime Minister put for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward the plea, as would any responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian, that the adequate defence of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia cannot stop at the 3-mile

Speaker: NA
Text: limit. Would any one suggest that Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia has not for years been defended by

Speaker: NA
Text: what has taken place in the English

Speaker: NA
Text: Channel, the Mediterranean, Burma,

Speaker: NA
Text: China, and Rtissia? Obviously, Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia is to be defended wherever the

Speaker: NA
Text: enemy can be met and fought. I t is for

Speaker: NA
Text: that reason that the Prime Minister asked

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Labour party to agree to

Speaker: NA
Text: the amendment of the Defence Act so that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia might be defended in the man-

Speaker: NA
Text: ner stated to be necessary-state d not by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government or by the Opposition, but

Speaker: NA
Text: by those best able to offer an opinion, tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: High Command.

Speaker: NA
Text: The conference decided to adjourn con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration of the matter, and i t was re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred to the State branches for con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration so tbat they might direct their

Speaker: NA
Text: delegates how to vote at a special con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ference to be held not later than the end

Speaker: NA
Text: of December. Whilst the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: is to be commended for taking a realistic

Speaker: NA
Text: view of the situation, the manner in

Speaker: NA
Text: which he acted calls for comment. My

Speaker: NA
Text: view is that such an important matter

Speaker: NA
Text: was one for consideration, in the first

Speaker: NA
Text: place, by Cabinet and the Advisory War

Speaker: NA
Text: Council. The next move would have been

Speaker: NA
Text: to summon Parliament to consider it.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, I recognize the position of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister. He is a member of a

Speaker: NA
Text: party to which he has given a pledge,

Speaker: NA
Text: and he must submit to the rules and

Speaker: NA
Text: regulations of that party. The people

Speaker: NA
Text: must understand that every Labour repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentative whom they elect immediately

Speaker: NA
Text: passes beyond their control, and comes

Speaker: NA
Text: directly under the control of an irrespon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible party junta.

Speaker: NA
Text: One would have thought that the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister would have at least received

Speaker: NA
Text: the unanimous support of those whom

Speaker: NA
Text: he leads. He has persevered in support

Speaker: NA
Text: of the platform of his party up till now,

Speaker: NA
Text: and has resisted the consistent pressure

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition to amend the Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Act. No doubt he hoped from day to day

Speaker: NA
Text: that the war situation might improve and

Speaker: NA
Text: that it would not be necessary for him to

Speaker: NA
Text: humiliate himself by having to approach

Speaker: NA
Text: an outside organization and ask it to give

Speaker: NA
Text: him power to govern the nation in time

Speaker: NA
Text: of war. I am sure that the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter recognizes the humiliating position in

Speaker: NA
Text: which he has placed himself. Even then,

Speaker: NA
Text: ifr. Fadden.

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labour conference would not support

Speaker: NA
Text: him. I t "passed the buck" to the State

Speaker: NA
Text: executives, and in the meantime the war

Speaker: NA
Text: is raging and the position in the Pacific is

Speaker: NA
Text: no less grave that it was on the 17th

Speaker: NA
Text: November. I t is, as I have said, humilia-
