Speaker: NA
Text: ting thait a war-time Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: should have to approach a gathering of

Speaker: NA
Text: men representing, not the whole of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian people, but only a section of

Speaker: NA
Text: them. I t is a body entirely lacking i n

Speaker: NA
Text: official status, and we, as the elected

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives of the people, cannot con-

Speaker: NA
Text: done the method followed by the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. We are the elected represen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tatives of the people, and there is only

Speaker: NA
Text: one place where the military requirements

Speaker: NA
Text: of the nation should be decided-tha t is,

Speaker: NA
Text: in this Parliament. We recall the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's bold declaration in December,

Speaker: NA
Text: 1941, a few days after Japan entered

Speaker: NA
Text: the war-

Speaker: NA
Text: I say to tlie people of Australia, I cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: wait upon debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet, in November, 1942, the Prime Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister has been forced to wait until his

Speaker: NA
Text: party supporters debate an important

Speaker: NA
Text: question of national defence. He has told

Speaker: NA
Text: the people and his own organization that

Speaker: NA
Text: this is not a political matter, that it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: military necessity, one that is regarded as

Speaker: NA
Text: of the first importance by the High Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mand of the South Pacific.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the 19th November, there was still

Speaker: NA
Text: further delay. The federal executive of

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe Australian Labour party decided that

Speaker: NA
Text: the special conference would not be held

Speaker: NA
Text: until the 4th January of next year. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: the meantime, the war continues to

Speaker: NA
Text: rage, and necessary defence measures

Speaker: NA
Text: are being delayed. The Labour party

Speaker: NA
Text: is itself divided on this question,

Speaker: NA
Text: and for that very reason Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment should have been taken into the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister's confidence at the very

Speaker: NA
Text: earliest date. I t is an unpardonable

Speaker: NA
Text: thing that this House should be denied

Speaker: NA
Text: information which was placed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister before the executive of

Speaker: NA
Text: a political party. The Australian Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: party has decided to hold a further

Speaker: NA
Text: special conference on the 4th January-

Speaker: NA
Text: a delay of six and a half weeks following

Speaker: NA
Text: -the first conference. These little dictators

Speaker: NA
Text: were afraid to give the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: the authority he sought because they

Speaker: NA
Text: feared to risk their own political hides.

Speaker: NA
Text: The risks of the men who are fighting,

Speaker: NA
Text: the danger of the Japanese moving far-

Speaker: NA
Text: ther south, and all the implications

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Japanese menace did not matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: Visualize what might happen i f our

Speaker: NA
Text: own fighting men and those of our

Speaker: NA
Text: .allies adopted the standstill attitude.

Speaker: NA
Text: Would they have captured Gona, as we

Speaker: NA
Text: learn to-day they have done ? Subsequent

Speaker: NA
Text: to the interstate Labour 'Conference in

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne, the Prime Minister declared

Speaker: NA
Text: that one army under one command in the

Speaker: NA
Text: South-west Pacific had become a military

Speaker: NA
Text: necessity because of " the bitter handicap

Speaker: NA
Text: imposed in dealing with the enemy by

Speaker: NA
Text: factors hindering military mobility ". On

Speaker: NA
Text: the 24th November, it was reported in the

Speaker: NA
Text: press that the full Cabinet supported the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister's proposal. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: three members were not in agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: with the proposal. The Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: went .first to an outside junta, and,

Speaker: NA
Text: .secondly, to the Cabinet with his pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal, but the Cabinet was not unanimous

Speaker: NA
Text: and three members publicly declared their

Speaker: NA
Text: -disagreement. Cabinet government is in

Speaker: NA
Text: jeopardy as the result. The Prime Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister discussed this matter neither with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Advisory War Council nor, so far,

Speaker: NA
Text: with this Parliament, the only constitu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional body with which it should be dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussed. The Sydney Morning Herald of

Speaker: NA
Text: the 28th November, in its report of the

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting of the Cabinet, stated-

Speaker: NA
Text: He ( Mr Curtin) strongly combated tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: argument that his proposal amounted tp the

Speaker: NA
Text: general introduction of conscription. I t meant

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing of the sort, he said. There would

Speaker: NA
Text: be a Militia and an Australian Imperial Force

Speaker: NA
Text: as separate entities.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f the idea of the Prime Minister, as

Speaker: NA
Text: originally submitted to the interstate

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour Conference, does not mean that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Imperial Force and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Militia are to be welded into one army,

Speaker: NA
Text: with an equal liability to serve and enjoy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing similar conditions, the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people have been misled. I f there is to

Speaker: NA
Text: be a distinction between the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Imperial Force and the Militia in the

Speaker: NA
Text: South-west Pacific area, the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will only be aggravating the unsatis-

Speaker: NA
Text: factory state of affairs which has existed

Speaker: NA
Text: since the Opposition first raised the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter. The Prime Minister should tell

Speaker: NA
Text: this House and, through this House, the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Australia exactly what his pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal means.

Speaker: NA
Text: Only a little more than a week ago,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister of Great Britain, Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Churchill, in a world broadcast, made a

Speaker: NA
Text: telling point when referring to the fact,

Speaker: NA
Text: that the war in Europe might end before

Speaker: NA
Text: the war in Asia. Mr Churchill said-

Speaker: NA
Text: Should events take such a course, we should

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately bring all our forces to the other

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the world to the aid of America and

Speaker: NA
Text: China and, above all, to our own kith and kin

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia and New Zealand in their valiant

Speaker: NA
Text: struggle agajnst Japan's aggressions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Contrast the British Prime Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: pledge with the reluctance-th e enforced

Speaker: NA
Text: reluctance-o f the Prime Minister of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and his Ministers to merge

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Imperial Force and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Militia into one army for service

Speaker: NA
Text: wherever required. Though Britain is

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to come to our aid, we are not

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared tp send more than a section of

Speaker: NA
Text: our army to the aid of Britain. Such

Speaker: NA
Text: a state of affairs is cowardly, i t demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: strates the political cowardice of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministry,

Speaker: NA
Text: I now propose to state the conclusions

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Opposition has reached as the

Speaker: NA
Text: result of careful analysis of developments

Speaker: NA
Text: over the last thirteen months or so.

Speaker: NA
Text: First, the Government stands condemned

Speaker: NA
Text: for its attitude to this proposal since it

Speaker: NA
Text: was first raised by the Opposition twelve

Speaker: NA
Text: months ago next week. The Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: has consistently brought this matter for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward. We have been decidedly patient,

Speaker: NA
Text: but we recognize that the merging of the

Speaker: NA
Text: still two armies and the employment of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Militia wherever circumstances require

Speaker: NA
Text: are indispensable and are an inescapable

Speaker: NA
Text: necessity i f we are to wage total war in

Speaker: NA
Text: the defence of Australia. We have been

Speaker: NA
Text: motivated by no other -reason than our

Speaker: NA
Text: desire to ensure that we shall be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: do that. We could have made political

Speaker: NA
Text: capital out of this matter had we so

Speaker: NA
Text: desired; we desire with a full recognition

Speaker: NA
Text: of its position to assist and co-operate

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Government in obtaining ade-

Speaker: NA
Text: quate defence for Australia. That, we

Speaker: NA
Text: consider, can be got only along the lines

Speaker: NA
Text: of policy advocated in our letter to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister of the 17th September,

Speaker: NA
Text: 1942. [Extension of time granted.]

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has been guilty of pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: crastination, deliberate evasion, and a

Speaker: NA
Text: complete failure to measure up to the

Speaker: NA
Text: proper defence needs of a nation

Speaker: NA
Text: threatened by a powerful enemy and

Speaker: NA
Text: dependent on association with our allies.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government's attitude contrasts

Speaker: NA
Text: strikingly with the speed with which i t

Speaker: NA
Text: has acted in matters which it has con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered politically favorable.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, when the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: very belatedly did move in the matter, he

Speaker: NA
Text: did so in a way to which the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: takes the strongest possible exception.

Speaker: NA
Text: We submit that in Parliament the

Speaker: NA
Text: elected representatives of the people

Speaker: NA
Text: should have been first advised of this very

Speaker: NA
Text: important matter, particularly in view of

Speaker: NA
Text: the attitude of the Opposition, which bas

Speaker: NA
Text: been consistent since the 17th .September

Speaker: NA
Text: last. The urgent need to extend the use

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Militia must have been impressed

Speaker: NA
Text: upon the Prime Minister. He must have

Speaker: NA
Text: been advised and convinced by his

Speaker: NA
Text: advisers that the limitations on the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Militia were hampering the war effort.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why did he consider i t to be a matter

Speaker: NA
Text: requiring the consideration of an outside

Speaker: NA
Text: organization? Why did he not regard

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter as one calling for an urgent

Speaker: NA
Text: decision. Parliament could have been

Speaker: NA
Text: summoned immediately he was acquainted

Speaker: NA
Text: with the requirements of the High Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mand. Had the Prime Minister taken

Speaker: NA
Text: this course-th e right and proper one-

Speaker: NA
Text: the decision could have been taken by

Speaker: NA
Text: the elected representatives of the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian people. Parliament, and not

Speaker: NA
Text: the executive of the Labour party, has

Speaker: NA
Text: the responsibility to ensure that the war

Speaker: NA
Text: shall be prosecuted with the maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: degree of effectiveness. Likewise, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister has a responsibility to

Speaker: NA
Text: discharge to the people of this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: His actionwith the resultant indecision

Speaker: NA
Text: and delay by the Australian Labour party

Speaker: NA
Text: was an affront to Parliament and to the

Speaker: NA
Text: people which honorable members cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: condone.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thirdly, the reference of this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: to an outside organization obviously

Speaker: NA
Text: put Australia in a bad light in the eyes

Speaker: NA
Text: of our allies. Already we have had evition

Speaker: NA
Text: dence of a misunderstanding in the United parties and by most members.

Speaker: NA
Text: States of America because we are

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to allow the whole of our

Speaker: NA
Text: troops to fight wherever required. Those able member

Speaker: NA
Text: of us who are jealous of Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Fadden.

Speaker: NA
Text: reputation and integrity are anxious

Speaker: NA
Text: that anything likely to cause i l l feeling

Speaker: NA
Text: between ourselves and our allies should

Speaker: NA
Text: be speedily removed . 1

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition demands that Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament shall be called together as

Speaker: NA
Text: early as the circumstances will permit.

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament should provide the means

Speaker: NA
Text: to meet the requirements of an all-in

Speaker: NA
Text: war effort. We do not assure the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister that we shall accept

Speaker: NA
Text: whatever proposal be may put before

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament, but we shall give careful con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration to it. We shall be guided by

Speaker: NA
Text: the conditions which exist in the light

Speaker: NA
Text: of military advice and strategic informa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion placed before us by the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister as to what is needed for the

Speaker: NA
Text: adequate defence of Australia, and as to

Speaker: NA
Text: the best means of bringing i t into

Speaker: NA
Text: existence.

Speaker: Mr BLACKBURN
Text: Bourke) [4.25] -

Speaker: NA
Text: I move-

Speaker: NA
Text: That all words after "That" be left out

Speaker: NA
Text: with a view to insert in lieu thereof the words

Speaker: NA
Text: " this House, reaffirming the policy upon

Speaker: NA
Text: which the majority of its members were

Speaker: NA
Text: elected, opposes the imposition of any form

Speaker: NA
Text: of compulsory service outside Australia and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Territories of the Commonwealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendment is really the obverse

Speaker: NA
Text: of the amendment moved by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Eadden)

Speaker: NA
Text: on the 1st May, 1942. There

Speaker: NA
Text: are two things in this amendment.

Speaker: NA
Text: First, i t reminds the House that the

Speaker: NA
Text: majority of its members were elected on

Speaker: NA
Text: a policy of opposing the extension of

Speaker: NA
Text: compulsory military service. I thank

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition for

Speaker: NA
Text: his phrase, repeated several times, "We

Speaker: NA
Text: are the elected representatives and the

Speaker: NA
Text: trustees of the people ". We are not here

Speaker: NA
Text: to do what we think fit. We are elected

Speaker: NA
Text: on pledges which we gave to the people,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I submit that before any member

Speaker: NA
Text: is false to the pledge which he gave to

Speaker: NA
Text: the people, on which he was elected and

Speaker: NA
Text: without which he probably would not

Speaker: NA
Text: have been elected, he should cease to be

Speaker: NA
Text: has a member of the House and submit him-

Speaker: NA
Text: self again to the electors. The last elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: was fought on a pledge given by all

Speaker: NA
Text: I

Speaker: NA
Text: not except the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Deakin ( Mr Hutchinson), the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: for Boothby (Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Price), the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Barker ( Mr Archie Cameron), and the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Wakefield ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Duncan-Hughes)-ther e are, I suppose

Speaker: NA
Text: a round half-dozen whom one can except

Speaker: NA
Text: -bu t the other members agreed with

Speaker: NA
Text: their parties in saying that they would

Speaker: NA
Text: not support alteration of the Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Act to provide that men shall be sent

Speaker: NA
Text: to serve beyond Australia and its terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tories. The Leader of the Opposition has

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to the resolution carried in

Speaker: NA
Text: June, 1940, at the Australian Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: party conference, but the very words in

Speaker: NA
Text: that resolution made it perfectly clear

Speaker: NA
Text: tbat the service was to be within the

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of the Defence Act. That Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Act contains section 49 which provides

Speaker: NA
Text: against service outside Australia and

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian territories. Immediately after

Speaker: NA
Text: that conference had met, this House met,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the right honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Kooyong ( Mr Menzies), who was Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, submitted to this House an

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment of the National Security Act

Speaker: NA
Text: which was carried and which provided

Speaker: NA
Text: that nothing in that act should authorize

Speaker: NA
Text: the imposition of any form of compul-

Speaker: NA
Text: sory service beyond tbe limits of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. That was common ground. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: was common ground with every body that

Speaker: NA
Text: whatever else might be done, service out-

Speaker: NA
Text: side the limits of Australia should not

Speaker: NA
Text: be imposed. There were people who

Speaker: NA
Text: thought we should not go so far as

Speaker: NA
Text: that implied. This House is now

Speaker: NA
Text: asked by my amendment to reaffirm the

Speaker: NA
Text: policy on which the majority-th e great

Speaker: NA
Text: majority-o f its members were elected.

Speaker: NA
Text: That policy was opposition to any

Speaker: NA
Text: extension of compulsory service. Almost

Speaker: NA
Text: 40 years have elapsed since, after a

Speaker: NA
Text: conflict of opinion in this Parliament,

Speaker: NA
Text: there was put into the Defence Act a

Speaker: NA
Text: provision that voluntary forces ' should

Speaker: NA
Text: not be required to serve outside Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: That was inserted in 1903 as a result of

Speaker: NA
Text: a difference of opinion which arose i n the

Speaker: NA
Text: early days of federation. The then go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment introduced legislation to enable

Speaker: NA
Text: it to send citizen forces anywhere in the

Speaker: NA
Text: world. That was opposed by nearly all

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members. The government

Speaker: NA
Text: said that that was not really its intention,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the bill was abandoned. The bill as

Speaker: NA
Text: finally passed in 1903 contained section

Speaker: NA
Text: 49, which is the only guarantee that we

Speaker: NA
Text: shall have in Australia adequate forces

Speaker: NA
Text: for the defence of our hearths and

Speaker: NA
Text: homes. My objection and the objec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion held by a large number of people,

Speaker: NA
Text: which would decide me i f there

Speaker: NA
Text: were no other reasons for my

Speaker: NA
Text: attitude on this matter, is that

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that tbe community has

Speaker: NA
Text: not the -moral right to compel persons to

Speaker: NA
Text: go abroad from this land to fight.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f a man of his own free will volunteers

Speaker: NA
Text: for service overseas, it is no doubt because

Speaker: NA
Text: of his having arrived at a reasoned con-

Speaker: NA
Text: clusion that he should do so. But many

Speaker: NA
Text: persons in this community, of whom I am

Speaker: NA
Text: one, believe that it is entirely wrong to

Speaker: NA
Text: compel people to bear arms in a country

Speaker: NA
Text: other than their own.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Doe s the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber think that it is wrong to compel people

Speaker: NA
Text: to bear arms in defence of their own

Speaker: NA
Text: country ?

Speaker: Mr BLACKBURN
Text: Excep t in the

Speaker: NA
Text: case of conscientious objectors, I agree

Speaker: NA
Text: that people should be required to bear

Speaker: NA
Text: arms in defence of their own land. But

Speaker: NA
Text: a small minority of persons will not

Speaker: NA
Text: resist violence, and I believe that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: practicable to make special provisions to

Speaker: NA
Text: meet their case. There is a vast differ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence, however, between requiring persons

Speaker: NA
Text: to bear arms in their own country in order

Speaker: NA
Text: to resist other persons who are un-

Speaker: NA
Text: doubtedly aggressors, and requiring them

Speaker: NA
Text: to bear arms in a country other than

Speaker: NA
Text: their own. I f a person considers i t his

Speaker: NA
Text: duty to take up arms in a country

Speaker: NA
Text: other than his own that is his business;

Speaker: NA
Text: we should not compel him to do so. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: the one case it seems to me that the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pulsion is a form of organization. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is an instinct in a man which causes him

Speaker: NA
Text: to resist an aggressor. There is reason in

Speaker: NA
Text: requiring a person to bear arms in defence

Speaker: NA
Text: of his own country. There can be no

Speaker: NA
Text: instinct in a man which will compel him

Speaker: NA
Text: to bear arms in defence of another man's

Speaker: NA
Text: country. Although some persons may be

Speaker: NA
Text: forced by reasons which they regard as

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficient to take up arms in defence of

Speaker: NA
Text: a country other than their own, that is a

Speaker: NA
Text: very different thing from compelling them

Speaker: NA
Text: to do so. I f we compel a person to take up

Speaker: NA
Text: arms for the purpose of fighting overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: that person may be obliged to bear arms

Speaker: NA
Text: against subject populations which have

Speaker: NA
Text: no interest at all in the quarrel that has

Speaker: NA
Text: to be settled. I bave in mind, for ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ample, Malays, Burmese and tbe people

Speaker: NA
Text: of India, who bave no interest in the

Speaker: NA
Text: present quarrel except their desire to keep

Speaker: NA
Text: out of it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr RANKIN,-Th e honorable gentle-

Speaker: NA
Text: man is prepared to accept the help of

Speaker: NA
Text: conscripts from another country to defend

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: Mr BLACKBURN
Text: Th e honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Bendigo ( Mr Rankin), even

Speaker: NA
Text: so recently as last year, was opposed to

Speaker: NA
Text: conscription. I n support of that state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment I direct attention to the following

Speaker: NA
Text: remarks that he made in this House on

Speaker: NA
Text: the 2nd July, 1941, as reported in Han-

Speaker: NA
Text: sard, vol. 167, page 765:-

Speaker: NA
Text: Personally I do not believe in conscription.

Speaker: NA
Text: During the last war I did not vote for it, and

Speaker: NA
Text: specific reasons have prompted me to adopt

Speaker: NA
Text: this attitude. For example, a general in

Speaker: NA
Text: will take the best weapon that comes to his

Speaker: NA
Text: hand and will use i t again and again. It

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia had four divisions in the field with

Speaker: NA
Text: an unlimited supply of reinforcements they

Speaker: NA
Text: would be employed repeatedly, and this coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try would be bled white.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was in agreement with the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member at that time; but if he has

Speaker: NA
Text: changed his mind since then I regret

Speaker: NA
Text: that I cannot follow him.

Speaker: Mr RANKIN
Text: I was talking about a

Speaker: NA
Text: European war.

Speaker: Mr BLACKBURN
Text: I t is quite clear

Speaker: NA
Text: that i f we sent our men abroad Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: might easily exhaust its man-power.

Speaker: NA
Text: I take a definite position on this

Speaker: NA
Text: subject. Certain members of the House,

Speaker: NA
Text: like the honorable member for Deakin

Speaker: NA
Text: and the honorable member for Barker

Speaker: NA
Text: have advocated consistently, at all times

Speaker: NA
Text: since the commencement of the war, that

Speaker: NA
Text: our men should be compelled to serve

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas. I have no quarrel with them

Speaker: NA
Text: on that account. They have fought elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions upon the issue. The great majority

Speaker: NA
Text: of honorable members, however, includ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the right honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Kooyong ( Mr Menzies) and the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Darling Downs

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Fadden) and many of their fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowers have not only refused to consent

Speaker: NA
Text: to the introduction of conscription in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, but have also repudiated any

Speaker: NA
Text: such idea. The right honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Kooyong was responsible for the

Speaker: NA
Text: insertion of a provision in the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Security Act that conscription could not

Speaker: NA
Text: be introduced by regulation. I n other

Speaker: NA
Text: words, section 49 of the Defence Act

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot be overridden by regulations.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: -An d tbe Government

Speaker: NA
Text: and party of which he was the leader

Speaker: NA
Text: supported him on that issue.

Speaker: Mr BLACKBURN
Text: Tha t is so. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: those honorable gentlemen now desire

Speaker: NA
Text: release from undertakings that they have

Speaker: NA
Text: given in that regard they should seek

Speaker: NA
Text: them in the democratic way by approach-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the electors on the subject. Other

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members of the House also

Speaker: NA
Text: have opposed conscription consistently. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am one of them. I do not desire to

Speaker: NA
Text: traverse the reasons which I have pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: viously given for my attitude. I consider

Speaker: NA
Text: it sufficient for me to say at this stage

Speaker: NA
Text: that I am opposed to conscription on

Speaker: NA
Text: ethical grounds. The evils of industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: battle conscription which have been forced on

Speaker: NA
Text: this country will be aggravated one

Speaker: NA
Text: hundred-fold in the minds of militant

Speaker: NA
Text: unionists and other supporters of tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour party i f the Government's present

Speaker: NA
Text: policy be applied. Other evils also may

Speaker: NA
Text: fall upon the country i f more of our men

Speaker: NA
Text: are sent far afield. We know very well

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Prime Minister not long ago

Speaker: NA
Text: threatened the coal-miners of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: that i f ' they continued to strike they

Speaker: NA
Text: would be put in uniform, which would

Speaker: NA
Text: mean that they would have to bear arms

Speaker: NA
Text: in defence of Australia.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Woul d there be any-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing wrong with that?

Speaker: Mr BLACKBURN
Text: I call it an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: sult to the coal-miners of Australia to

Speaker: NA
Text: tell them that they would be compelled,

Speaker: NA
Text: as a punishment, to bear arms in defence

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia and Australian territories.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Th e honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: should not cry about it.

Speaker: Mr BLACKBURN
Text: I am not crying

Speaker: NA
Text: about i t ; but I object to tbe coal-miners

Speaker: NA
Text: being insulted in such a way. They would

Speaker: NA
Text: not regard i t as a punishment to have to

Speaker: NA
Text: defend their country. I n any case, tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for New England

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Abbott) need not work himself into

Speaker: NA
Text: a passion. Section 49 of the Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Act guarantees, for this country, a force

Speaker: NA
Text: adequate for its defence. I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: had i t not been for tbat section of tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: act this country would bave been denuded

Speaker: NA
Text: of its natural defenders, just as I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that New Zealand has been denuded of its

Speaker: NA
Text: defenders. I believe tbat we should

Speaker: NA
Text: retain in this country a force adequate

Speaker: NA
Text: for its defence; and therefore I am

Speaker: NA
Text: opposed to tbe compulsory sending of

Speaker: NA
Text: more of our men abroad. I hope tbat

Speaker: NA
Text: my amendment will be agreed to.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: I second the amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and reserve my right to speak.

Speaker: Sir CHARLES MARR
Text: Parkes)

Speaker: NA
Text: [4.45] -The House has been called to-

Speaker: NA
Text: gether for the specific purpose of hearing

Speaker: NA
Text: a statement by the Prime Minister ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Curtin) on the war position. We are glad

Speaker: NA
Text: to have had the report that the right hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: orable gentleman has placed before us to-

Speaker: NA
Text: day. The speech that he made shows the

Speaker: NA
Text: seriousness of the position that obtains

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout the world. Honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers, however, expected to hear something

Speaker: NA
Text: in regard to the way in which Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: was to play its part in conjunction with

Speaker: NA
Text: its allies in driving the enemy from

Speaker: NA
Text: occupied territories and in preventing it

Speaker: NA
Text: from attacking our own. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: listened to the remarks of the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Bourke ( Mr Blackburn).

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Ver y wise ones, too.

Speaker: Sir CHARLES MARR
Text: H e prefaced

Speaker: NA
Text: them by giving notice of an amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: that he proposed to move for the addi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to the motion of words that would

Speaker: NA
Text: prevent the introduction of conscription

Speaker: NA
Text: for military service abroad. Many of us,

Speaker: NA
Text: in our hearts, are opposed to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: scription as such. But I have, in this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament during this war, consis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tently supported it. The workers, above

Speaker: NA
Text: all others, should be prepared to fight

Speaker: NA
Text: in defence of privileges and rights which

Speaker: NA
Text: have been handed down to them

Speaker: NA
Text: by their forbears. The speech of the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Bourke would

Speaker: NA
Text: lead one to believe that we can cringe to

Speaker: NA
Text: our allies; that we can say to the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States of America, New Zealand, Canada,

Speaker: NA
Text: the British Isles, China, and all others

Speaker: NA
Text: who are allied with us, "For the Lord's

Speaker: NA
Text: sake, come and help us; but, unfortu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nately, we cannot go to your help ".

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Whe n did the 'honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member change his mind ?

Speaker: Sir CHARLES MARR
Text: I bave never

Speaker: NA
Text: changed my mind on this matter.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Th e honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: was an anti-conscriptionist six months

Speaker: NA
Text: ago.

Speaker: Sir CHARLES MARR
Text: Never ! The

Speaker: NA
Text: people whom the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bourke represents in this House-th e

Speaker: NA
Text: Communists-ar e to-day the most out-

Speaker: NA
Text: spoken in favour of conscription.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: I rise to a point of

Speaker: NA
Text: order. Is the honorable member i n order

Speaker: NA
Text: in accusing the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bourke of being the representative of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Communists in this Parliament? Is it

Speaker: NA
Text: not a fact that the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bourke represents the electors of Bourke,

Speaker: NA
Text: and no one else?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Objectio n to any

Speaker: NA
Text: remark must be made by the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member concerned.

Speaker: Mr BLACKBURN
Text: Wha t the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member has said will not do me any

Speaker: NA
Text: harm. '

Speaker: - Sir CHARLES MARR
Text: I f the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Bourke is hurt by what

Speaker: NA
Text: I bave said, I withdraw it. I have too

Speaker: NA
Text: much respect for his convictions, and

Speaker: NA
Text: his attitude i n this House, to "throw

Speaker: NA
Text: stones " at him. He has a right to his

Speaker: NA
Text: opinions, and be has been courageous

Speaker: NA
Text: enough to voice them. I t appears to me

Speaker: NA
Text: that responsibility for the present lack of

Speaker: NA
Text: man-power, which is so much deplored,

Speaker: NA
Text: must be laid at tbe door of Ministers.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t has been considered necessary to issue

Speaker: NA
Text: regulations in respect of tbe employment

Speaker: NA
Text: of domestic help, in order to obtain more

Speaker: NA
Text: women for engagement in war activities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Surely, i f Ministers were to abolish the

Speaker: NA
Text: loading that is evident in some of our

Speaker: NA
Text: munitions establishments and other

Speaker: NA
Text: activities, i f the employees could be en-

Speaker: NA
Text: couraged to devote their full energies to

Speaker: NA
Text: the war effort instead of slacking and

Speaker: NA
Text: making overtime necessary, much better

Speaker: NA
Text: results would accrue. Our sister dominion

Speaker: NA
Text: of New Zealand has always had compul-

Speaker: NA
Text: sory service. New Zealanders served

Speaker: NA
Text: during the last war, and have again on

Speaker: NA
Text: this occasion, not where they desired, but

Speaker: NA
Text: where the advisers of the Government of

Speaker: NA
Text: that dominion considered that they could

Speaker: NA
Text: best be engaged. Has the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Bourke, the honorable memiber for

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne ( Mr Calwell), or any other

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member, with the possible ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ception of the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Batman ( Mr Brennan)-wh o bas de-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced the British Navy-eve r de-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced' the provision that requires any

Speaker: NA
Text: member of tbe Royal Australian. Navy

Speaker: NA
Text: to serve wherever required? Those men

Speaker: NA
Text: are not invited to enlist to serve only in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian waters. On one occasion, I

Speaker: NA
Text: heard the honorable member for Batman

Speaker: NA
Text: say that they were a menace to mankind.

Speaker: Mr BRENNAN
Text: Neve r in my life.

Speaker: Sir CHARLES MARR
Text: That

Speaker: NA
Text: ment appears in Hansard.

Speaker: Mr BRENNAN
Text: I t does not.

Speaker: Sir CHARLES MARR
Text: -I s the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: orable member now in favour of the

Speaker: NA
Text: regulations relating to tbe enlistment of

Speaker: NA
Text: men in the Royal Australian Navy?

Speaker: Mr BRENNAN
Text: Tha t is a vastly dif-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferent proposition.

Speaker: Sir CHARLES MARR
Text: I s the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member in favour of the regulations

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to the enlistment of members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Royal Australian Air Force?

Speaker: Mr BRENNAN
Text: I do not think so; but

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not know what they are.

Speaker: Sir CHARLES MARR
Text: Member s of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Royal Australian A i r Force, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Royal Australian Navy, and the Mer-

Speaker: NA
Text: cantile Marine, can be sent to serve any-

Speaker: NA
Text: where. One cannot enlist in the A i r

Speaker: NA
Text: Force to serve only in Australia, but must

Speaker: NA
Text: be prepared to go wherever one's services

Speaker: NA
Text: can best be used.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Bu t one enlists

Speaker: NA
Text: voluntarily.

Speaker: Sir CHARLES MARR
Text: On enlists

Speaker: NA
Text: voluntarily in other organizations. My

Speaker: NA
Text: quarrel with the Government is, that i t

Speaker: NA
Text: does not go far enough in the application

Speaker: NA
Text: of compulsion. I t ought not to make

Speaker: NA
Text: the Parliament an exempt establishment.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: I s the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member in favour of compulsory

Speaker: NA
Text: unionism ?

Speaker: Sir CHARLES MARR
Text: I f the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: orable member is in favour of compulsory

Speaker: NA
Text: unionism, he ought to be in favour o'f

Speaker: NA
Text: -compulsory service for the defence of

Speaker: NA
Text: those things for which unionism has

Speaker: NA
Text: fought and won battles. Honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members who sit on the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: benches never raise their voices against

Speaker: NA
Text: enlistment in the Navy or the Air Force;

Speaker: NA
Text: yet they contend that members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Citizen Military Forces must serve only

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australian territory! I t appears to

Speaker: NA
Text: me that some Ministers give indirect en-

Speaker: NA
Text: couragement to those who desire to avoid

Speaker: NA
Text: service, by finding positions for them in

Speaker: NA
Text: Government departments. One depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in Sydney contains a large number

Speaker: NA
Text: of eligible men. Yet men of 59 years of

Speaker: NA
Text: age bave been industrially conscripted I

Speaker: NA
Text: The men in that category are not invited

Speaker: NA
Text: to say whether they will serve near their

Speaker: NA
Text: homes in Melbourne or Sydney, but may

Speaker: NA
Text: be sent to the farthest parts of Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: state- land, or elsewhere. Was the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Melbourne in favour of that

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial conscription ?

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Th e honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber was.

Speaker: Sir CHARLES MARR
Text: I did not

Speaker: NA
Text: vote for it. But I am in favour of con-

Speaker: NA
Text: scription for every war activity, and

Speaker: NA
Text: would put a man to work in a munitions

Speaker: NA
Text: factory or any other undertaking in

Speaker: NA
Text: which he was best fitted to serve. I n a

Speaker: NA
Text: factory that I visited, a foreman told me

Speaker: NA
Text: that women who were engaged on the

Speaker: NA
Text: production of shells, were, after three

Speaker: NA
Text: months' experience, making twenty shells

Speaker: NA
Text: a unit a shift more than trained men. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have informed the Minister for the Army

Speaker: NA
Text: that thousands of Australians who volun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tarily went overseas in order to prevent

Speaker: NA
Text: the enemy from approaching our shores,

Speaker: NA
Text: and escaped from countries to which their

Speaker: NA
Text: activities had taken them, are now en-

Speaker: NA
Text: gaged in guerrilla warfare in the hills of

Speaker: NA
Text: Java, in Timor, and i n other islands of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Pacific. The Government says:

Speaker: NA
Text: " They are outside Australian territory.

Speaker: NA
Text: They were fools enough to enlist; let

Speaker: NA
Text: e

Speaker: NA
Text: them stew in their own juice. We shall

Speaker: NA
Text: not compel any Australian to rescue them

Speaker: NA
Text: and bring them back ". That is the view

Speaker: NA
Text: that honorable members opposite held in

Speaker: NA
Text: the last war, and one cannot expect them

Speaker: NA
Text: to change it. They will not oblige their

Speaker: NA
Text: good trade unionists friends to serve i f it

Speaker: NA
Text: be possible for them to avoid service. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister's eloquence and ability

Speaker: NA
Text: are of no avail. I t is shameful tbat tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: leader of the country, the first man in

Speaker: NA
Text: the nation, should have to seek the direc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of an outside junta as to the way in

Speaker: NA
Text: which he should lead this country.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Doe s not the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member go to an outside junta?

Speaker: Sir CHARLES MARR
Text: I have never

Speaker: NA
Text: been to one in my life.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Di d not Mr Bruce go

Speaker: NA
Text: to Collins House ?

Speaker: Sir CHARLES MARR
Text: No . Neither

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Bruce nor the right honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for North Sydney ( Mr Hughes)

Speaker: NA
Text: went to any outside junta. I n the last

Speaker: NA
Text: war, the right honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: North Sydney led this country as a leader

Speaker: NA
Text: should. What did the Labour party do?

Speaker: NA
Text: I t did to him what it would do to John

Speaker: NA
Text: Curtin, i f that right honorable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: were to do the right and noble thing

Speaker: NA
Text: without fear of consequences; but be

Speaker: NA
Text: would find that the country was solidly

Speaker: NA
Text: behind him. I t would be a waste of time

Speaker: NA
Text: to try to convince my friends opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: that their colleagues in the unions are

Speaker: NA
Text: opposed to their attitude.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: 'Ho w does the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member like the idea of the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munists supporting him?

Speaker: Sir CHARLES MARR
Text: I welcome

Speaker: NA
Text: the co-operation of anybody who can assist

Speaker: NA
Text: to win the war. I have listened with great

Speaker: NA
Text: pleasure to the representative of the

Speaker: NA
Text: munists in the Sydney Domain. I f he

Speaker: NA
Text: could make a speech in this House to my

Speaker: NA
Text: friends opposite, he would open their

Speaker: NA
Text: eyes and show them how they should act.

Speaker: Mr ARCHIE CAMERON
Text: O n a point of

Speaker: NA
Text: order, I should like to know whether the

Speaker: NA
Text: motion should be discussed in tbe absence

Speaker: NA
Text: of every member of the Ministry. Not

Speaker: NA
Text: one of His Majesty's Ministers is on the

Speaker: NA
Text: treasury bench, and the proceedings are

Speaker: NA
Text: entirely out of order.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Scully having entered the chamber,

Speaker: Sir CHARLES MARR
Text: Th e amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has placed the Cabinet in a

Speaker: NA
Text: dilemma.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: I t will place the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: orable member in a dilemma later.

Speaker: Sir CHARLES MARR
Text: I t will never

Speaker: NA
Text: place me in a dilemma. Because it pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: poses to add to the motion a declaration

Speaker: NA
Text: that in no circumstances shall conscrip-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion be introduced, I cannot support i t ;

Speaker: NA
Text: nor, in my opinion, can tbe Ministry or

Speaker: NA
Text: the members of the Labour party.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Tha t is our policy.

Speaker: Sir CHARLES MARR
Text: I s it? Then

Speaker: NA
Text: why were workers conscripted indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trially? Honorable members opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: say that they represent the workers

Speaker: NA
Text: in this Parliament. A l l that I can

Speaker: NA
Text: say is, " God help the workers who

Speaker: NA
Text: have that sort of representation".

Speaker: NA
Text: I f the honorable member for Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne bad blood relations serving over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas, he might take a different view.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since the 11th July last, I have been

Speaker: NA
Text: fighting the Minister for the Army on

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of men who, having fought vali-

Speaker: NA
Text: antly for the defence of this country

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout the campaigns in Greece, Crete

Speaker: NA
Text: and Syria, were tried by court martial in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Middle East because of what they had

Speaker: NA
Text: done when an officer who had never been

Speaker: NA
Text: in action marched them over the desert

Speaker: NA
Text: in order to give them further training.

Speaker: NA
Text: These men were tried for mutiny and

Speaker: NA
Text: sentenced to 26 months' imprisonment,

Speaker: NA
Text: some being imprisoned in Pentridge and

Speaker: NA
Text: others at Long Bay. I shall never cease

Speaker: NA
Text: to oppose such treatment. I t is monstrous

Speaker: NA
Text: that a Labour government should put

Speaker: NA
Text: soldiers who volunteered to fight for their

Speaker: NA
Text: country in gaol with common criminals.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the first time that it has

Speaker: NA
Text: ever been done by any Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: government. No civilian can be placed

Speaker: NA
Text: Com- in a gaol with criminals until he has

Speaker: NA
Text: been tried by a jury and found guilty

Speaker: NA
Text: of the offence of which he was charged.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f these soldiers were guilty, they

Speaker: NA
Text: could have served their sentences in

Speaker: NA
Text: concentration camps, but they should not

Speaker: NA
Text: have been put into gaols with criminals.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have been fighting this case ever since

Speaker: NA
Text: the 11th July last. Only to-day I received

Speaker: NA
Text: a letter from the Prime Minister to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that he understood that the matter which

Speaker: NA
Text: I had brought under his notice had been

Speaker: NA
Text: dealt with by the Minister for the Army.

Speaker: NA
Text: I may say that I have never once received

Speaker: NA
Text: an affirmative reply from the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Army on any subject.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Tbe honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member must confine himself more closely

Speaker: NA
Text: to the subject-matter of the amendment.

Speaker: Sir CHARLES MARR
Text: Th e Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister made a very comprehensive

Speaker: NA
Text: statement which took us into many fields.

Speaker: NA
Text: He travelled from the Philippines to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Middle East. I have not yet gone so far;

Speaker: NA
Text: I have not even got to Europe yet. Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Miles, the Communist, said in the Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: Domain recently that he did not

Speaker: NA
Text: care whether we had one army or ten so

Speaker: NA
Text: long as we all combined to chase those

Speaker: NA
Text: little yellow swine back to their holes in

Speaker: NA
Text: Japan. Do honorable members think

Speaker: NA
Text: that we can defeat Japan by passing

Speaker: NA
Text: resolutions in this House? I was dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed that the Prime Minister did

Speaker: NA
Text: not finish his statement by making a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: port upon his attendance at the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour party conference in Melbourne.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n my opinion, he had no right to go to

Speaker: NA
Text: the conference at all. I take it that he

Speaker: NA
Text: attended as Prime Minister and, i f he

Speaker: NA
Text: visited one outside organization in that

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity he should visit all. Seeing

Speaker: NA
Text: that he did go, he should have made a

Speaker: NA
Text: report to Parliament on his visit. He

Speaker: NA
Text: should have said that, while Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: was in recess, he went to the Trades Hall

Speaker: NA
Text: and outlined the Government's proposals

Speaker: NA
Text: to the delegates there. He might have

Speaker: NA
Text: added that he was not quite sure whether

Speaker: NA
Text: those proposals would be turned down or

Speaker: NA
Text: accepted. I am curious to know what he

Speaker: NA
Text: proposes to do if the trade unions decide

Speaker: NA
Text: against him. However, i t is not for us at

Speaker: NA
Text: this stage to make the way too hard for

Speaker: NA
Text: him. We must give him a chance to get

Speaker: NA
Text: away with it i f he can, but I should like

Speaker: NA
Text: to know what he proposes to do i f he

Speaker: NA
Text: not get away with it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr OAIAVTSLT, -H e will not join the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Australia party, anyway.

Speaker: Sir CHARLES MARR
Text: I should like

Speaker: NA
Text: the leader of the Parliament to be

Speaker: NA
Text: the leader of the people. There should

Speaker: NA
Text: be complete unity at this time. We

Speaker: NA
Text: do not want political party divisions

Speaker: NA
Text: now. We should have a national govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, which would be representative of

Speaker: NA
Text: all the people. The Minister for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Army ( Mr Eorde) and the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Air ( Mr Drakeford) flew to New

Speaker: NA
Text: Guinea, and came back with harrowing

Speaker: NA
Text: tales, but what could they have seen

Speaker: NA
Text: in a few days ? I happen to be one who

Speaker: NA
Text: went over the Owen Stanley Range, and

Speaker: NA
Text: at one stage i t took more than 30 natives

Speaker: NA
Text: over four days to cut a track a mile long.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our men have played a noble paTt in

Speaker: NA
Text: New Guinea, whether they be members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian Imperial Force or the

Speaker: NA
Text: Citizen Military Forces. We should

Speaker: NA
Text: give to our military advisers the support

Speaker: NA
Text: which they bave a right to expect. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: they are worth having as advisers it is

Speaker: NA
Text: worth our while to accept their advice.

Speaker: NA
Text: The trouble is tbat we have too many

Speaker: NA
Text: pettifogging critics in this country who

Speaker: NA
Text: can all tell the Army, the Navy and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Air Force how they are doing things

Speaker: NA
Text: wrongly. The Australian Imperial Force

Speaker: NA
Text: was brought back from overseas and

Speaker: NA
Text: .split up among Militia units. What is

Speaker: NA
Text: to happen i f the Government's pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal for merging the two forces be not

Speaker: NA
Text: eiven effect? I suppose tbe men will be

Speaker: NA
Text: lined up and an officer will say, "Hands

Speaker: NA
Text: up all those who are members of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Imperial Force. Take two paces

Speaker: NA
Text: to the front. Those who are not of. the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Imperial Force will stay at

Speaker: NA
Text: home and look after the women." Armies

Speaker: NA
Text: do not fight as individuals; they are

Speaker: NA
Text: trained and fight as organizations, and

Speaker: NA
Text: that applies with greater force than ever

Speaker: NA
Text: in these days of mechanization. Much

Speaker: NA
Text: as I admire the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bourke ( Mr Blackburn) and much as I

Speaker: NA
Text: like to listen to his speeches, I cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: support his amendment.

Speaker: Mr BRENNAN
Text: Batman) [5.9] - I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that it may be candidly admitted-

Speaker: NA
Text: because I feel that I cannot honestly

Speaker: NA
Text: deny it-tha t Government supporters

Speaker: NA
Text: does find themselves in the present circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances in a very embarrassing position

Speaker: NA
Text: in regard to discussions upon defence

Speaker: NA
Text: measures. The Prime Minister ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Curtin) has made a statement, and moved

Speaker: NA
Text: that the paper be printed. Tbe honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Bourke ( Mr Blackburn)

Speaker: NA
Text: has moved an amendment affirming the

Speaker: NA
Text: desirability of maintaining the historic

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour policy regarding conscription for

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas military service. To this policy,

Speaker: NA
Text: not one word of reference was made

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Prime Minister. Nevertheless,

Speaker: NA
Text: as is well known, he had publicly made

Speaker: NA
Text: a declaration of an intention on bis part

Speaker: NA
Text: to depart from Labour's historic policy

Speaker: NA
Text: and to substitute a new one.

Speaker: NA
Text: The attitude of Labour has always been

Speaker: NA
Text: one of implacable opposition to overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: conscription. Tbat faith was so firmly

Speaker: NA
Text: held that many good Labourites and true

Speaker: NA
Text: thought that the principle should be em-

Speaker: NA
Text: bedded in the Australian Constitution so

Speaker: NA
Text: as to ensure its permanence. Most

Speaker: NA
Text: people who are interested in the Lab-

Speaker: NA
Text: our movement believe that its greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: achievement, next to the famous attack

Speaker: NA
Text: made upon vested interests in the early

Speaker: NA
Text: 'nineties during the period of the founda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the Labour party, was its repeated

Speaker: NA
Text: and continued resistance to the policy of

Speaker: NA
Text: compulsory military service in a foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: country. To-day, our policv is still anti-

Speaker: NA
Text: con scriptionist, but we meet this Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in the extraordinary position that

Speaker: NA
Text: the leader of the party and the head of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has publicly declared his

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition to what many of us regard as

Speaker: NA
Text: not merely a plank, but a cardinal prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciple of Labour policv. This new policy

Speaker: NA
Text: advocated by tbe Prime Minister bas not

Speaker: NA
Text: yet been adopted. Indeed, i n my opinion,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is not likely to be adopted by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour movement. I f it 'had pleased the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Fadden)

Speaker: NA
Text: to-day to move an amendment affirming

Speaker: NA
Text: allegiance to the principle of conscription

Speaker: NA
Text: as laid down by the Prime Minister, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister himself and every mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of bis party would have been bound

Speaker: NA
Text: to oppose the motion- a most extra-

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinary position-jus t as they will be

Speaker: NA
Text: bound to support the spirit of the motion

Speaker: NA
Text: of the honorable member for Bourke, as

Speaker: NA
Text: I most cordially do.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t may as well, I think, be frankly

Speaker: NA
Text: admitted that we have been led into a

Speaker: NA
Text: position in which we are exposed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: ridicule and contempt not only of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition and our own supporters, but

Speaker: NA
Text: also of the electorate as a whole. Almost

Speaker: NA
Text: every honorable member of this House,

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly every party, has come from the

Speaker: NA
Text: electors pledged and, so far as I know,

Speaker: NA
Text: continues to be pledged against the policy

Speaker: NA
Text: of conscription for service i n foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: countries. There were, of course, some

Speaker: NA
Text: die-hards. Tbe honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bourke ( Mr Blackburn) excepts them

Speaker: NA
Text: in more pleasant words than I feel dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed to apply to them. There were

Speaker: NA
Text: those of the Opposition, who piping very

Speaker: NA
Text: loudly in this House, piped not so

Speaker: NA
Text: loudly in the electorate at the time that

Speaker: NA
Text: military service in foreign countries was

Speaker: NA
Text: regarded as very unpopular.

Speaker: Mr ARCHIE CAMERON
Text: I f the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member had accompanied me on the

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign he would have formed a dif-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferent opinion.

Speaker: Mr BRENNAN
Text: Th e truth is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the great majority of the members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition exhibited extraordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: sensitiveness about any suggestion that

Speaker: NA
Text: they were favorable to conscription. I

Speaker: NA
Text: remember gravely offending a former

Speaker: NA
Text: member of this Parliament, who was an

Speaker: NA
Text: anti-conscriptionist of an earlier war, by

Speaker: NA
Text: suggesting that his protests of recent date

Speaker: NA
Text: against conscription for foreign service

Speaker: NA
Text: were not entirely genuine or sincere. I

Speaker: NA
Text: took that occasion to point out that it

Speaker: NA
Text: was doubtful, i f they were submitted to

Speaker: NA
Text: the test, whether Opposition members

Speaker: NA
Text: would not be shown to run true to form

Speaker: NA
Text: and prove themselves, i n reality, con-

Speaker: NA
Text: scriptionists.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t must be admitted that there is little

Speaker: NA
Text: difference between the policy of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour party acting by its majority and

Speaker: NA
Text: that of the United Australia party and its

Speaker: NA
Text: somewhat uncertain satellite, the Country

Speaker: NA
Text: party. I t must be granted that the

Speaker: NA
Text: sometimes doubt whether it should be

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition is a kid-glove opposition. I

Speaker: NA
Text: described in its relationship with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government as a Siamese twin, or whe-

Speaker: NA
Text: ther the Country party and the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment are merely a married couple. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: know, however, that the United Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia party's opposition to the Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, as at present constituted, is

Speaker: NA
Text: much more apparent than real. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: know that the Leader of the Opposition,

Speaker: NA
Text: so far as he is the leader, and not merely

Speaker: NA
Text: a political accident, speaks much more

Speaker: NA
Text: valiantly than he acts. I do know that

Speaker: NA
Text: he makes statements of tremendous

Speaker: NA
Text: ferocity in tbe press and that he soft

Speaker: NA
Text: pedals them remarkably in Parliament,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that finally he is wont to express his

Speaker: NA
Text: complete satisfaction with the explana-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion tendered by the Prime Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: All differences 'between them end in

Speaker: NA
Text: pleasant felicitations exchanged between

Speaker: NA
Text: "Jack " and " A r t i e " , and there the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter ends. The Advisory "War Council

Speaker: NA
Text: is usually the incubator of these downy

Speaker: NA
Text: chickens of complete harmony. Nobody

Speaker: NA
Text: wa3 surprised, therefore, to learn that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition would spare us in the

Speaker: NA
Text: moment of our humiliation. Nobody

Speaker: NA
Text: was surprised to find that the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, finding the Government through

Speaker: NA
Text: its head, promising to "go quiet", de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cided that it should be encouraged

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than that it should suffer tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: indignity of forcible arrest. I f one had

Speaker: NA
Text: had an ear to the keyhole when the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition party meeting was being held

Speaker: NA
Text: on this matter of defence no doubt one

Speaker: NA
Text: would have heard that genial phrase-

Speaker: NA
Text: maker, the right honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: .Kooyong ( Mr Menzies) suggesting that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government should ibe allowed to

Speaker: NA
Text: stew in its own juice. I can quite

Speaker: NA
Text: imagine the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Barker ( Mr Archie Cameron) saying

Speaker: NA
Text: that they should not throw a stone at

Speaker: NA
Text: a stewpot of disruption which was

Speaker: NA
Text: already simmering nicely on the Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: hearth. I have said that there is little

Speaker: NA
Text: difference between parties, and there is;

Speaker: NA
Text: but I always thought that anti-conscrip-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion was safer in the hands of the Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: party and a Labour Government than

Speaker: NA
Text: any other party in this House, for

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons which I have already given.

Speaker: Mr ARCHIE CAMERON
Text: I think I told

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member at the 1939 elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion that it was not.

Speaker: Mr BRENNAN
Text: Yes , I believe so,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I myself said something in support

Speaker: NA
Text: of the honorable member's logic. I said

Speaker: NA
Text: that the honorable member might be

Speaker: NA
Text: right. But there is an old saying, " Once

Speaker: NA
Text: a policeman always a policeman". I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not agree with that, because I know many

Speaker: NA
Text: gentlemen who, having been very good

Speaker: NA
Text: officers of police, have for many years

Speaker: NA
Text: since retirement proved themselves very

Speaker: NA
Text: goodi citizens. But I do say, "Once a

Speaker: NA
Text: conscriptionist always a conscriptionist".

Speaker: NA
Text: You can trace the continued presence of

Speaker: NA
Text: the virus. You know him as a conscrip-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionist even when he is most loudly pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: claiming himself an anti-conscriptionist.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f conscription for overseas service is

Speaker: NA
Text: such a good thing, why bastardize it?

Speaker: NA
Text: Why call i t out of its name? Why

Speaker: NA
Text: apologize for it? Why explain, "We

Speaker: NA
Text: do not mean conscription, we merely

Speaker: NA
Text: mean merge-on e army. We do not

Speaker: NA
Text: mean territories far away in Europe,

Speaker: NA
Text: we merely mean lands-th e terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tories of foreign powers, certainly-

Speaker: NA
Text: relatively near to Australia" ? When

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Bourke

Speaker: NA
Text: was speaking on that subject he en-

Speaker: NA
Text: deavoured to define the indefinite and

Speaker: NA
Text: to tell us what was meant by the South-

Speaker: NA
Text: west Pacific. We might have hoped that

Speaker: NA
Text: he would tell us also what was meant by

Speaker: NA
Text: the phrase " associated with the defence

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia " ; but the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: waxed a little indignant and said that

Speaker: NA
Text: these were secret matters which could not

Speaker: NA
Text: be disclosed. I hardly understand how

Speaker: NA
Text: we are to determine what we mean by

Speaker: NA
Text: conscription in tlie South-west Pacific,

Speaker: NA
Text: unless the geographical area referred to

Speaker: NA
Text: is disclosed, in the discussion on the

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment of the Defence Act. I make

Speaker: NA
Text: this further observation that the anxiety

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Prime Minister was a little belated

Speaker: NA
Text: because it appears that the definition bas

Speaker: NA
Text: already been published in a Sydney news-

Speaker: NA
Text: paper only this morning. I n the good

Speaker: NA
Text: old days when we were fighting con-

Speaker: NA
Text: scription before, the Prime Minister did

Speaker: NA
Text: me the honour of presiding at a fateful

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting which I addressed, at the Bijou

Speaker: NA
Text: Theatre on the 4th July, 1915. He was

Speaker: NA
Text: then a militant opponent of conscription

Speaker: NA
Text: for overseas service. I n those days the

Speaker: NA
Text: men who stood for conscription were not

Speaker: NA
Text: ashamed of the name. They called i t for

Speaker: NA
Text: what it was. The immortal " B i l l y " ,

Speaker: NA
Text: and men like Paddy Lynch and George

Speaker: NA
Text: Pearce, all arch conscriptionists, advo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cated conscription without using euphem-

Speaker: NA
Text: isms. They said what they meant. They

Speaker: NA
Text: called a spade a spade. The reference

Speaker: NA
Text: to the two last gentlemen I have men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioned-wh o came from your own State,

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: suggest s that the blossom

Speaker: NA
Text: of conscriptionflourishesremarkably well

Speaker: NA
Text: in the congenial atmosphere of Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. The words used by the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister in setting out his proposal were,

Speaker: NA
Text: I think, sufiiciently clear to be under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stood. They were-

Speaker: NA
Text: That, having regard to the paramount neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sity of Australia's defence, as expressed at the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal conference of the Australian Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: party in June, 1940, the Government should be

Speaker: NA
Text: authorized to add to the Defence Act, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: definition of " Commonwealth", which at

Speaker: NA
Text: present defined the territory to which the act

Speaker: NA
Text: extended, the following words:-''an d such

Speaker: NA
Text: other territories in the South-west Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: area as the Governor-General proclaims as

Speaker: NA
Text: being territories associated with the defence of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia ".

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: I s that official?

Speaker: Mr BRENNAN
Text: I am quoting from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Tabor Call. I hope that even

Speaker: NA
Text: though Labour policy may be some-

Speaker: NA
Text: what in the balance at the moment the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for New England

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Abbott) will not regard i t as an

Speaker: NA
Text: offence for me to quote from a Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: newspaper. The words that I have

Speaker: NA
Text: quoted have been stated in many places.

Speaker: NA
Text: The words are sufficiently clear to remove

Speaker: NA
Text: all doubt that the Government desires

Speaker: NA
Text: power to compel the youth of Australia to

Speaker: NA
Text: serve in foreign countries. The general

Speaker: NA
Text: intention of the proposal is, undoubtedly,

Speaker: NA
Text: conscription for service overseas. Such

Speaker: NA
Text: phrases as " South-west Pacific area " or

Speaker: NA
Text: " associated w i t h " are not at all clear,

Speaker: NA
Text: but the general purpose of tbe proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: is, beyond any question, to give the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment power to conscript Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: youth for military service in foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: countries. I f this proposal were adopted,

Speaker: NA
Text: our young men could be sent against their

Speaker: NA
Text: will anywhere in the world, according to

Speaker: NA
Text: the whim of the Government in power at

Speaker: NA
Text: the time. The expression "such other

Speaker: NA
Text: territories in the South-west Pacific area

Speaker: NA
Text: as the Governor-General proclaims as

Speaker: NA
Text: being territories associated with the

Speaker: NA
Text: defence of Australia" is broad enough

Speaker: NA
Text: for anything. At the most, a further

Speaker: NA
Text: trifling amendment of the law would be

Speaker: NA
Text: required. I f this proposal should become

Speaker: NA
Text: law, the policy of the Labour party in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of military service would be

Speaker: NA
Text: entirely changed. I f we yield to the

Speaker: NA
Text: present clamour for this amendment, we

Speaker: NA
Text: shall yield the last ditch. The proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: now before us is conscription for foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: service, stark and unashamed. I n order

Speaker: NA
Text: to see clearly what is intended we must

Speaker: NA
Text: follow the steps, one by one, which have

Speaker: NA
Text: brought us to this position. I n 1940, when

Speaker: NA
Text: the then honorable member for Corio,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Casey, felt impelled to accept a safe

Speaker: NA
Text: sinecure somewhere beyond Australia, a

Speaker: NA
Text: by-election was held for the Corio

Speaker: NA
Text: division. I n due course the representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the electorate passed to a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: petent Labour man who, as Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: War Organization of Industry, has been

Speaker: NA
Text: required to bear, personally, the en-

Speaker: NA
Text: venomed attacks of Labour's enemies

Speaker: NA
Text: which should have been, and in ordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances would have been, directed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Government as a whole. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister, then Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition, called the Victorian mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of the party together and urged

Speaker: NA
Text: that the policy of Labour in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas service should he modified to a

Speaker: NA
Text: material degree. Later he acted upon

Speaker: NA
Text: the equivocal and doubtful approval

Speaker: NA
Text: which he received. He then acquiesced in

Speaker: NA
Text: an enlargement of the definition of " Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia " to include the Mandated Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tories. Still later he urged and encour-

Speaker: NA
Text: aged tbe sending of unlimited numbers of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian troops to Malaya and other

Speaker: NA
Text: more or less adjacent areas. I t was not

Speaker: NA
Text: his responsibility, but the responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Government then in power, that

Speaker: NA
Text: our men were sent to the Middle East, to

Speaker: NA
Text: Crete, and to Greece so desperately i l

Speaker: NA
Text: equipped that in the Middle East, at any

Speaker: NA
Text: rate, the Australian commander refused

Speaker: NA
Text: to take them into action. I t was not the

Speaker: NA
Text: present Prime Minister's responsibility,

Speaker: NA
Text: but that of the present Opposition, that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian troops were thrown into these

Speaker: NA
Text: various distant theatres of war, where so

Speaker: NA
Text: many lost their lives. But it is only fair

Speaker: NA
Text: to admit that all of these movements had

Speaker: NA
Text: the ready acquiescence of the majority of

Speaker: NA
Text: the members of the then Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have pointed out more than once, and

Speaker: NA
Text: so have certain other honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: on this side of the chamber, that con-

Speaker: NA
Text: scription was the inevitable result of such

Speaker: NA
Text: a policy. Obviously, it would be neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary to reinforce troops sent to foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: countries: I f the men in Australia were

Speaker: NA
Text: not prepared to volunteer for such ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice, it appeared to me to be inevitable

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government of tbe day would

Speaker: NA
Text: ship them abroad compulsorily to fight

Speaker: NA
Text: and-, i f necessary, to lay down their lives

Speaker: NA
Text: on foreign soil. There is a legal maxim

Speaker: NA
Text: that a man is presumed to intend the

Speaker: NA
Text: natural consequences of his acts. Many

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable gentlemen who supported tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister in this gradual process of

Speaker: NA
Text: breaking down Labour policy in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas military service did not perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: realize the natural results of their actions,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I have too high an opinion of tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: intelligence of the right honorable gentle-

Speaker: NA
Text: man to believe that he did not realize what

Speaker: NA
Text: must be the inevitable result of his policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Inasmuch as Labour policy is opposed

Speaker: NA
Text: to compulsory service in foreign countries

Speaker: NA
Text: -an d we on this side of the House are

Speaker: NA
Text: under an obligation to defend that policy

Speaker: NA
Text: at this moment- I must confess that

Speaker: NA
Text: I have never heard the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter make a forthright declaration against

Speaker: NA
Text: the principle of conscription. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: never heard him made a positive

Speaker: NA
Text: declaration that conscription for

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas military service was a hateful

Speaker: NA
Text: thing, or that it was an unchangeable and

Speaker: NA
Text: deep-rooted belief of the Labour party

Speaker: NA
Text: that the bodies of Australian youth

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be seized and rendered up as

Speaker: NA
Text: a sacrifice in foreign countries against

Speaker: NA
Text: their will.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the Leader of tbe Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Fadden) moved the adjournment of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House some time ago to discuss this

Speaker: NA
Text: l - subject, the present Prime Minister re-

Speaker: NA
Text: plied to him on purely strategical

Speaker: NA
Text: grounds. He said the course suggested

Speaker: NA
Text: was not necessary, that other courses were

Speaker: NA
Text: open, and that conscription would divide

Speaker: NA
Text: the people. Tliere is one matter upon

Speaker: NA
Text: which the Prime Minister is absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: sincere. He believes that he is the

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest military strategist since Han-

Speaker: NA
Text: nibal, not excluding Napoleon Bonaparte.

Speaker: NA
Text: His opposition .to the proposal of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition was based on

Speaker: NA
Text: military considerations, not on principle.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t will be remembered that a "govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment spokesman" foreshadowed some

Speaker: NA
Text: months ago the proposal that the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister has now made. The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member f or Melbourne ( Mr Calwell)

Text: and I , as well as other honorable

Text: members, addressed questions to the

Text: picions.

Text: picions, but hopes.

Text: I think that

Speaker: NA
Text: " Government Spokesman " had certain

Text: knowledge, and that knowledge was not

Text: confined to him. That the head of

Text: the Government should spring upon

Text: the public a declaration of a radical

Text: change of policy of the kind here fore-

Text: shadowed, without consulting his Cabinet,

Text: or his party, the electorate to which he

Text: was pledged as a deeply dyed i n the wool

Text: Minister, and without knowing whether

Speaker: NA
Text: or not, at the very moment at which

Text: was expounding his new policy, one of

Speaker: NA
Text: his f a i t h f u l Labour Ministers might-

Text: have been expounding the old policy is as

Speaker: NA
Text: amazing as i t is inexplicable. M y selfthey

Text: esteem in this matter is of minor imporone

Speaker: NA
Text: tance to honorable members, but

Speaker: NA
Text: great importance to me. I , too, am

Speaker: NA
Text: pledged against conscription for foreign I

Speaker: NA
Text: service; I renewed that pledge at tbe last

Text: elections, and I was returned to this-

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament f a i t h f u l l y to observe i t -

Speaker: NA
Text: Most of my constituents, knowing my

Speaker: NA
Text: beliefs, were confident that I would f a i t h -

Speaker: NA
Text: f u l l y observe i t . Some of them knew that,

Speaker: NA
Text: as a member of a Labour Government,,

Speaker: NA
Text: and with Labour approval, I had visited

Text: Geneva as the head of an Australian.

Speaker: NA
Text: Government delegation, and that there,

Text: in the presence of the representatives of

Text: 53 nations, I had declared that the Lab-

Text: our party of Australia was implacably

Speaker: NA
Text: opposed to the policy of conscription for

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign service, through which, I ven-

Speaker: NA
Text: tured to say-foolishly , as the event has-

Speaker: NA
Text: proved-Labou r had deliberately, de-

Speaker: NA
Text: finitely, and finally, drawn its pen.

Speaker: NA
Text: I invite honorable members to read in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Worker of Wednesday,

Speaker: NA
Text: the 2nd December, a leading article by

Speaker: NA
Text: my old friend Mr Boote, who has been

Speaker: NA
Text: associated with that newspaper so long

Speaker: NA
Text: and honorably as a champion of freedom.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n this well-reasoned article against con-

Speaker: NA
Text: scription he speaks for tlie great body of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labour party, and i n his concluding

Speaker: NA
Text: words, referring to the fact that certain

Speaker: NA
Text: favorably to the Prime Minister's new

Speaker: NA
Text: policy, said-

Speaker: NA
Text: Should the Prime Minister get his way, the

Speaker: NA
Text: State Labour executives or the Interstate

Speaker: NA
Text: susLabour Conference will have agreed to some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing profoundly and nationally serious for
