Text: which nothing worthy of being called justifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: the tion has been advanced.

Speaker: NA
Text: In that event a mere handful of men will

Speaker: NA
Text: have destroyed, at the request of a single

Speaker: NA
Text: person, a principle which more than a million

Speaker: NA
Text: people established by their votes on two

Speaker: NA
Text: historic occasions.

Speaker: NA
Text: What Australia did in the last great wai

Speaker: NA
Text: commanded the world's admiration.

Speaker: NA
Text: And this applied not only to the deeds of

Speaker: NA
Text: our soldiers on the_ fields of battle, but also

Speaker: NA
Text: to the magnificent determination of the nation

Speaker: NA
Text: to carry its love of freedom to the length of

Speaker: NA
Text: forbidding the conscription of its sons even in

Speaker: NA
Text: the hour of dire peril.

Speaker: NA
Text: he TUERE SHOULD BE ANOTHER REFERENDUM OK

Speaker: NA
Text: THIS ISSUE. ONLY THE NATION SHOULD

Speaker: NA
Text: REPEAL WHAT THE NATION HAS DECREED.

Speaker: NA
Text: If those who are to settle this vital question

Speaker: NA
Text: are as deep-thoughted as they are patriotic

Speaker: NA
Text: will decline to obliterate from our annals

Speaker: NA
Text: of the grandest decisions ever recorded by

Speaker: NA
Text: i t is of a democratic people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having carefully studied all the facts,

Speaker: NA
Text: am driven most reluctantly and

Speaker: NA
Text: painfull y to the conclusion that, whilst

Speaker: NA
Text: other members of the Cabinet were

Speaker: NA
Text: making crystal clear their opposition to

Speaker: NA
Text: conscription i n principle, the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister has never been in sympathy w i th

Speaker: NA
Text: the policy of the party on that vital issue.

Speaker: Mr HARRISON
Text: Wentworth) [5.53].

Speaker: NA
Text: -Durin g the last war, when the

Speaker: NA
Text: boys " on the other side" wanted

Speaker: NA
Text: a little relaxation, they took a charge

Speaker: NA
Text: of cordite out of a shell and jammed i t

Speaker: NA
Text: down the rat holes of the infested trenches.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having placed a necessary weight on top

Speaker: NA
Text: of the cordite, they would ignite

Speaker: NA
Text: it. Immediately, there would be

Speaker: NA
Text: a wild rush of rats out of the holes i n

Speaker: NA
Text: an effort to get away from the fumes of

Speaker: NA
Text: the cordite. The honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bourke ( Mr Blackburn) has put down

Speaker: NA
Text: the rat-holes on the Labour side tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: biggest charge of cordite ever used, and

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members have been scampering

Speaker: NA
Text: away i n order to dodge the fumes. This

Speaker: NA
Text: exhibition must cause the country grave

Speaker: NA
Text: concern. The division on the amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: will be an extraordinary one, and I shall

Speaker: NA
Text: be most interested to witness i t . Imme-

Speaker: NA
Text: diately the amendment was moved, mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of the Cabinet went into conference;

Speaker: NA
Text: leaving the House without a single Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter to take charge of the front bench

Speaker: NA
Text: until the honorable member for Barker

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Archie Cameron) drew attention

Speaker: NA
Text: to the fact. Consternation reigned

Speaker: NA
Text: supreme. I t is passing strange that

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Bourke,

Speaker: NA
Text: who is a Socialist, who possibly would

Speaker: NA
Text: like to be known as a Communist, and

Speaker: NA
Text: who certainly is a pacifist, should have

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced something that cuts right

Speaker: NA
Text: across the very principles of socialism.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I view the matter, the fundamentals

Speaker: NA
Text: of a democracy are based on common

Speaker: NA
Text: privilege. Indeed, democracy bas evolved

Speaker: NA
Text: to its present stage only after a long,

Speaker: NA
Text: bloody, and bitter struggle against auto-

Speaker: NA
Text: cracy. The privileges conferred by a

Speaker: NA
Text: democracy are enjoyed by every person

Speaker: NA
Text: in i t . I t is claimed by some per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sons that communism is the next step

Speaker: NA
Text: from democracy to the ultimate achieve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I do not agree with them. But i t

Speaker: NA
Text: can at least be said that those privileges

Speaker: NA
Text: which are common to socialism and com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munism have been defended by the very

Speaker: NA
Text: means to which exception is now taken;

Speaker: NA
Text: in other words, communism has reverted

Speaker: NA
Text: to the very elements of autocracy i n an

Speaker: NA
Text: endeavour to defend its privileges, includ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the compulsion of every unit in tho

Speaker: NA
Text: communistic State. We regard democracy

Speaker: NA
Text: as more enlightened than communism.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Bourke would

Speaker: NA
Text: resist any attempt by an autocracy to

Speaker: NA
Text: introduce autocratic methods; yet

Speaker: NA
Text: he is not prepared to call upon every

Speaker: NA
Text: individual i n the community to protect

Speaker: NA
Text: those communal privileges that we enjoy

Speaker: NA
Text: to-day. I know that i t is difficult in a

Speaker: NA
Text: democracy to furnish convincing evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: of the need for war. Every person who

Speaker: NA
Text: enjoys the comforts and privileges of a

Speaker: NA
Text: democracy seeks to preserve them selfishly

Speaker: NA
Text: for himself, and is not prepared to forgo

Speaker: NA
Text: them. Democracy was designed to become

Speaker: NA
Text: effective i n all its ethical relationships,

Speaker: NA
Text: not i n a period of war, but i n a peaceful

Speaker: NA
Text: world. But when there are those who

Speaker: NA
Text: will not observe the fundamental prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciples of democracy, but abuse the privi -

Speaker: NA
Text: leges that make f o r peace, their own

Speaker: NA
Text: methods must be employed against them

Speaker: NA
Text: in order that the standards and privileges

Speaker: NA
Text: of democracy may be preserved. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is recognized by communism. Every per-

Speaker: NA
Text: son who considers that the privileges he

Speaker: NA
Text: enjoys are of sufficient worth to justify

Speaker: NA
Text: the use of autocratic, dictatorship

Speaker: NA
Text: methods in order to retain them, is pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to use them.

Speaker: NA
Text: The supporters of the Government have

Speaker: NA
Text: used i t extensively fo r the recruitment

Speaker: NA
Text: of their industrial army. They claim to

Speaker: NA
Text: be the champions of industrialism, to be

Speaker: NA
Text: the only persons who adequately repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent the workers, and they have not

Speaker: NA
Text: hesitated to exercise dictatorial powers

Speaker: NA
Text: for the conscription of their industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: army. What, in the name of Heaven, is

Speaker: NA
Text: the use of conscripting an industrial army

Speaker: NA
Text: i f you are not prepared to conscript a

Speaker: NA
Text: military force to defend i t when its exist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence is threatened?

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Wha t about the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: scription of wealth?

Speaker: Mr HARRISON
Text: I f taxation at the

Speaker: NA
Text: rate of 18s. i n the £1 does not repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent a pretty f a i r measure of conscription

Speaker: NA
Text: of wealth, I do not know what would;

Speaker: NA
Text: and moreover, those who are paying at

Speaker: NA
Text: that rate are not squealing. A l l our

Speaker: NA
Text: boasted industrial and social standards

Speaker: NA
Text: would go by the board i f Australia were

Speaker: NA
Text: successfully invaded. No one with any

Speaker: NA
Text: common sense would pretend that Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia can be defended by waiting within

Speaker: NA
Text: the borders of Australia to meet an

Speaker: NA
Text: invading enemy. It has always been a

Speaker: NA
Text: cardinal principle of military strategy

Speaker: NA
Text: to fight your wars, if possible, in tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: enemy's territory. Germany knows that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Germany has never fought a war on its

Speaker: NA
Text: own soil since tbe time of Napoleon.

Speaker: NA
Text: Japan adheres to the same principle. I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not say that we should become unduly

Speaker: NA
Text: aggressive, but we must recognize that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is necessary to employ force to uphold

Speaker: NA
Text: our democratic principles and privileges

Speaker: NA
Text: when they are threatened by an enemy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now the honorable member for Bourke

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Blackburn), the arch-priest of

Speaker: NA
Text: socialism, has directed a dagger at the

Speaker: NA
Text: heart of democracy and socialism. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister, as a champion of

Speaker: NA
Text: democracy, must admit that Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: is necessarily the highest tribunal in the

Speaker: NA
Text: land. It is an assembly of the repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives of the people, and it is a duty

Speaker: NA
Text: of those representatives to make laws for

Speaker: NA
Text: the good order and government of the

Speaker: NA
Text: country. I have no wish to traverse the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister's record during tbe last

Speaker: NA
Text: war, nor the record of some of his

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers during that time. I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister, by his diligence,

Speaker: NA
Text: energy and patriotism during this war,

Speaker: NA
Text: has wiped out many blots on his

Speaker: NA
Text: escutcheon. Would to God that he would

Speaker: NA
Text: go a little farther in the interests of his

Speaker: NA
Text: country! Unfortunately, he is restricted

Speaker: NA
Text: by party affiliations, and there can be

Speaker: NA
Text: no great leader in this country, or in

Speaker: NA
Text: any other, who is prepared to bow the

Speaker: NA
Text: knee to party dictatorship. Therefore,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister must still be regarded

Speaker: NA
Text: as a political opportunist. As Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition, he resisted the despatch

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas of an expeditionary force until

Speaker: NA
Text: the logic of events forced him to change

Speaker: NA
Text: his attitude. He resisted the participa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of Australia in the Empire Air

Speaker: NA
Text: Training Scheme until events forced him

Speaker: NA
Text: to withdraw his opposition. He resisted

Speaker: NA
Text: the merging of the Australian Imperial

Speaker: NA
Text: Force and the Citizen Military Forces

Speaker: NA
Text: until he was forced by events to agree

Speaker: NA
Text: to it. He declared that be would not

Speaker: NA
Text: be bound by debate, and that the require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments of General MACArthur would not

Speaker: NA
Text: have to wait upon political considera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. Nevertheless, when a request is

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Harrison.

Speaker: NA
Text: made that he should follow a line of

Speaker: NA
Text: action necessary for the preservation of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, be does not come to Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, but by back-door methods

Speaker: NA
Text: approaches a group of union secretaries,

Speaker: NA
Text: an industrial and political junta, and

Speaker: NA
Text: tells them what must be done in order

Speaker: NA
Text: to save the country, while withholding

Speaker: NA
Text: that information from the elected repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives of the people. He even refuses

Speaker: NA
Text: to allow the matter to be debated in his

Speaker: NA
Text: own caucus. This is the man who, at

Speaker: NA
Text: the moment, is Prime Minister of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, the leader of the nation, the

Speaker: NA
Text: man against whom a member of his

Speaker: NA
Text: own party has directed an amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: designed to reassert the rights of indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: vidual members who refuse to be tricked

Speaker: NA
Text: by methods which are other than straight.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish here and now to register my

Speaker: NA
Text: protest against the gratuitous insult

Speaker: NA
Text: which has been offered to the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia through their elected represen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tatives by the Prime Minister in seeking

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe permission of an irresponsible poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: tical junta to introduce legislation vitally

Speaker: NA
Text: affecting the welfare of the country. And

Speaker: NA
Text: these outsiders, instead of being im-

Speaker: NA
Text: pressed by the fact that they have been

Speaker: NA
Text: treated as the power behind the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, as a set of all-powerful political

Speaker: NA
Text: commissars, have refused to give the

Speaker: NA
Text: authority for which the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: asked, and have told him to come back on

Speaker: NA
Text: the 4th January for their decision. " Or

Speaker: NA
Text: better still," they say, " try to convince

Speaker: NA
Text: those who are less than we are, but

Speaker: NA
Text: greater than you-th e members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: State executives." Such a situation can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not be tolerated in Australia or in any

Speaker: NA
Text: other democratic country. The Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister must answer to the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia for what he has done. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: in complete accord with .the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe Opposition on this issue. I cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: support the amendment, because I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that it threatens the very existence of

Speaker: NA
Text: democracy. I believe in conscription

Speaker: NA
Text: because I know it to be necessary i f we

Speaker: NA
Text: are to preserve tbe rights and privileges

Speaker: NA
Text: which we enjoy.

Speaker: Mr FROST
Text: Fo r two years the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member supported a government

Speaker: NA
Text: which never had the courage to bring in

Speaker: NA
Text: conscription.

Speaker: Mr HARRISON
Text: M y attitude on

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter has always been straight-

Speaker: NA
Text: forward, and will bear any investigation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope that as much may be said of the

Speaker: NA
Text: attitude of the Minister for Repatriation

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Frost) when the division is taken

Speaker: NA
Text: on this amendment. .

Text: I wonder bow want

Text: honorable gentlemen opposite will enjoy

Text: party. Here is one-

Speaker: NA
Text: Soviet Russia was not going to be made a

Speaker: NA
Text: " cat's-paw " of British imperialism.

Text: another extract-

Speaker: NA
Text: The pact of non-aggression with Germany

Text: marked the complete defeat of British foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: policy, which aimed at an anti-Soviet war, ticipating.

Speaker: NA
Text: with German fascism as the spearhead of the

Text: attack.

Speaker: NA
Text: By torpedoing the peace front the British

Text: Government opened the gates of war. Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Chamberlain and Lord Halifax are as much

Text: responsible for the war as Hitler.

Text: I have no doubt that various means will

Text: be taken by honorable gentlemen opposite

Text: to slide out of the difficulty in which

Text: they find themselves; but not even their

Speaker: NA
Text: acrobatic capacity to "float through the occupy.

Text: air with the greatest of ease " will enable

Text: I have no doubt that, with the help of

Speaker: NA

Text: doubt, very different.

Text: gentleman.

Speaker: NA
Text: the imperialist powers are destroying

Text: each other, the Soviet Government is stand-

Speaker: NA
Text: to keep their safe jobs in protected

Text: of and they have no intention of seeing

Text: tralia party and otherwise, to force other

Text: people into active participation in a war

Speaker: NA
Text: in which they have no intention of par-

Text: I have a very great respect for the

Text: military record of the honorable member

Text: Communist friends of the United Aus-

Text: can, tralia party. Honorable gentlemen oppo-

Text: site are in a disordered state of mind

Text: these new colleagues of theirs.

Text: Perhaps while I am reading a little more

Speaker: NA
Text: the from a Communist publication they may

Speaker: NA
Text: no be able to collect their thoughts. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: the early stages of this war the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munist party published tbe following

Speaker: NA
Text: At the beginning Of the war, Mr Curtin

Speaker: NA
Text: "much to the satisfaction of the

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: " supported the war. At the same

Text: time, in a half-hearted way, he said that the

Text: leading to a reversal of Labour party policy.

Text: ing, which is only one step from conscrip-

Text: tion for overseas service, has been introduced,

Text: The Communist party declares that not only

Text: Australians overseas must, at all cost, be

Text: withdrawn.

Speaker: NA
Text: Curtin's somersault recalls that at the

Text: and other Labour leaders said they were

Text: conscription for overseas service.

Speaker: NA
Text: The threat of conscription hangs over the

Text: Labour movement is to fight i t successfully,

Speaker: NA
Text: appeals to the Government to apply

Speaker: NA
Text: conscription in Australia so tbat Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian troops may be sent beyond the

Text: territorial limits of this country.

Speaker: NA

Text: rated to-day by tbe Leader of tbe Opposi-

Text: tion are designed to introduce conscrip-

Text: theatre. One school of thought i n Eng-

Text: land-i t is the dominating school-con -

Text: was the first objective of tbe British Go-

Text: and the Opposition has assisted him.

Text: I t is true. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have a part to play in this war.

Text: in tbe European theatre of war?

Speaker: NA
Text: Is i t expected tbat the Australian people

Speaker: NA
Text: shall agree to tbe policy of tbe con-

Speaker: NA
Text: scription of troops sufficient to form

Speaker: NA
Text: about twelve divisions, while we have

Speaker: NA
Text: five or six divisions in support? I have

Speaker: NA
Text: to say these things in this Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: in order tbat the people may know the

Speaker: NA
Text: facts. I have a very great regard for

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe American people, as well as a blood

Speaker: NA
Text: relationship with America, distant though

Speaker: NA
Text: it be, of which I am extremely

Speaker: NA
Text: proud. I remind honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite, who protest their friendship for

Speaker: NA
Text: America to-day, that for about twenty

Speaker: NA
Text: years they were "squealing" over tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of war debts to America. They

Speaker: NA
Text: were responsible, in part, for building up

Speaker: NA
Text: in the United States of America the isola-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionist bloc which kept America out of the

Speaker: NA
Text: war for two years. Those are facts which

Speaker: NA
Text: none of their new-found fervour for

Speaker: NA
Text: America can hide. We are entitled to ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pect from an Australian Government a

Speaker: NA
Text: statement of what our liabilities are

Speaker: NA
Text: the number of men to be used outside

Speaker: NA
Text: the borders of Australia. We could have

Speaker: NA
Text: all of our divisions against. Japan

Speaker: NA
Text: and there would still be many more

Speaker: NA
Text: divisions of Japanese to attack us.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before we can think of taking the offen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive against Japan, we must have in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country as many divisions as will be

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary effectively to defend it. The

Speaker: NA
Text: number of divisions needed for its proper

Speaker: NA
Text: defence is 25.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Wher e did the honor able

Speaker: NA
Text: member get, that information? Is he also

Speaker: NA
Text: a Hannibal?

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: I should never maku

Speaker: NA
Text: the mistake of considering the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for New England is a

Speaker: NA
Text: Napoleon or a Caesar.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: I do not set up to

Speaker: NA
Text: one.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: I am not setting up

Speaker: NA
Text: as anything but an honest man facing

Speaker: NA
Text: a position and not running away from scription ?

Speaker: NA
Text: it. I point out to the House that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have the right to expect from the British

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, too, a statement as to the

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance which this country will get in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Pacific when it mobilizes its full re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sources of man-power, simultaneously

Speaker: NA
Text: with any movement which the British

Speaker: NA
Text: and American Governments contemplate ask the people.

Speaker: NA
Text: making in Africa, Europe, or anywhere

Speaker: NA
Text: else. To Australians, Australia is the

Speaker: NA
Text: most important part of the world. Any

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian who will not consider Ausber

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia in that light may be a good

Speaker: NA
Text: imperialist, but certainly is not a good

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian. A good Australian must

Speaker: NA
Text: consider the interests of his own men,

Speaker: NA
Text: women and children as being more im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant to him than the interests of any

Speaker: NA
Text: other persons. I remind honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers opposite, in their enthusiasm for

Speaker: NA
Text: conscription, that the fate of the

Speaker: NA
Text: British people, if they were over-

Speaker: NA
Text: whelmed by Germany, would be less

Speaker: NA
Text: dreadful than the fate of Australians i f

Speaker: NA
Text: they were overwhelmed by the Japanese.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have not failed to mobilize and train

Speaker: NA
Text: our men. Comparatively, we have done

Speaker: NA
Text: more than any of our allies. Any

Speaker: NA
Text: man who said the opposite would

Speaker: NA
Text: not be telling the truth. The man-

Speaker: NA
Text: power of this country has been dragged

Speaker: NA
Text: from the factories and the farms. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: the rural districts of Australia, only

Speaker: NA
Text: as to children, old men, and women are

Speaker: NA
Text: left to attempt to carry on. In the cities,

Speaker: NA
Text: except for those who have been able to

Speaker: NA
Text: use some influence to evade service,

Speaker: NA
Text: there are very few young men of

Speaker: NA
Text: military age who are capable of

Speaker: NA
Text: serving. Our honorable friends opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: do not consider all these aspects of the

Speaker: NA
Text: case. They say, as the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Barker said in the beginning,

Speaker: NA
Text: of the war, " Let us send ten divisions

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas ". For this country, the sending

Speaker: NA
Text: of ten divisions overseas wop Id be a

Speaker: NA
Text: physical impossibility; it could .not send

Speaker: NA
Text: five divisions. The voluntary system has

Speaker: NA
Text: not been found wanting in this crisis,

Speaker: NA
Text: any more than i t was in the last war,

Speaker: NA
Text: when over 300,000 Australians went

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas as volunteers, despite the

Speaker: NA
Text: be attempt of the right honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for North Sydney to introduce con-

Speaker: NA
Text: scription for such service.

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: Di d I introduce con-

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Th e right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman tried to do so, and failed.

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: I did not try to do so.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Th e right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman made a good attempt,

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: Al l that I did was to

Speaker: NA
Text: [Extension of time granted.]

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Th e honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: for Richmond is anxious to hear what

Speaker: NA
Text: I .am about to say. As I remarked on a

Speaker: NA
Text: previous occasion, I have no hope of con-

Speaker: NA
Text: vincing anybody with that bovine men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tality which this House has long since

Speaker: NA
Text: accustomed itself to associate witb mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bership of the Country party.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was very little in regard to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific in the statement which the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister made to the House. I , for one,

Speaker: NA
Text: am disturbed at the failure of members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the War Cabinet, the Advisory War

Speaker: NA
Text: Council, and all the others who are

Speaker: NA
Text: running this war, to tell us precisely

Speaker: NA
Text: what our obligations are, what assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: we are likely to get from our allies, and

Speaker: NA
Text: just what we are to do in the coming

Speaker: NA
Text: months. The Prime Minister, for one,

Speaker: NA
Text: has told us that we must hold on for six

Speaker: NA
Text: months. Therefore, there can be no neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sity for conscription for many more

Speaker: NA
Text: months to come. He has told us tbat he

Speaker: NA
Text: wants to merge the two forces. At the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal conference of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour party in Melbourne, he said,

Speaker: NA
Text: " Gentlemen, there is no argument against

Speaker: NA
Text: one army ".

Speaker: NA
Text: OPPOSITION MEMBERS -Hear , hear!

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: I disagree witb that,

Speaker: NA
Text: because I do not want to send ten divi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions out of this country; and I certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: would not trust honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite with the arrangements in con-

Speaker: NA
Text: nexion with our military activities or

Speaker: NA
Text: with the disposal of the lives of young

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians. They failed ignominiously

Speaker: NA
Text: in time of peace. I n the depression years,

Speaker: NA
Text: thev starved the kiddies of this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: They had 30 per cent, of the bread-

Speaker: NA
Text: winners out of work and on the dole; and

Speaker: NA
Text: while that was happening, those of them

Speaker: NA
Text: who were members of anti-Labour govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments passed bills through this Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment designed to make the capitalist

Speaker: NA
Text: edifice more secure, by reducing the taxes

Speaker: NA
Text: imposed on their wealthy supporters.

Speaker: NA
Text: They were entirely indifferent to the suf-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferings of the masses of the people. But

Speaker: NA
Text: now, when those half-starved and under-

Speaker: NA
Text: nourished kiddies reach the age of eigh-

Speaker: NA
Text: teen years, these conscriptionists want

Speaker: NA
Text: to take their bodies and say, " Go

Speaker: NA
Text: out and fight in defence of the country

Speaker: NA
Text: that starved you". They would have

Speaker: NA
Text: them fight to win back for their former

Speaker: NA
Text: owners the tin-mine3 in Malaya, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the rubber plantations which were not

Speaker: NA
Text: destroyed but were left intact to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Japanese so that they might be reclaimed

Speaker: NA
Text: at some future time. That is the record

Speaker: NA
Text: of statesmanship- I use the expression

Speaker: NA
Text: satirically-o f honorable members oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: site. They have left behind them no

Speaker: NA
Text: legislative monument, no administrative

Speaker: NA
Text: act, by which they will be remembered

Speaker: NA
Text: by a grateful country. Posterity will

Speaker: NA
Text: say of them that they were the creatures,

Speaker: NA
Text: the willing tools, of the Niemeyers, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Montagu Normans, and others, in thp

Speaker: NA
Text: mis-government of this country in a time

Speaker: NA
Text: of crisis. They are anxious to regain

Speaker: NA
Text: office. They want to destroy this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment if they can; because, with, whatever

Speaker: NA
Text: faults it may possess, it is infinitely pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferable to the collection of political

Speaker: NA
Text: failures who occupied the ministerial

Speaker: NA
Text: bench of this country for too long a

Speaker: NA
Text: period. My criticism of the present Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment is, that it is not proceeding

Speaker: NA
Text: fast and hard enough to implement the

Speaker: NA
Text: policy of the party for the destruction of

Speaker: NA
Text: the capitalist system of society and the

Speaker: NA
Text: giving of a fair share of the products

Speaker: NA
Text: of their labour to the workers of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. I have no doubt that honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite will try to put their

Speaker: NA
Text: thoughts into words a little later. I t will

Speaker: NA
Text: be a difficult task. They wish, if they can,

Speaker: NA
Text: to use the present situation, to destroy

Speaker: NA
Text: our national unity, which can be main :

Speaker: NA
Text: tained only upon the basis of no con-

Speaker: NA
Text: scription. Any attempt to conscript Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians will divide the nation in two.

Speaker: NA
Text: T do not don the mantle of the prophet,

Speaker: NA
Text: but look at the position as I saw i t in

Speaker: NA
Text: the last war, and take the past as a guide

Speaker: NA
Text: to the future. I have not the slightest

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt that the introduction of conscrip-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in this country will destroy our

Speaker: NA
Text: war effort, and will create a schism in

Speaker: NA
Text: the community which could very well be

Speaker: NA
Text: avoided. The Prime Minister told the

Speaker: NA
Text: conference in Melbourne that whereas

Speaker: NA
Text: many thousands had volunteered for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Imperial Force, it was

Speaker: NA
Text: not desired that any more should

Speaker: NA
Text: volunteer because the Government wished

Speaker: NA
Text: not to destroy the Citizen Military Force

Speaker: NA
Text: divisionsbut to take the whole of these

Speaker: NA
Text: soldiers as conscripts and use them in

Speaker: NA
Text: Timor or somewhere else. The honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Wentworth, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: agrees with that policy. I have not

Speaker: NA
Text: had the opportunity, tbe time, or even

Speaker: NA
Text: the inclination, to check up entirely on

Speaker: NA
Text: his political activities, but I accept the

Speaker: NA
Text: assurance of the Minister for Labour and

Speaker: NA
Text: National Service ( Mr Ward) that, at the

Speaker: NA
Text: time of the existence of the New Guard

Speaker: NA
Text: in New South Wales, he was friendly dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed towards some of its members, i f

Speaker: NA
Text: not actually a member of the organiza-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. I know why honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite want to introduce conscription.

Speaker: NA
Text: They wish to get rid of the man-power of

Speaker: NA
Text: this country so as to break down labour

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions, introduce a larger number of

Speaker: NA
Text: women into industry, and force the

Speaker: NA
Text: workers, after the war, to fight their way

Speaker: NA
Text: up from tbe bottom of the pit once more.

Speaker: NA
Text: During the last war, the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for North Sydney was accused

Speaker: NA
Text: of bringing Maltese into this country-

Speaker: NA
Text: in fact, he was called " William Maltese

Speaker: NA
Text: Hughes"-t o take the place of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians who were being shipped abroad.

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: Thre e got in.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: I have read in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne Herald of the 3rd December

Speaker: NA
Text: that-

Speaker: NA
Text: Coloured labour might even be imported

Speaker: NA
Text: food production.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t looks as i f the conscriptionists want

Speaker: NA
Text: to introduce coloured labour, despite

Speaker: NA
Text: the White Australia policy. This con-

Speaker: NA
Text: scription propaganda is all a part

Speaker: NA
Text: of a gigantic swindle, and I greatly

Speaker: NA
Text: regret that the Prime Minister should,

Speaker: NA
Text: bave even toyed with the idea. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition proposes to

Speaker: NA
Text: administer conscription to tbe nation in

Speaker: NA
Text: one gulp; the Prime Minister would give

Speaker: NA
Text: it i n a series of little doses. I am as

Speaker: NA
Text: much opposed to conscription in little

Speaker: NA
Text: doses as in one big one. I see in the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal an attempt to break down tbe con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditions which the working people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia bave established for themselves

Speaker: NA
Text: during the war.

Speaker: Mr FADDEN
Text: Doe s the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member think that the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: is a party to tbat?

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: I think that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister was most unfortunately

Speaker: NA
Text: influenced by persons associated with him

Speaker: NA
Text: on the War Council-person a who write

Speaker: NA
Text: letters of the kind which the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition read to the House this

Speaker: NA
Text: afternoon. Conscription is the only issue

Speaker: NA
Text: upon which the Opposition can divide

Speaker: NA
Text: the nation, the only issue upon which,

Speaker: NA
Text: with the help of its press backers, it has

Speaker: NA
Text: any chance of being restored to power.

Speaker: NA
Text: Behind all these schemes for conscript-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing man-power is the idea of introducing

Speaker: NA
Text: coloured labour into Australia. This

Speaker: NA
Text: country rejected conscription during the

Speaker: NA
Text: last war, and opposition to conscription

Speaker: NA
Text: has become a tradition in the Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: party. We even went so far as to include

Speaker: NA
Text: in the platform of the party a demand

Speaker: NA
Text: that the principle of opposition to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: scription be written into the Constitution

Speaker: NA
Text: of the country, and I hope that that will

Speaker: NA
Text: yet be done. I f the manhood of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia is to be sacrificed in military

Speaker: NA
Text: operations abroad as it was sacrificed

Speaker: NA
Text: in Greece, in Crete and in Libya, where

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians bore the brunt of tbe fighting

Speaker: NA
Text: in this war as they did in France and

Speaker: NA
Text: elsewhere during the last war, then the

Speaker: NA
Text: future of the white race in this country

Speaker: NA
Text: will be a very doubtful one indeed. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have a big country to defend, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: must recognize the possibility tbat in

Speaker: NA
Text: another 25 years we may have to fight

Speaker: NA
Text: in its defence again, and at a time when

Speaker: NA
Text: for Europe is quiet and nobody is interested

Speaker: NA
Text: in us. We have done as much in this war

Speaker: NA
Text: as any country could do, and we have cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainly mobilized a greater percentage of

Speaker: NA
Text: our manhood than most other countries.

Speaker: NA
Text: But for the speed with which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Americans came to our assistance, our

Speaker: NA
Text: plight would have been perilous indeed.

Speaker: Mr HARRISON
Text: Yes , they sent their

Speaker: NA
Text: conscripts here.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: We did not ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: American people to conscript armies for

Speaker: NA
Text: our defence, and it is only the fifth-

Speaker: NA
Text: column talk of members of the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion which is creating misunder-

Speaker: NA
Text: standings between Australia and the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States of America by making

Speaker: NA
Text: comparisons between our volunteers and

Speaker: NA
Text: their conscripts. The newspaper articles

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to by the Leader of the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion which, according to him, were

Speaker: NA
Text: arousing distrust in the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: of America, were written by Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: journalists. Many of them were the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duct of the chief press backer of tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition, the man who is trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: burst his way into this Parliament, the

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman who goes by the name of Keith

Speaker: NA
Text: Murdoch. [Further extension of time

Speaker: NA
Text: granted.]

Speaker: NA
Text: Having been favoured with a further

Speaker: NA
Text: extension of time, I desire now to refer

Speaker: NA
Text: to the part played by some of those who

Speaker: NA
Text: control the finances of Australia. This

Speaker: NA
Text: year, we have voted £500,000,000 for war

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes, and it was done on the distinct

Speaker: NA
Text: understanding that the money would be

Speaker: NA
Text: used for the prosecution of the war, and

Speaker: NA
Text: not for making profits for the share-

Speaker: NA
Text: holders of big companies. I t was cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainly not voted for the purpose of pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: viding the Broken H i l l Proprietary Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pany Limited with a profit of millions

Speaker: NA
Text: for the last financial year, but that was

Speaker: NA
Text: what, in fact, happened.

Speaker: Mr HARRISON
Text: Wha t has this got to

Speaker: NA
Text: do with the amendment?

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Th e Broken H i l l

Speaker: NA
Text: Proprietary Company Limited is one of

Speaker: NA
Text: the organizations which support the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition, and which pay the election

Speaker: NA
Text: expenses of the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Wentworth.

Speaker: Mr HARRISON
Text: I wish that were true!

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Similarly the

Speaker: NA
Text: Graziers Association pays the expenses of

Speaker: NA
Text: the members of the Country party. The

Speaker: NA
Text: gross earnings of the Broken H i ll Pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: prietary Company Limited for 1940 were

Speaker: NA
Text: for 1942, £3,100,000. And these huge

Speaker: NA
Text: profits have been made out of the

Speaker: NA
Text: sacrifices of the people. The value of

Speaker: NA
Text: the stores held by the Broken H i l l Pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: prietary Company Limited increased

Speaker: NA
Text: 1941, and in 1942 they stood at

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Th e honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member must connect his remarks with

Speaker: NA
Text: the subject before the House.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Th e relevancy of

Speaker: NA
Text: my remarks is perfectly obvious to hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: orable members on this side of the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Broken H i l l Proprietary Company

Speaker: NA
Text: Limited supports the party which is now

Speaker: NA
Text: pressing for conscription. The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Bourke bas moved an amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment asking the House to register its

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition to the attempt to stampede the

Speaker: NA
Text: country into conscription.

Speaker: Mr HARRISON
Text: Ho w is the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member going to vote?

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Havin g seconded

Speaker: NA
Text: the amendment I propose to vote for it,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I expect to see honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite, with their mixed ideas on con-

Speaker: NA
Text: scription, bejng forced into the position

Speaker: NA
Text: of showing by their votes where they

Speaker: NA
Text: stand. They had not the courage to

Speaker: NA
Text: make a motion of their own when they

Speaker: NA
Text: had the opportunity, and that was when

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of tbe Opposition addressed

Speaker: NA
Text: the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: I regret that, by your meticulous re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gard for the Standing Orders, exercised,

Speaker: NA
Text: as it was, by your well-known sense of

Speaker: NA
Text: fairness, you prevented me, Mr Speaker,

Speaker: NA
Text: from telling tbe story of the gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: whose press activities have never re-

Speaker: NA
Text: dounded to the good of Australia. I

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that the Minister for War

Speaker: NA
Text: Organization of Industry ( Mr Dedman)

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Minister for Labour and

Speaker: NA
Text: National Service ( Mr Ward), and

Speaker: NA
Text: those other Ministers associated witb tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: calling up of man-power for the service

Speaker: NA
Text: of the country, should bave another look

Speaker: NA
Text: at the newspaper offices of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no reason why the newspaper in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry should not be rationalized. I f we

Speaker: NA
Text: have to put up with a lot of other priva-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions, then let us gladly suffer a situation

Speaker: NA
Text: in which there would be only one morn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing paper and one evening paper in each

Speaker: NA
Text: capital city. I f people engaged in a

Speaker: NA
Text: sheltered industry are prostituting their

Speaker: NA
Text: talents in an attempt to force conscrip-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion on the country there must be surplus

Speaker: NA
Text: man-power in that industry. This sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: plus man-power in the newspaper offices

Speaker: NA
Text: could be put to better use, as also could

Speaker: NA
Text: the. stocks of paper. They might be used

Speaker: NA
Text: for the printing of important documents

Speaker: NA
Text: for official purposes. Not only have the

Speaker: NA
Text: newspapers been a protected industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: but they have also been a specially privi-

Speaker: NA
Text: leged industry. I have no doubt that the

Speaker: NA
Text: influence of honorable members opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: has been used-thoug h perhaps i t was

Speaker: NA
Text: not altogether needed-t o save the news-

Speaker: NA
Text: papers from having to play their part in

Speaker: NA
Text: .the war effort. There are many young,

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible men in the newspaper profession

Speaker: NA
Text: who are screaming for conscription. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are like the Communists, who do not

Speaker: NA
Text: want to go to the war, but want others

Speaker: NA
Text: to do the fighting. Let those who

Speaker: NA
Text: want conscription be themselves con-

Speaker: NA
Text: scripted, and those who want others

Speaker: NA
Text: to fight do a bit of fighting them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves. Let there be equality of

Speaker: NA
Text: sacrifice. So far as a great many people

Speaker: NA
Text: are concerned there is no such thing as

Speaker: NA
Text: equality of sacrifice. Only those who

Speaker: NA
Text: are doing the actual fighting, and their

Speaker: NA
Text: close relatives, are making a 100 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, war effort. Among a great many

Speaker: NA
Text: others there is nothing but selfishsuffered

Speaker: NA
Text: ness, greed and cupidity. Everywhere

Speaker: NA
Text: people are trying to make themselves rich.

Speaker: NA
Text: For some this is a very good war, and

Speaker: NA
Text: they never want to see the end of it.

Speaker: NA
Text: finish almost where I began: The volunadvised

Speaker: NA
Text: tary system has never failed in this

Speaker: NA
Text: try, and i t will not fail now. There has

Speaker: NA
Text: never been any need for conscription, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the eonscriptionists are the worst enemies

Speaker: NA
Text: which Australia has at the moment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Apparently, honorable members opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: are not disposed to speak on this subject,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the reason for their silence may

Speaker: NA
Text: well imagined. They are satisfied

Speaker: NA
Text: parently to rely on what the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition has said.

Speaker: NA
Text: I regard the statement made by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Curtin) as a most

Speaker: NA
Text: excellent statement. I n the first place,

Speaker: NA
Text: keeps faith with Parliament by honourthe

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a promise which was made by the

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorable gentleman that Parliaformed

Speaker: NA
Text: ment would meet before Christmas to

Speaker: NA
Text: hear the. latest news of war developments.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister's statement records

Speaker: NA
Text: not only the deeds of valour of our troops,

Speaker: NA
Text: but also the casualties that have been

Speaker: NA
Text: inflicted upon them by our enemies.

Speaker: NA
Text: also gave a review of the position up

Speaker: NA
Text: the present. I t is cheering to have

Speaker: NA
Text: sented to us in a concise form a balanced

Speaker: NA
Text: statement indicating that the position

Speaker: NA
Text: materially improved. The statement was

Speaker: NA
Text: worth while for that alone. I am sure

Speaker: NA
Text: we all feel deeply for those who have

Speaker: NA
Text: lost their relatives in this awful conflict

Speaker: NA
Text: -no t only our own people, but also our

Speaker: NA
Text: allies who are fighting side by side with

Speaker: NA
Text: us. Our losses have been considerable,

Speaker: NA
Text: but. perhaps they are not so severe in

Speaker: NA
Text: the numbers killed and wounded as had

Speaker: NA
Text: been inflicted upon us after three years

Speaker: NA
Text: of the war of 1914-18.

Speaker: Mr RANKIN
Text: The y are only a bagaa

Speaker: NA
Text: telle in comparison.

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: Tha t may be so, which

Speaker: NA
Text: but tliat does not minimize tbe effect

Speaker: NA
Text: upon those who have lost relatives. The

Speaker: NA
Text: wa r to-day is very different from the

Speaker: NA
Text: war. I t is mechanized, and, while it

Speaker: NA
Text: more costly in materials, it appears so

Speaker: NA
Text: far to have been less costly in man-power.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nevertheless, I am sure that our sympa-

Speaker: NA
Text: thies are extended to those who have

Speaker: NA
Text: the loss of loved ones in battle.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition made

Speaker: NA
Text: quite a dispassionate, temperate state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. He did not, as the press forecast he

Speaker: NA
Text: I would do-th e press seem to have been ill

Speaker: NA
Text: on this occasion-mov e an amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: counment to the motion that the paper be

Speaker: NA
Text: printed. But he did indulge in a good deal

Speaker: NA
Text: of criticism of the Labour party. He com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared statements made from time to time

Speaker: NA
Text: over the last few months by responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers. He of course marshalled them

Speaker: NA
Text: in such a way, and used only such ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tracts from speeches, as would develop a

Speaker: NA
Text: case that would, in his view, damage this

Speaker: NA
Text: be Government in the eyes of the people

Speaker: NA
Text: apof Australia. He set out as far as he

Speaker: NA
Text: of was able, not only to damage us now,

Speaker: NA
Text: but also to prepare material which will be

Speaker: NA
Text: useful in the impending election cam-

Speaker: NA
Text: paign. He criticized the Labour party

Speaker: NA
Text: it and its for-m of organization. He criticized

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister for presenting to a

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour conference the views that he had

Speaker: NA
Text: in consultation with those who

Speaker: NA
Text: are conducting the military campaign for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian and American forces in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and Australian territory. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition went only a

Speaker: NA
Text: certain distance with this. He cited

Speaker: NA
Text: I t certain' of the planks of the Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: to party's platform and its methods of

Speaker: NA
Text: preorganization to suit his own case. Now

Speaker: NA
Text: I propose to .present the full facts

Speaker: NA
Text: has about Labour's platform and organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: zation. I assume that I shall be in order

Speaker: NA
Text: that in setting out in more detail the aims

Speaker: NA
Text: and objectives of the Labour party as

Speaker: NA
Text: stated in the official documents of the

Speaker: NA
Text: party and in thereby placing on record

Speaker: NA
Text: all the facts of the Labour organization.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is true that the Labour party has a

Speaker: NA
Text: - written constitution, which lay3 down cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain broad principles upon which the

Speaker: NA
Text: party operates. I t is true that men before

Speaker: NA
Text: they can be officially endorsed as Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: candidates must sign a pledge. They sign

Speaker: NA
Text: pledge to support the principles, plat-

Speaker: NA
Text: form and policy of the Labour party,

Speaker: NA
Text: is available in published form not

Speaker: NA
Text: only to Labour supporters, hut also to

Speaker: NA
Text: anybody who cares to pay the small sum

Speaker: NA
Text: last of 6d. to purchase a copy. Copies are

Speaker: NA
Text: is distributed-almos t broadcast! But what

Speaker: NA
Text: do we find in the parties in Opposition?

Speaker: NA
Text: They have no definite policy or plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no difficulty in becoming a Candi-

Speaker: NA
Text: da re for either the United Australia party

Speaker: NA
Text: or the Country party.

Speaker: Sir GEORGE BELL
Text: Ther e is difficulty

Speaker: NA
Text: in being elected, though.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr BAE2TABD -Tha t is true; and

Speaker: NA
Text: I. believe that in the future there will

Speaker: NA
Text: be even greater difficulty for United Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia party members to be elected, simply

Speaker: NA
Text: because the people are becoming more

Speaker: NA
Text: enlightened and educated. They are be-

Speaker: NA
Text: ginning to realize after passing through

Speaker: NA
Text: the years of the last war, the years of

Speaker: NA
Text: depression and the years of the war in

Speaker: NA
Text: which we are now engaged that all this

Speaker: NA
Text: talk about not being able to find money

Speaker: NA
Text: for social services, improved living con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditions and the distribution of goods and

Speaker: NA
Text: services among the people is idle and

Speaker: NA
Text: worthless. As the people are becoming

Speaker: NA
Text: more enlightened, so also is the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia party organization itself be-

Speaker: NA
Text: coming a little more democratic, if we

Speaker: NA
Text: can believe the reports we read in the

Speaker: NA
Text: press from day to day. Only this week

Speaker: NA
Text: I read of a plan which has been formu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lated in Sydney by the United Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: party, but which only follows the trail

Speaker: NA
Text: which has been blazed by the Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: party over the years. As I was saying,

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no difficulty in becoming a

Speaker: NA
Text: United Australia party candidate. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: two or more people want to cut the

Speaker: NA
Text: throats of one another in a scramble

Speaker: NA
Text: to enter Parliament, the United Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: party finally endorses them all. That

Speaker: NA
Text: happened at the last genera] elections,

Speaker: NA
Text: and indeed the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Kiehmond ( Mr Anthony) displaced a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of his organization, the Country

Speaker: NA
Text: party. Probably both were endorsed for

Speaker: NA
Text: the same contest. The Labour party does

Speaker: NA
Text: not do things that way. I t has a definite

Speaker: NA
Text: plan and policy and a written constitu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, and it endorses only its selected

Speaker: NA
Text: candidate. I t is on the platform and

Speaker: NA
Text: policy as laid down from time to time

Speaker: NA
Text: by the properly constituted' body repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: senting the Labour organizations in the

Speaker: NA
Text: various States that our members are

Speaker: NA
Text: elected. That body is elected on the

Speaker: NA
Text: same basis as the Australian people

Speaker: NA
Text: elect the Senate. There are six repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives from each State regardless

Speaker: NA
Text: of the size of the population of the

Speaker: NA
Text: State. The six members from each State

Speaker: NA
Text: gather i n conference and. discuss the

Speaker: NA
Text: items which have been listed for con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration, and the majority decides what

Speaker: NA
Text: is to be the policy of the organization.

Speaker: NA
Text: Once that body makes its decision unani-

Speaker: NA
Text: mously or by a majority, the decision

Speaker: NA
Text: is accepted by all those assembled at

Speaker: NA
Text: the conference and by the Labour move-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment as a whole. There can be nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: more democratic than that. There may

Speaker: NA
Text: be some handicaps in difficult times. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are living in difficult times now and it

Speaker: NA
Text: may not be quite so easy to follow the

Speaker: NA
Text: normal procedure, but the Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: in his capacity as a delegate from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australian branch of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Labour party, presented to the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal conference certain ideas based on

Speaker: NA
Text: his experience as the leader of the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment in these dark and difficult days.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am reminded that this party, although

Speaker: NA
Text: it has not a majority in either House, is

Speaker: NA
Text: in power because of the solidarity that it

Speaker: NA
Text: has displayed over the years and because

Speaker: NA
Text: of the lack of solidarity that has been

Speaker: NA
Text: so marked in the parties in opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have not a majority of our own

Speaker: NA
Text: members, but at least we have displayed

Speaker: NA
Text: solidarity. This Government has a very

Speaker: NA
Text: notable record in this war. I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest for a moment that we did not

Speaker: NA
Text: inherit some advantages from what had

Speaker: NA
Text: been done by our predecessors. I t is per-

Speaker: NA
Text: fectly true that we did. Every Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment inherits good things and bad things,

Speaker: NA
Text: advantages and disadvantages, from its

Speaker: NA
Text: predecessors. The Scullin Government

Speaker: NA
Text: inherited from the Bruce-Page Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment the legacy of debt which finally

Speaker: NA
Text: wrecked it, and the Lyons Government

Speaker: NA
Text: inherited from the Scullin Government

Speaker: NA
Text: the foundation upon which we rebuilt

Speaker: NA
Text: our solvency through the tariff having

Speaker: NA
Text: been placed on a much firmer basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government that preceded the Curtin

Speaker: NA
Text: Government did something to lay a foun-

Speaker: NA
Text: dation of a successful war effort, but

Speaker: NA
Text: the latter, because of its ability to

Speaker: NA
Text: make up its mind, bas been able to accel-

Speaker: NA
Text: erate the pace remarkably. I t has been

Speaker: NA
Text: able to secure the co-operation of organ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ized labour in its endeavours to marshal

Speaker: NA
Text: the man-power and woman-power of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country, and also its material resources,

Speaker: NA
Text: so that the war effort has been prosecuted

Speaker: NA
Text: with zeal and vigour.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish to bring to the notice of honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members some points i n the plat-

Speaker: NA
Text: form of the Labour party as i t was altered

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1936. Our objective, " the socialization

Speaker: NA
Text: of industry, production and exchange",

Speaker: NA
Text: remains the same, but we are realists,

Speaker: NA
Text: and, in 1936, we saw that only the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plete organization of our resources,

Speaker: NA
Text: whether i t was called socialization or

Speaker: NA
Text: something else, could secure for our people

Speaker: NA
Text: the advantages that they desired and

Speaker: NA
Text: deserved. Consequently variations were

Speaker: NA
Text: made in the details of the platform which

Speaker: NA
Text: were designed to quicken our march to-

Speaker: NA
Text: wards national control of many of our

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions. We set about the work i n a

Speaker: NA
Text: truly democratic way. Great B ritain

Speaker: NA
Text: has made tremendous strides i n relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to social security since the outbreak of the

Speaker: NA
Text: war. I have read the published extracts

Speaker: NA
Text: from the report of Sir Willia m Bever-

Speaker: NA
Text: idge. Whilst I do not regard his pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posals as providing a perfect scheme f o r

Speaker: NA
Text: social security I believe they are a step

Speaker: NA
Text: in the right direction, and that they will

Speaker: NA
Text: go some distance i n assuring to the people

Speaker: NA
Text: of Great B r i t a in an improved minimum

Speaker: NA
Text: standard of living. As Sir W i l l i

Speaker: NA
Text: Beveridge said, his scheme provides f or

Speaker: NA
Text: people from the cradle to the grave. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: we are to survive as a democratic com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity we also must have a sound social

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. I am not concerned whether we

Speaker: NA
Text: use the word " socialization" or some

Speaker: NA
Text: other word to describe the goal at which

Speaker: NA
Text: we are aiming. I am concerned that we

Speaker: NA
Text: shall have a policy to which we can devote

Speaker: NA
Text: ourselves with enthusiasm. I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: the policy of the Labour party w i l l take

Speaker: NA
Text: us much farther along this road than any

Speaker: NA
Text: other policy. Some of the general prin -

Speaker: NA
Text: ciples on which our activities are based

Speaker: NA
Text: are stated i n our platform in the follow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing words:-

Speaker: NA
Text: Cultivation of Australian democratic senti-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, development of an enlightened and

Speaker: NA
Text: self-reliant community and maintenance of

Speaker: NA
Text: White Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Complete Australian self-government as a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the British Commonwealth of

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations, the Commonwealth Parliament alone

Speaker: NA
Text: controlling administration with the vice-regal

Speaker: NA
Text: representative at all times acting on the advice

Speaker: NA
Text: of Commonwealth Ministers, except where such

Speaker: NA
Text: appears inconsistent with Imperial Treaty

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations.

Speaker: NA
Text: The platform also provides for progres-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive reform in banking. We believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government should take control of

Speaker: NA
Text: ilr. Barnard.

Speaker: NA
Text: rhe credit resources of the nation, and

Speaker: NA
Text: use them in the interest of the people

Speaker: NA
Text: and f or the development of the nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our monetary system should be applied to

Speaker: NA
Text: the advantage of the nation as a whole.

Speaker: NA
Text: We believe i n the progressive reduction

Speaker: NA
Text: of working hours so that every body will

Speaker: NA
Text: bave an opportunity to render some useful

Speaker: NA
Text: service to the community. That, I be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve, is a democratic provision. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour party also has a definite policy

Speaker: NA
Text: for agricultural advancement. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: set out clearly andconcisely in our

Speaker: NA
Text: printed platform. I referred earlier to

Speaker: NA
Text: rhe rules of the Australian Labour party.

Speaker: NA
Text: These, also, have been published for any

Speaker: NA
Text: one who cares to read them.

Speaker: NA
Text: So that i t may be clear that we are not

Speaker: NA
Text: static but move with the times, I bring

Speaker: NA
Text: to the notice of honorable members the

Speaker: NA
Text: following resolutions of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour party conference held in Adelaide

Speaker: NA
Text: on the 18th and 19th June, 1940 :-

Speaker: NA
Text: Having regard to the gravity of the world

Speaker: NA
Text: situation and the imminent danger to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth of Australia, the Empire and

Speaker: NA
Text: the allies, tliis conference of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: a m Labour party definitely declares as its policy-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Complete and indissoluble unity with the

Speaker: NA
Text: allies in the war.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. The entire resources of Australia (which

Speaker: NA
Text: include all productive and financial organiza-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions) to be under the control of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Government for national service in

Speaker: NA
Text: the urgent and adequate defence of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: and the prosecution of the war.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. That to secure maximum productive

Speaker: NA
Text: efforts, all idle employable labour be absorbed

Speaker: NA
Text: into industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. Speeding up of our war and other services

Speaker: NA
Text: on a planned scale, aiming at the highest effi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciency and the most economic use of the

Speaker: NA
Text: resources at our command.

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. National training for defence, in terms

Speaker: NA
Text: of the existing Defence Act to be maintained on

Speaker: NA
Text: the highest basis of efficiency, and provision

Speaker: NA
Text: for an adequate system of physical training

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout Australia. Complete participation

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Empire Air Force scheme. Necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: provision for reinforcement of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Imperial Force divisions, the extent of Euro-

Speaker: NA
Text: pean participation by volunteer army to be

Speaker: NA
Text: determined by circumstances as they arise,

Speaker: NA
Text: having regard to the paramount necessity of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's defence.

Speaker: NA
Text: 6. Full recognition of trade unions, safe-

Speaker: NA
Text: guarding industrial standards and the partici-

Speaker: NA
Text: pation by Labour organizations in the success-

Speaker: NA
Text: ful organization of the nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: 7. An excess war profits tax of 100 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: This conference is firmly convinced that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia can be united on these principles

Speaker: NA
Text: and calls to Australians to stand together in

Speaker: NA
Text: resisting aggression from any source, to bear

Speaker: NA
Text: willingly any burden that may be imposed in

Speaker: NA
Text: the interests of Australia's security and to

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrate to the Empire and its allies that

Speaker: NA
Text: we shall not be found wanting in the struggle

Speaker: NA
Text: for human liberty.

Speaker: NA
Text: The conference also decided-

Speaker: NA
Text: In order to implement effectively the

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed upon by conference and to achieve and

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain the maximum of national unity and

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure the preservation of the utmost de-

Speaker: NA
Text: gree of civil liberty consistent with the

Speaker: NA
Text: duct of the war, this conference declares-

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) That Parliament should be regularly

Speaker: NA
Text: consulted.

Speaker: NA
Text: (&) That the Labour party should main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain its integral identity in the

Speaker: NA
Text: people's interests.

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) That a National War Council, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: cluding representatives of Labour,

Speaker: NA
Text: should be established to advise

Speaker: NA
Text: Government in respect to the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: duct of the war and in preparing

Speaker: NA
Text: for the post-war reconstruction.

Speaker: NA
Text: The events of the last two years have

Speaker: NA
Text: caused the Prime Minister to make f u r -

Speaker: NA
Text: ther proposals to the governing ibody of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labour party. These have been re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred to a special conference fo r con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration. Surely i t w i l l be agreed that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is of the essence of democracy that

Speaker: NA
Text: such consultations shall be had with

Speaker: NA
Text: bodies responsible for the election of

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members to this Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: The gibe of the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: at the Prime Minister for having con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sulted the representative body of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Labour party was unworthy of

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honorable gentleman. I be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve that the right thing has been done.

Speaker: NA
Text: We shall be unable to marshal our physi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal and material resources to their highest

Speaker: NA
Text: pitch of production unless we can retain

Speaker: NA
Text: the goodwill of the men and women who

Speaker: NA
Text: comprise our organizations. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that i t has only been because of tbe effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive co-operation of tbe working men and

Speaker: NA
Text: women of Australia that the manufacture

Speaker: NA
Text: of munitions, the building of aerodromes

Speaker: NA
Text: and runways, and the production of war

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment generally have been stepped up

Speaker: NA
Text: so remarkably i n tbe last twelve months.

Speaker: NA
Text: Had the Government attempted to achieve

Speaker: NA
Text: these essential objectives without first ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: taining the co-operation of the working

Speaker: NA
Text: men and women of the country i t would

Speaker: NA
Text: have failed. Because of the loyalty of

Speaker: NA
Text: the working people, the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: been able to make tbe utmost use of the

Speaker: NA
Text: labour resources of the country. I f men

Speaker: NA
Text: and women serving i n one locality and in

Speaker: NA
Text: one industry have been needed more i n

Speaker: NA
Text: some other industry i n another locality

Speaker: NA
Text: they have been transferred, and so tin:

Speaker: NA
Text: war effort bas been stimulated to the sat-

Speaker: NA
Text: isfaction of the whole community. I n -

Speaker: NA
Text: stead of criticizing the Government for

Speaker: NA
Text: policy what i t has done i n this respect, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of tbe Opposition should bave

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulated i t . Many men and women

Speaker: NA
Text: con- have readily agreed, at great personal

Speaker: NA
Text: discomfort, to leave their usual places of

Speaker: NA
Text: employment and even their homes,

Speaker: NA
Text: to go to some other locality in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to engage i n other work

Speaker: NA
Text: which was regarded as being more

Speaker: NA
Text: essential to the war effort. I would not

Speaker: NA
Text: the bave believed, five years ago, that we could

Speaker: NA
Text: possibly have organized our resources so

Speaker: NA
Text: completely, and I am quite sure that we

Speaker: NA
Text: should never have been able to do i t

Speaker: NA
Text: except for the sympathetic co-operation

Speaker: NA
Text: of tbe leaders of our industrial organiza-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. We should pay tribute to the men

Speaker: NA
Text: and women who have responded so readily

Speaker: NA
Text: to the imperative demands of the nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is only because of the democratic way

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has set to work that this

Speaker: NA
Text: end has been achieved. I take no credit

Speaker: NA
Text: whatsoever for what has been done, for

Speaker: NA
Text: I have had little part i n i t . The credit

Speaker: NA
Text: is due to the Cabinet Ministers who have

Speaker: NA
Text: spent themselves without restraint i n the

Speaker: NA
Text: service of the country, particularly in

Speaker: NA
Text: organizing its resources of man-power

Speaker: NA
Text: and material. I have often criticized the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister f o r War Organization of Indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try ( Mr Dedman) because of the way he

Speaker: NA
Text: has done certain things. I believed that

Speaker: NA
Text: they could have been done more effectively

Speaker: NA
Text: with less dislocation, but the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman had a tremendous job to do,

Speaker: NA
Text: and he bad no precedents to guide h i m .

Speaker: NA
Text: He had to work hurriedly and to make

Speaker: NA
Text: plans almost f r o m day to day. I n such

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances i t was inevitable tbat mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: takes would be made. I have no doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: that had tbe honorable gentleman had

Speaker: NA
Text: time to lay plans carefully, and to give

Speaker: NA
Text: due consideration to them he would have

Speaker: NA
Text: been able to achieve results witb less i n -

Speaker: NA
Text: convenience to the general community;

Speaker: NA
Text: but I pay tribute to him for the

Speaker: NA
Text: splendid work that he has done. He

Speaker: NA
Text: deserves praise and not criticism, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: should be more ready to give praise and

Speaker: NA
Text: less ready to criticize. The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman has done a very important job

Speaker: NA
Text: for the whole community. He, and his

Speaker: NA
Text: Cabinet colleagues, have been mainly re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsible for rhe marshalling of our man-

Speaker: NA
Text: power and resources for the war effort.

Speaker: NA
Text: It cannot be denied that there is complete

Speaker: NA
Text: conscription of the man-power and

Speaker: NA
Text: woman-power of this country, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: it has the approval of the Labour organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: zations.

Speaker: Dr PRICE
Text: No t conscription, only

Speaker: NA
Text: disemployment.

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: I should like to

Speaker: NA
Text: know what the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Boothby (Dr Price) regards as conscrip-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion i f it is not conscription to take a

Speaker: NA
Text: man from Tasmania and send him to the

Speaker: NA
Text: north of Queensland to work in the Civil

Speaker: NA
Text: Constructional Corps. I know men who

Speaker: NA
Text: have come from Tasmania to the main-

Speaker: NA
Text: land because, having completed their

Speaker: NA
Text: training in munitions annexes or tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nical schools, no work was offering in

Speaker: NA
Text: their trades in that State. Because it

Speaker: NA
Text: was necessary to the war effort, they left

Speaker: NA
Text: their homes, their wives and families in

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania; and they are unable to return.

Speaker: NA
Text: Is not that conscription? They desire to

Speaker: NA
Text: be fitted into an organization in which

Speaker: NA
Text: they can render service at home. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is a natural inclination. Men who have

Speaker: NA
Text: been taken from one place and sent to

Speaker: NA
Text: another in order to protect this country

Speaker: NA
Text: against the aggressor have for the most

Speaker: NA
Text: part done willingly and without com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plaint what has been required of them.

Speaker: NA
Text: We ought to place on record our appre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciation of the services they have rendered,

Speaker: NA
Text: because in their way they are playing

Speaker: NA
Text: just as important a part in the defence

Speaker: NA
Text: of this country as is the man who

Speaker: NA
Text: shoulders a rifle and goes away to fight.

Speaker: Mr RANKIN
Text: The y are in a much

Speaker: NA
Text: pafer job.

Speaker: NA
Text: M'r. BARNARD -Th e honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Bendigo ( Mr Rankin) will-

Speaker: NA
Text: ingly left Australia to fight in the last

Speaker: NA
Text: war because he was then younger and

Speaker: NA
Text: physically fit. He would not criticize

Speaker: NA
Text: another who, because of unfitness and

Speaker: NA
Text: advancing years, remains on the home

Speaker: NA
Text: front. Let us not lose our sense

Speaker: NA
Text: of proportion 1 All cannot be soldiers

Speaker: NA
Text: in the line, bur all can be workers

Speaker: NA
Text: in the interests of the nation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: degree of their mental and physical

Speaker: NA
Text: fitness.

Speaker: Mr ARCHIE CAMERON
Text: I f the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member will quote Mary and

Speaker: NA
Text: Martha, he will round the story off

Speaker: NA
Text: properly.

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: I would not quote

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Barker. His

Speaker: NA
Text: judgment was wrong when he howled

Speaker: NA
Text: down the policy of the Labour party,

Speaker: NA
Text: which was designed to have the sky

Speaker: NA
Text: black with aeroplanes. He wanted man-

Speaker: NA
Text: power to be conscripted and sent over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas. The present war has shown that

Speaker: NA
Text: an army which has not an effective air-

Speaker: NA
Text: screen is decimated. I have received a

Speaker: NA
Text: letter from an officer friend in Egyp;.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n it he said, " Thank God for the planes

Speaker: NA
Text: that are coming from America. I t was

Speaker: NA
Text: hell before we got them." What hap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pened in the Coral .Sea, in Midway, and

Speaker: NA
Text: off Guadalcanal? Some of those happen-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings will not make pleasant reading when

Speaker: NA
Text: the history of them is written. [Exten-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of time granted.] A week ago, 1

Speaker: NA
Text: had the privilege of visiting an aircraft

Speaker: NA
Text: factory, at which I saw some of the work

Speaker: NA
Text: that is being done by Australian men

Speaker: NA
Text: and women. I was very pleased to note

Speaker: NA
Text: the production that had resulted from

Speaker: NA
Text: that organization, which was established

Speaker: NA
Text: in a very short space of time. Not very

Speaker: NA
Text: long ago, an honorable member who sat

Speaker: NA
Text: on this side, consistently in season and out

Speaker: NA
Text: of season advocated the building of a

Speaker: NA
Text: complete motor car in Australia. I re-

Speaker: NA
Text: called that fact during my visit to this

Speaker: NA
Text: aircraft factory, when I saw the type of

Speaker: NA
Text: machine that is being built there. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: aircraft are regarded as the equal of

Speaker: NA
Text: anv of their type in the world. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are now being used everywhere for the

Speaker: NA
Text: defence of this country and its allies.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f I were permitted, I could mention

Speaker: NA
Text: what is being produced, the objective of

Speaker: NA
Text: the management, the enthusiasm of all.

Speaker: NA
Text: and the willingness of the men and

Speaker: NA
Text: women employed to make sacrifices in

Speaker: NA
Text: order that this work may be done for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have said something about the form

Speaker: NA
Text: of organization that the Labour party

Speaker: NA
Text: has: how we operate; how we are

Speaker: NA
Text: governed, always by the majority;

Speaker: NA
Text: and our tolerance and recognition of

Speaker: NA
Text: the rights of minorities. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: waging this war in order to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that the majority shall recognize the

Speaker: NA
Text: rights of the minority at all times. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: aim is to have a community actuated

Speaker: NA
Text: by a spirit of tolerance, and a readiness

Speaker: NA
Text: to recognize tbe rights of all who live in it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The statement made by the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister to-day gave us a picture of the

Speaker: NA
Text: state of the war and the results that have

Speaker: NA
Text: so far been manifested. "We are entitled

Speaker: NA
Text: to feel a certain degree of gratification,

Speaker: NA
Text: but must not be unduly optimistic. There,

Speaker: NA
Text: is a long way yet to go, and probably we.

Speaker: NA
Text: shall suffer further reverses. I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: see in conjunction with the prosecution

Speaker: NA
Text: of the war the development of the social

Speaker: NA
Text: aspects of life, as is being done in Eng-

Speaker: NA
Text: land and New Zealand. I should like

Speaker: NA
Text: plans to be prepared for post-war recon-

Speaker: NA
Text: struction, and during the progress of the

Speaker: NA
Text: war an attempt to ameliorate the lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: the less fortunate members of the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity. The record of the present Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment in that regard has been marvel-

Speaker: NA
Text: lous; but i t has not yet done all thai

Speaker: NA
Text: might be done. I trust that further efforts

Speaker: NA
Text: will be made during the life of this Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament, and that ere long there will be

Speaker: NA
Text: peace throughout the world on the basis

Speaker: NA
Text: of equality, justice and fraternity.

Speaker: Mr MAKIN
Text: Hindmarsh-Ministe r

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Navy and Minister for Muni-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions) [9.44] -I t is due to the House

Speaker: NA
Text: that I as one of the Service Ministers,

Speaker: NA
Text: should supplement the speech made

Speaker: NA
Text: this afternoon by the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Curtin) with certain comments

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to the service of which I am

Speaker: NA
Text: ministerially in control. I am sure thai

Speaker: NA
Text: these will prove interesting to both hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: orable members and the country. I

Speaker: NA
Text: shall also indicate the progress that has

Speaker: NA
Text: been made industrially in the mobiliza-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of our resources for the provision of

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment of war, which is so essential

Speaker: NA
Text: if victory is to he secured.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister, in his most com-

Speaker: NA
Text: prehensive statement, gave a clear indica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the considerable improvement that

Speaker: NA
Text: had occurred in connexion with world

Speaker: NA
