Text: strategy. I n every theatre of war, the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations are now on the offensive.

Speaker: NA
Text: The disappointment and difficulties which

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier were almost the unbroken experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence of the Allied forces, have now given

Speaker: NA
Text: way to what promises to afford much

Speaker: NA
Text: greater satisfaction to those who are con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned with the fortunes of the war.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister was good would

Speaker: NA
Text: enough to compliment the various British Navy.

Speaker: NA
Text: fighting services, and none of them, I

Speaker: NA
Text: venture to say, was more worthy of his

Speaker: NA
Text: praise than that which I have the honour

Speaker: NA
Text: to administer, namely, tbe Royal Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Navy. I t has consistently main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained the lofty traditions which were

Speaker: NA
Text: handed on to it by the Royal Navy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Units of the Royal Australian Navy have

Speaker: NA
Text: been distributed throughout the various

Speaker: NA
Text: theatres of war, and everywhere the men

Speaker: NA
Text: have shown the resource, initiative,

Speaker: NA
Text: valour and determination which are

Speaker: NA
Text: characteristic of the races from which

Speaker: NA
Text: they spring. I desire, as their Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: to add my tribute to that of the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for the work which they have

Speaker: NA
Text: done. I n the course of the war we have

Speaker: NA
Text: suffered grievous losses, and we honour

Speaker: NA
Text: those who have made the supreme sacri-

Speaker: NA
Text: fice in their devotion to duty. Their

Speaker: NA
Text: heroism will be recorded in the history

Speaker: NA
Text: of this struggle, and they themselves will

Speaker: NA
Text: always be honoured by the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: nation. Tbe men of the Navy are re-

Speaker: NA
Text: garded by members of the other services

Speaker: NA
Text: witb the greatest respect. I n the battles

Speaker: NA
Text: of Greece and Crete our naval forces

Speaker: NA
Text: were in the thickest of the fight,

Speaker: NA
Text: and brought what help was possible to

Speaker: NA
Text: those engaged in land operations. Units

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Royal Australian Navy were the

Speaker: NA
Text: last to leave Singapore, bringing with

Speaker: NA
Text: them all those whom i t was possible to

Speaker: NA
Text: evacuate. At Java also, our ships played

Speaker: NA
Text: an important part, and were among the

Speaker: NA
Text: last to leave the scene of hostilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the history of this war is written,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia will have reason to be proud

Speaker: NA
Text: of the officers and men of the Royal

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Navy. I desire to acknow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ledge our indebtedness to the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Britain for their gift to us of the

Speaker: NA
Text: cruiser Shropshire. No gift could be

Speaker: NA
Text: more appropriate at this time, or more

Speaker: NA
Text: expressive of the bonds which unite the

Speaker: NA
Text: component parts of the British Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth of Nations. We desire at this

Speaker: NA
Text: time to express our appreciation of tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: help which Great Britain has given to

Speaker: NA
Text: us in this and in many other ways.

Speaker: NA
Text: Security reasons prevent me from dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: closing everything which Britain has

Speaker: NA
Text: done for us.

Speaker: Mr FORDE
Text: Th e safe transport of our

Speaker: NA
Text: troops to and from the Middle East

Speaker: NA
Text: have been impossible but for the

Speaker: Mr MAKIN
Text: Tha t is so. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: received generous help from Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Britain, and the gift of the cruiser

Speaker: NA
Text: Shropshire to replace H.M.A.S. Canberra

Speaker: NA
Text: was an expression of the goodwill of the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Britain towards Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst we have suffered the loss of

Speaker: NA
Text: several fine ships, I am glad to be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to say that, from the shipyards of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia there has come a continuous flow

Speaker: NA
Text: of vessels which bave done valuable work

Speaker: NA
Text: in keeping our coasts free from enemy

Speaker: NA
Text: raiders. These Australian-built ships

Speaker: NA
Text: have proved most efficient, and are a

Speaker: NA
Text: credit to those responsible for their

Speaker: NA
Text: design and construction. I hope it will

Speaker: NA
Text: be possible to speed up production still

Speaker: NA
Text: more. The more vessels of this kind we

Speaker: NA
Text: have in commission, the greater protec

Speaker: NA
Text: tion we shall be able to afford to our

Speaker: NA
Text: extended Australian coastline, and. to those

Speaker: NA
Text: territories for tbe defence of which we

Speaker: NA
Text: are responsible. I am confident tbat

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian workmen will respond to this

Speaker: NA
Text: call.

Speaker: NA
Text: The latest addition to the personnel

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Royal Australian Navy is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Women's Auxiliary, and I feel sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: those women who have identified them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves with our work will do their part

Speaker: NA
Text: to uphold the great traditions of the

Speaker: NA
Text: service. I welcome their help, which, at

Speaker: NA
Text: this time, is so important to us.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now, as Minister for Munitions,

Speaker: NA
Text: I desire to say a word on the sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: ject of the production of equipment

Speaker: NA
Text: which is necessary i f our forces are to

Speaker: NA
Text: succeed in this conflict. One of the great

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties which beset the Allied cause

Speaker: NA
Text: from the beginning was their lack of

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment. For many years our enemies

Speaker: NA
Text: had been preparing for this war,

Speaker: NA
Text: and they were able to time to a

Speaker: NA
Text: nicety the beginning of their offen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive against us. The United Kingdom,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the other members of the British

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth of Nations, had placed

Speaker: NA
Text: their trust in disarmament, and were

Speaker: NA
Text: thus severely handicapped during the

Speaker: NA
Text: initial stages of our conflict with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Axis Powers. I t was only by great

Speaker: NA
Text: courage and initiative that the peoples of

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Britain and the dominions, who

Speaker: NA
Text: were left alone in the early stages of the

Speaker: NA
Text: war, were able to gather the essential

Speaker: NA
Text: munitions needed to hold hack the onward

Speaker: NA
Text: rush of the enemy while they gathered the

Speaker: NA
Text: greater strength that they have to-day.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was great sacrifice of life i n those

Speaker: NA
Text: days. I t was as i f human life had to take

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe place of equipment. I say, therefore,

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is indeed marvellous that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: been able to emerge from those dreadful

Speaker: NA
Text: days when we were so ill-equipped and

Speaker: NA
Text: ill-prepared to meet the emergency of war.

Speaker: NA
Text: The response of those working in the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustries of the United Nations has been

Speaker: NA
Text: so marvellous that to-day we are able to

Speaker: NA
Text: proclaim that we have equality with

Speaker: NA
Text: the enemy in respect of aircraft,

Speaker: NA
Text: ships and all armaments and are able,

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore, to take the offensive against

Speaker: NA
Text: those who have threatened our existence.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is appropriate that I should indicate

Speaker: NA
Text: that in this country we have made marked

Speaker: NA
Text: progress in the provision of armaments.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Supreme Commander of the Allied

Speaker: NA
Text: Forces in the South-west Pacific area,

Speaker: NA
Text: General Douglas MACArthur, I suppose

Speaker: NA
Text: would be the best man to express an

Speaker: NA
Text: opinion on this matter, and he has indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cated his profound admiration of the

Speaker: NA
Text: wonderful way in which this country has

Speaker: NA
Text: mobilized to meet needs in the factory and

Speaker: NA
Text: on the field. Recently he sent a message

Speaker: NA
Text: to the manufacturers and workers in

Speaker: NA
Text: the war industries of the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: of America, which I believe has equal

Speaker: NA
Text: application to ourselves. I t was in these

Speaker: NA
Text: terms-

Speaker: NA
Text: From Bataan aud Corrcgidor, from our

Speaker: NA
Text: soldiers and sailors in the combat zone, from

Speaker: NA
Text: our Australian and Dutch allies, from the

Speaker: NA
Text: souls of those who have already shown us

Speaker: NA
Text: how to die, anxious thoughts go to you who

Speaker: NA
Text: drive the wheels of war production. Without

Speaker: NA
Text: your help the blood at the front will avail

Speaker: NA
Text: little against an enemy rich in numbers, planes,

Speaker: NA
Text: guns and ships.

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry is an indispensable factor in war.

Speaker: NA
Text: There can be no line of demarcation between

Speaker: NA
Text: the man who uses a weapon and the man who

Speaker: NA
Text: makes it. If one fails, the other must perish.

Speaker: NA
Text: We, your comrades of the firing line, bless you

Speaker: NA
Text: for what you have already done for us and

Speaker: NA
Text: wish you Godspeed.

Speaker: NA
Text: That message which he so appropriately

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed to the industries of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States of America could rightly be ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dressed to those who are engaged in indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try in this country, and who are render-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing magnificent service. The greatness of

Speaker: NA
Text: that service can be realized when i t is

Speaker: NA
Text: remembered that before 1937 not one gun

Speaker: NA
Text: was made in this country, whereas to-day

Speaker: NA
Text: almost the full range of ordnance required

Speaker: NA
Text: by the armed services-th e Navy, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Army and the Air Force-i s being manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: factured in Australia, and that the quality

Speaker: NA
Text: is second to none in the world. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: guns are being used in the various theatres

Speaker: NA
Text: of war with wonderful results. One strik-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing example of the efficient workmanship

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian industry is the 3.7 inch

Speaker: NA
Text: anti-aircraft gun, a most effective piece

Speaker: NA
Text: ordnance that, we use to defend coastal

Speaker: NA
Text: /ones in this country. Recently 21 Jap-

Speaker: NA
Text: anese aircraft passed over an area in

Speaker: NA
Text: which seven of these guns were located.

Speaker: NA
Text: A battery of four guns, using Australian-

Speaker: NA
Text: made ammunition, at the first salvo

Speaker: NA
Text: brought down four Japanese aircraft.

Speaker: NA
Text: I regard that . as outstanding evi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence of the great merit of the equip-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that we are supplying to our men.

Speaker: NA
Text: But it does more than that. The feat of

Speaker: NA
Text: the gunners with Australian-made wea-

Speaker: NA
Text: pons and ammunition will increase the

Speaker: NA
Text: confidence of the men using them that

Speaker: NA
Text: they are capable of doing the job re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quired of them. Our men can feel con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tent that they are using the best weapons

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is possible to provide them with.

Speaker: NA
Text: But it is not only in the manufacture of

Speaker: NA
Text: the 3.7 inch gun that we have excelled.

Speaker: NA
Text: Every other class of weapon which we arc

Speaker: NA
Text: turning out for our men in the fighting

Speaker: NA
Text: services is of a high order. The vast

Speaker: NA
Text: range of armaments manufactured in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia was brought to public notice at a

Speaker: NA
Text: huge demonstration recently in the streets

Speaker: NA
Text: of Melbourne. Every one who saw that

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstration must have been impressed

Speaker: NA
Text: with the fact that the industries of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country have achieved wonderful things.

Speaker: NA
Text: On Saturday next there will be an even

Speaker: NA
Text: larger display in Sydney of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: ingenuity and manufacturing skill, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that the Australian people will be

Speaker: NA
Text: further stimulated by evidence of the

Speaker: NA
Text: gigantic efforts that are being made to-

Speaker: NA
Text: day throughout the length and breadth

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia, to make us more secure

Speaker: NA
Text: against any attempt by the enemy to tres-

Speaker: NA
Text: pass upon our soil. I believe,, with Gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral MACArthur, that we shall not concede

Speaker: NA
Text: one single inch of this country to the

Speaker: NA
Text: enemy. But only by providing our

Speaker: NA
Text: forces witb the weapons of war they

Speaker: NA
Text: need shall we be able to achieve that

Speaker: NA
Text: resolve.

Speaker: Mr FORDE
Text: Th e 25-pounder gun did

Speaker: NA
Text: a wonderful job in New Guinea.

Speaker: Mr MAKIN
Text: I am glad to have the

Speaker: NA
Text: commendation of the Minister for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Army of the 25-pounder gun. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: who have seen the splendid photographic

Speaker: NA
Text: display by the Department of Informa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of our fighting forces in service in

Speaker: NA
Text: New Guinea will have seen that our 25-

Speaker: NA
Text: of pounder gun has been used in that area

Speaker: NA
Text: with great effect, I t is one of the most

Speaker: NA
Text: powerful weapons our men possess in

Speaker: NA
Text: that battle zone and I know that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for the Army has received the

Speaker: NA
Text: most encouraging reports of its work.

Speaker: NA
Text: Not only in the production of the heavier

Speaker: NA
Text: artillery and anti-aircraft guns have our

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturers of munitions been excel-

Speaker: NA
Text: ling. We have been able to provide the

Speaker: NA
Text: very best of sub-machine gun equipment.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have even been able to improve

Speaker: NA
Text: upon - the latest designs from overseas,

Speaker: NA
Text: thereby making the weapons far more

Speaker: NA
Text: efficient in doing the job required of

Speaker: NA
Text: them. I pay tribute to the ingenuity of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australians, both the scientists in the

Speaker: NA
Text: laboratories and the men in the work-

Speaker: NA
Text: shops. They all have contributed to-

Speaker: NA
Text: wards reaching the high degree of

Speaker: NA
Text: efficiency that stands to our credit-

Speaker: NA
Text: in all classes of war-time produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. A further example of the skill of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian industry is the fact that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have been able to manufacture all the dif-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferent classes of armour-plate required

Speaker: NA
Text: and kept up the flow of the material to

Speaker: NA
Text: the various factories. That proves how

Speaker: NA
Text: valuable these industries are to Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is perhaps an astounding fact that we

Speaker: NA
Text: are able to manufacture this steel at half

Speaker: NA
Text: the price that we should have to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: if we'imported it.

Speaker: Sir FREDERICK STEWART
Text: Th e credit

Speaker: NA
Text: must go to the Broken Hill Proprietary

Speaker: NA
Text: Company Limited.

Speaker: Mr MAKIN
Text: An d to others, for others

Speaker: NA
Text: are providing munitions to the depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I do not desire to deprive

Speaker: NA
Text: anybody of due credit. All praise to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Broken Hill Proprietary Company

Speaker: NA
Text: Limited and to the others who have

Speaker: NA
Text: made these wonderful contributions to-

Speaker: NA
Text: wards our safety! One class of armour-

Speaker: NA
Text: plate we produce at one-sixth of what Wf

Speaker: NA
Text: used to pay for it when we imported it.

Speaker: NA
Text: These examples indicate that in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia very fine work is being done. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have increasingly sought to make Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia self-contained and self-sufficient, so

Speaker: NA
Text: tbat it shall be able to provide all the

Speaker: NA
Text: essentials of warfare.

Speaker: Sir FREDERICK STEWART
Text: I think the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister will be fair enough to admit

Speaker: NA
Text: tbat both tbe 3.7 anti-aircraft gun, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the 25-pounder field gun were put into

Speaker: NA
Text: production by the previous Government.

Speaker: Mr MAKIN
Text: I am not trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: make any political capital out of this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter. I deprecate attempts to place

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility witb this or that govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. A ll I say is that the guns were

Speaker: NA
Text: made available for the fighting services

Speaker: NA
Text: by this Government. This essential

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment, and other war material, have

Speaker: NA
Text: been turned out from the workshops of

Speaker: NA
Text: this country in a way that reflects the

Speaker: NA
Text: highest credit upon our workers. Not

Speaker: NA
Text: only have artillery pieces, anti-tank guns

Speaker: NA
Text: and anti-aircraft guns been turned out in

Speaker: NA
Text: quantity but, as the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: announced recently, we have been able

Speaker: NA
Text: to produce 1,000,000,000 rounds of

Speaker: NA
Text: ammunition.

Speaker: NA
Text: "What I have said shows that our

Speaker: NA
Text: establishments have' made remarkable-

Speaker: NA
Text: development. I n the past our war

Speaker: NA
Text: industries have been concentrated too

Speaker: NA
Text: largely in our capital cities, but ever

Speaker: NA
Text: since I assumed office, I have taken

Speaker: NA
Text: all possible steps to apply a policy ol

Speaker: NA
Text: decentralization in this regard. I be

Speaker: NA
Text: lieved that only in this way could we use,

Speaker: NA
Text: to the greatest possible degree, our re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sources of equipment and man-power.

Speaker: NA
Text: All of the twenty factories which have

Speaker: NA
Text: been put into production during the four-

Speaker: NA
Text: teen months that I have been Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Munitions have been located in

Speaker: NA
Text: country centres. This has made possiblp

Speaker: NA
Text: the best use of existing housing and trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: port and other essential services required

Speaker: NA
Text: for war production. I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: through centralization in our capital

Speaker: NA
Text: cities, our war industries were extremely

Speaker: NA
Text: vulnerable. For that reason, and also

Speaker: NA
Text: because I realized the need to bring into

Speaker: NA
Text: production all available resources of

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment, I have concentrated on estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lishing our new centres of production in

Speaker: NA
Text: country areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: It ha? been a common practice

Speaker: NA
Text: for people to criticize and find fault

Speaker: NA
Text: during the years of the war. I t is

Speaker: NA
Text: a great pity tbat such persons could not

Speaker: NA
Text: accompany their criticism with a few

Speaker: NA
Text: constructive suggestions. My colleague

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for War Organization of

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry ( Mr Dedman) has been singled

Speaker: NA
Text: out for special criticism; but I wish to

Speaker: NA
Text: inform the Australian public that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: largely because of his untiring efforts and

Speaker: NA
Text: loyal devotion to the imperative needs of

Speaker: NA
Text: the country, and by his endeavours to

Speaker: NA
Text: divert labour and equipment from the

Speaker: NA
Text: production of non-essential goods to the

Speaker: NA
Text: production of essential needs, that our

Speaker: NA
Text: war effort has reached such a high degree

Speaker: NA
Text: of efficiency. The Minister has been able

Speaker: NA
Text: to secure the co-operation of the working

Speaker: NA
Text: people, and so has made possible the

Speaker: NA
Text: utmost use of factory and man-power

Speaker: NA
Text: resources. Certain materials which were

Speaker: NA
Text: in desperately short supply have been

Speaker: NA
Text: diverted by him from non-essential in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustries to war industries. As I have been

Speaker: NA
Text: in charge of munitions production I am

Speaker: NA
Text: able to assess the value of the work done

Speaker: NA
Text: by the honorable gentleman, and I regard

Speaker: NA
Text: it very highly indeed. [Extension of

Speaker: NA
Text: lime granted.] I am afraid that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister has accepted a good deal of the

Speaker: NA
Text: criticism which should have been shared

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Production Executive. As I am

Speaker: NA
Text: a member of the Production Executive J

Speaker: NA
Text: wish to inform the House and the country

Speaker: NA
Text: generally that my colleagues and I on

Speaker: NA
Text: that executive accept our full share of

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility for what has been done

Speaker: NA
Text: We are well aware of the fine work that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for War Organization of

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry has performed in mobilizing

Speaker: NA
Text: production for the benefit of the fighting

Speaker: NA
Text: services. When the story of our achieve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments in this regard can be fully told,

Speaker: NA
Text: and when it is realized how effectively

Speaker: NA
Text: essential materials in short supply were

Speaker: NA
Text: used, I am sure tbat many people will

Speaker: NA
Text: regret their carping criticism. I pay high

Speaker: NA
Text: tribute to the Minister for his service.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that those honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: who are able to witness the display o

Speaker: NA
Text: munitions in the streets of Sydney on

Speaker: NA
Text: Saturday will be surprised at the diversity

Speaker: NA
Text: and quality of the equipment produced

Speaker: NA
Text: from our factories.

Speaker: NA
Text: I thank honorable members for their

Speaker: NA
Text: attention to what I have said concerning

Speaker: NA
Text: the activities of the Department of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Navy and the Department of Munitions.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have been proud and honoured to be

Speaker: NA
Text: identified with the administration of both

Speaker: NA
Text: departments, and I hope that my remarks

Speaker: NA
Text: will give honorable members and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Adjournment. | 10 DECEMBER, 1942. |

Speaker: NA
Text: country a better appreciation of what

Speaker: NA
Text: has been done through these instrumen-

Speaker: NA
Text: talities to assist the country i n its time of

Speaker: NA
Text: serious emergency.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr DRAKEFORD)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.

Text: ADJOURNMENT.

Text: Motion (by Mr CURTIN ) proposed-

Text: That the House do now adjourn.

Speaker: Mr RYAN
Text: Flinders) [10.26] -

Speaker: NA
Text: bring to the notice of the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: the very great dissatisfaction that has

Speaker: NA
Text: been caused to a large section of the

Speaker: NA
Text: public by the banning of the "Pleasant sun.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sunday Afternoon " broadcasts from Wes-

Speaker: NA
Text: ley Church, Melbourne, by the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Broadcasting Commission. These broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casts have been a feature of broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: in Victoria, and i n other parts of

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, f o r many years and the protests

Speaker: NA
Text: that have been made against the banning

Speaker: NA
Text: of them have come not only from despoken

Speaker: NA
Text: nominational bodies but also from

Speaker: NA
Text: organizations and prominent citizens

Speaker: NA
Text: associated with religious institutions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Wesley "Pleasant Sunday A f t e r n o o

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasts have filled a good portion

Speaker: NA
Text: the Sunday afternoon of many people

Speaker: NA
Text: years past. I am informed that the broadover,

Speaker: NA
Text: casts began thirteen years ago and

Speaker: NA
Text: they have increased i n popularity,

Speaker: NA
Text: by year; so much so, that in many house-

Speaker: NA
Text: holds the middle of the Sunday afternoon

Speaker: NA
Text: is regularly devoted to listening to them.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have some figures which, though not

Speaker: NA
Text: official, accurately indicate the popularity

Speaker: NA
Text: of the broadcasts. I am informed that

Speaker: NA
Text: in New South Wales 10 per cent, of

Speaker: NA
Text: listeners tune i n to the Wesley

Speaker: NA
Text: "Pleasant Sunday A f t e r n o o n "

Speaker: NA
Text: is a high percentage. I n Victoria,

Speaker: NA
Text: however, the figure is 40 per cent.,

Speaker: NA
Text: all honorable members w i l l agree, is

Speaker: NA
Text: pressive. These figures represent many

Speaker: NA
Text: Adjournment. 1731

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of listeners. So f a r as I have

Speaker: NA
Text: been able to' learn no reason has been

Speaker: NA
Text: given by the Australian Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission f o r the banning of the

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasts.

Speaker: Sir FREDERICK STEWART
Text: Th e honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member must have a good idea why

Speaker: NA
Text: they have been banned. Is i t not a

Speaker: NA
Text: further evidence of the influence of

Speaker: NA
Text: liquor interests?

Speaker: Mr RYAN
Text: I have my suspicions

Speaker: NA
Text: rhar. this may be so, but the fact remains

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Australian Broadcasting Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: A; mission has given no reason for its

Speaker: NA
Text: actions. The final banning of the broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casts came shortly after there had been a

Speaker: NA
Text: public controversy on the liquor subject.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many people believe, rightly or wrongly,

Speaker: NA
Text: that liquor interests are responsible f o r

Speaker: NA
Text: what has been done. However that may

Speaker: NA
Text: be, the Australian Broadcasting Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission's action has caused great dissatis-

Speaker: NA
Text: I faction. The " Pleasant Sunday After-

Speaker: NA
Text: noon " forum at Wesley Church has been

Speaker: NA
Text: used by all sorts and conditions of people

Speaker: NA
Text: to discuss almost every subject under the

Speaker: Sir FREDERICK STEWART
Text: Th e Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister recently used tbe forum.

Speaker: Mr RYAN
Text: I believe that i t ha--

Speaker: NA
Text: been occupied recently also by politician?

Speaker: NA
Text: Ausof every party. I know that both t h f

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister and the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Kooyong ( Mr Menzies) have

Speaker: NA
Text: at the " Pleasant Sunday After-

Speaker: NA
Text: noon " recently. Distinguished visitors,

Speaker: NA
Text: nor including Mr Noel Coward, have also

Speaker: NA
Text: The spoken there. The broadcasts to my know-

Speaker: NA
Text: n " ledge from listening, and from reports by

Speaker: NA
Text: of my friends, have been non-political, un-

Speaker: NA
Text: for denominational and non-sectional. More-

Speaker: NA
Text: they have been of educational valnp.

Speaker: NA
Text: that For these reasons I cannot understand

Speaker: NA
Text: year why they should have been banned.

Speaker: NA
Text: On Sunday afternoons Dr I r v i n g

Speaker: NA
Text: Benson, the minister of Wesley Church,

Speaker: NA
Text: has conducted a Questions and Answers

Speaker: NA
Text: session i n which he has dealt with

Speaker: NA
Text: subjects of a religious character.

Speaker: NA
Text: The answers are appropriate to the ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions, and i n them can be found no sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: . That tional or denominational trace. W h y

Speaker: NA
Text: the broadcasts should be banned, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: which, completely without knowledge. I can

Speaker: NA
Text: i m - see no reason f o r the ban. I ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to look very carefully into

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter, and to take what steps may

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriately be taken to have the

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasts restored to tbe programme of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Broadcasting Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion, thus satisfying a large number of

Speaker: NA
Text: persons. A great deal of good will be

Speaker: NA
Text: clone to the people as a whole if they are

Speaker: NA
Text: allowed to have the advantage of tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasts.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n conclusion, I shall read extracts

Speaker: NA
Text: from a letter I received a few days ago

Speaker: NA
Text: from a lady; it is typical of a large

Speaker: NA
Text: number of others, and admirably ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: presses the thoughts of these who have

Speaker: NA
Text: suffered the loss of these broadcasts, to

Speaker: NA
Text: which all looked forward with interest

Speaker: NA
Text: and anticipation-

Speaker: NA
Text: I am writing on behalf of the family and

Speaker: NA
Text: myself and friends to ask you to use your

Speaker: NA
Text: influence in the matter of the ban on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Pleasant Sunday Afternoon session from

Speaker: NA
Text: Wesley Church, and the Question and Answers

Speaker: NA
Text: session. This act of the commission appears

Speaker: NA
Text: to be a direct challenge to the public. Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Churchill once said, " Never did so many

Speaker: NA
Text: owe sp much to so few " (correct, am I not?);

Speaker: NA
Text: that can be reversed-Neve r did so few deprive

Speaker: NA
Text: so many of so much. I t savors of Hitlerism

Speaker: NA
Text: and dictatorship. The Pleasant Sunday After-

Speaker: NA
Text: noon is regarded as a national institution and

Speaker: NA
Text: should be broadcast from a national station,

Speaker: NA
Text: the people's station, and the one supported

Speaker: NA
Text: by the people. The commission is well aware

Speaker: NA
Text: of the very great popularity of this session;

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout the years it has been the highlight

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Sunday afternoon session. Strange

Speaker: NA
Text: that, at this late hour, the Australian Broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casting Commission has banned it. No other

Speaker: NA
Text: form of entertainment can take its place,

Speaker: NA
Text: nor is. the Australian Broadcasting Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion equal to giving anything to approach

Speaker: NA
Text: the Pleasant Sunday Afternoon. I t eannot

Speaker: NA
Text: be done, adequately, not even by the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tbe ban on Questions and Answers came as

Speaker: NA
Text: a second bomb. A session as highly appre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciated in its own sphere as the Pleasant

Speaker: NA
Text: Sunday Afternoon. Again, why has it taken

Speaker: NA
Text: just on thirteen years for the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Broadcasting Commission to wake up to the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that it's taking a risk, that it may give

Speaker: NA
Text: pain or offence to important sections of the

Speaker: NA
Text: community. No doubt you read " A.B.C. bans

Speaker: NA
Text: Talks by Dr Benson " in the Argus, Saturday,

Speaker: NA
Text: November 28th, and know what I'm referring

Speaker: NA
Text: to. Now, who are these important sections

Speaker: NA
Text: of the community? Easily answered, I think.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why don't .they turn the dial of their radio,

Speaker: NA
Text: as we do when the Australian Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission broadcasts modern arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: of the grand old masters played by swing

Speaker: NA
Text: bands and our lovely old songs modernized

Speaker: NA
Text: or sung (?) by moaning crooners.

Speaker: NA
Text: ghastly and the mutilation of our best music

Speaker: NA
Text: is absolutely disgraceful.

Speaker: NA
Text: No denomination is represented in Questions

Speaker: NA
Text: and Answers; they are absolutely unsec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tarian. If listeners have been satisfied all

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ryan.

Speaker: NA
Text: this time and wish for no other to conduct

Speaker: NA
Text: the session, in fact do not want any but Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Benson, that is all sufficient, and really no

Speaker: NA
Text: concern of the Australian Broadcasting Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission.

Speaker: NA
Text: The present controversy re religion and

Speaker: NA
Text: eliminating some church services now being

Speaker: NA
Text: aired in the A.B.C. Weekly is rather disquiet-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and apparently the thin end of the wedge.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are at war-som e of our nearest and

Speaker: NA
Text: dearest are giving their all to save our land,

Speaker: NA
Text: to save every one of us from the Godless,

Speaker: NA
Text: inhuman monsters that threaten to plunge

Speaker: NA
Text: the world back to the dark ages, the days of

Speaker: NA
Text: barbarism, or worse. Church services must

Speaker: NA
Text: not be interfered with. Are we not fighting

Speaker: NA
Text: for a Christian world? The radio church is

Speaker: NA
Text: a spiritual force in the community. It

Speaker: NA
Text: reaches thousands who would never hear a

Speaker: NA
Text: service but for it. The sick iu their own

Speaker: NA
Text: homes and in hospital, the aged, shut-in

Speaker: NA
Text: invalids, people of the far out-back country,

Speaker: NA
Text: people nearer who are unable to attend divine

Speaker: NA
Text: service for various reasons, and many others.

Speaker: NA
Text: The best the States have to offer from

Speaker: NA
Text: cathedrals and all leading churches (this list

Speaker: NA
Text: of those who benefit applies to the Pleasant

Speaker: NA
Text: Sunday Afternoon, too).

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Haire and other writers to the A.B.C.

Speaker: NA
Text: Weekly do not appear to consider others.

Speaker: NA
Text: All they need do is turn the dial of their

Speaker: NA
Text: radio. They will find a galaxy of entertain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to select from the commercial stations,

Speaker: NA
Text: even the class of music they ask the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Broadcasting Commission to broadcast

Speaker: NA
Text: in place of church services.

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope that the Government, at a very

Speaker: NA
Text: early date, will give serious consideration

Speaker: NA
Text: to the restoration of these broadcasts,

Speaker: NA
Text: which are of immense benefit and give

Speaker: NA
Text: considerable enjoyment to a vast section

Speaker: NA
Text: of our population.

Speaker: Mr BLACKBURN
Text: Bourke) [10.36].

Speaker: NA
Text: - I support what has been said by the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Flinders ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ryan) in relation to the "Pleasant

Speaker: NA
Text: Sunday Afternoon " broadcasts. I n Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne, I have expressed the opinion that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Broadcasting Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: may not be altogether to blame, because

Speaker: NA
Text: I have associated its action with a pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision of the Broadcasting Act that was

Speaker: NA
Text: passed during tbe last sessional period.

Speaker: NA
Text: Section 92 of that act enables the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter to prevent a broadcaster from repeat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing anything which he considers may

Speaker: NA
Text: have given offence to the public or any

Speaker: NA
Text: section of it. I noticed that that phrase

Speaker: NA
Text: It's was used in the letter sent by Mr Cleary

Speaker: NA
Text: to Dr Benson. I believe that the

Speaker: NA
Text: "Pleasant Sunday Afternoon" broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casts satisfied a widespread public de-

Speaker: NA
Text: mand, not merely in Melbourne, but also

Speaker: NA
Text: in the country districts of Victoria and

Speaker: NA
Text: probably in the other States as well. I

Speaker: NA
Text: consider that these broadcasts should be

Speaker: NA
Text: continued, and tbat their discontinuance

Speaker: NA
Text: was a great mistake. When the matter

Speaker: NA
Text: was mentioned previously in this House,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister ( Mr Curtin) said

Speaker: NA
Text: that he was surprised to hear that any

Speaker: NA
Text: religious denomination regularly had the

Speaker: NA
Text: exclusive use of the Australian Broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casting Commission service for any given

Speaker: NA
Text: time. The right honorable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: was under a misapprehension. This ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice is not used for the denominational

Speaker: NA
Text: religious purposes of the Methodist

Speaker: NA
Text: Church. The " Pleasant Sunday After-

Speaker: NA
Text: noon " service is a meeting -at which

Speaker: NA
Text: addresses are given by persons of all

Speaker: NA
Text: denominations and all faiths on matters

Speaker: NA
Text: of social interest. The Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: has been invited to it, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Social Services ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Holloway) has spoken at it. The secre-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary of the Melbourne Trades Hall

Speaker: NA
Text: Council bas given an address on several

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions. I t is entirely a non-partisan

Speaker: NA
Text: institution, and the discontinuance of it

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be permitted. I t is quite true

Speaker: NA
Text: that these meetings are now being broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: cast by a commercial station. I f they

Speaker: NA
Text: offend sections of the public, they are

Speaker: NA
Text: much more likely to offend the advertisers

Speaker: NA
Text: on a commercial station than tbe con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stituency of a public broadcasting com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission.

Speaker: Mr HOLT
Text: Fawkner) [10.39] - I

Speaker: NA
Text: accord general support to the plea

Speaker: NA
Text: made by the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Flinders ( Mr Ryan). Like him, I have

Speaker: NA
Text: had a number of protests from persons in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate, and these have confirmed

Speaker: NA
Text: the conviction I previously held that

Speaker: NA
Text: particular Sunday afternoon broadcast

Speaker: NA
Text: was being made to a very wide and appre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciative listening public. The service was

Speaker: NA
Text: not in its nature religious or denomi-

Speaker: NA
Text: national.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before proceeding with the points

Speaker: NA
Text: raised by the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Flinders, I remind the House that we had

Speaker: NA
Text: a discussion on the "Pleasant Sunday

Speaker: NA
Text: Afternoon" service during tbe last ses-

Speaker: NA
Text: sional period, when a particular talk

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed to be broadcast-was banned. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am prepared to admit, and possibly, upon

Speaker: NA
Text: reflection, those associated with the

Speaker: NA
Text: "Pleasant Sunday Afternoon" service

Speaker: NA
Text: will concede, that they committed

Speaker: NA
Text: an error of judgment in attempt-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to repeat at such sbort notice two

Speaker: NA
Text: talks on a highly controversial political

Speaker: NA
Text: matter. Surely, there must be some sig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nificance in the action which followed so

Speaker: NA
Text: quickly on the controversy that then

Speaker: NA
Text: ensued. Tbe arguments have been stated

Speaker: NA
Text: by the chairman of the Australian Broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casting Commission. I t seems odd, to say

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe least, that suddenly, after tbe discus-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion had developed, first the talk itself,

Speaker: NA
Text: and secondly the Questions and Answers

Speaker: NA
Text: or session, were banned. When the matter

Speaker: NA
Text: was raised in this House, the Prime Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister expressed some surprise that one

Speaker: NA
Text: particular service should enjoy a mono-

Speaker: NA
Text: poly of a. particular radio time in a

Speaker: NA
Text: national programme. Later, the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable gentleman said that he had

Speaker: NA
Text: made inquiries on his own account, and

Speaker: NA
Text: was satisfied that the Wesley services

Speaker: NA
Text: could not be regarded as denominational.

Speaker: NA
Text: He said, " They have been con-,

Speaker: NA
Text: ducted to the satisfaction of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Broadcasting Commission, which

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasts them ". I t may be that there

Speaker: NA
Text: are satisfactory reasons why the action

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian Broadcasting Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion should be upheld, but I have yet

Speaker: NA
Text: to be convinced that those reasons exist.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that the commission did not have

Speaker: NA
Text: a proper estimate of the interest in, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the value placed upon, these services by

Speaker: NA
Text: the listening public, particularly in

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria. Otherwise it would not have

Speaker: NA
Text: acted as i t did. The suggestion has

Speaker: NA
Text: been made that some of these talks might

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to be broadcast,, but that the

Speaker: NA
Text: script should he in the hands of the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission for a period of about three weeks

Speaker: NA
Text: this before a talk was delivered. Members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Broadcasting Committee will re-

Speaker: NA
Text: member tbat they commented on the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that over-centralization of the work of

Speaker: NA
Text: the commission in Sydney had meant

Speaker: NA
Text: that some services could not be rendered

Speaker: NA
Text: in the other States. The committee's

Speaker: NA
Text: report stated-

Speaker: NA
Text: We were astonished to learn that all con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tentious talks and commentaries are now

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to head office. This, owing to the

Speaker: NA
Text: time factor, gives residents of Sydney a

Speaker: NA
Text: monopoly of certain broadcasting.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not know what effective action

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament or the Government can take,

Speaker: NA
Text: but if no other course be open I think

Speaker: NA
Text: that it should at least be a matter for

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry by the Broadcasting Committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: That body could inquire into the circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances of the ban, and also into the

Speaker: NA
Text: value of the services rendered in the past;

Speaker: NA
Text: and should it be convinced, as I and

Speaker: NA
Text: many members on all sides of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: are convinced, that a very real and

Speaker: NA
Text: valuable service was being rendered, that

Speaker: NA
Text: committee might make representations to

Speaker: NA
Text: the commission to have the service

Speaker: NA
Text: restored.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recently, the Minister for "War

Speaker: NA
Text: Organization of Industry ( Mr Dedman)

Speaker: NA
Text: announced a policy in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: engagement of domestic servants. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: told, by interjection, that that policy is

Speaker: NA
Text: nor to be persisted in. I f the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: would indicate that that is so, time will

Speaker: NA
Text: be saved.

Speaker: Mr DEDMAN
Text: Tha t is so. The validity

Speaker: NA
Text: of the regulation has been called in

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and the matter is being examined.

Speaker: Mr HOLT
Text: Th e Minister's interjec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion indicates that the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: not definitely decided to abandon the

Speaker: NA
Text: policy that lias been announced. I f it

Speaker: NA
Text: be merely a matter, of the validity of the

Speaker: NA
Text: regulation, the Minister will have time

Speaker: NA
Text: for a little more reflection on the wisdom

Speaker: NA
Text: of the policy itself. I desire to make a

Speaker: NA
Text: few comments which may assist him to

Speaker: NA
Text: reach what I regard as a sound decision

Speaker: NA
Text: in the matter. .Should he proceed with

Speaker: NA
Text: the policy that he has announced, and

Speaker: NA
Text: should the legality of the regulation be

Speaker: NA
Text: confirmed, the Minister will have com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitted a grave administrative and psycho-

Speaker: NA
Text: logical blunder. As to the merits of the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal as a means of helping the war

Speaker: NA
Text: effort, I direct his attention to figures,

Speaker: NA
Text: which I understand came from the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Statistician, showing that the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of domestic servants, or persons

Speaker: NA
Text: classified under that heading, declined

Speaker: NA
Text: from about 120,000 in July, 1941, to

Speaker: NA
Text: about 90.000 in June or July of this year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since those latest figures were made

Speaker: NA
Text: available, several more months have

Speaker: NA
Text: elapsed and, thanks to the operations of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Women's Employment Board, the

Speaker: NA
Text: inducements for women to engage in

Speaker: NA
Text: other forms of industry have been made

Speaker: NA
Text: more attractive. I should be astonished

Speaker: NA
Text: if the total of 90,000 had not been

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced by at least another 20,000 since

Speaker: NA
Text: July of this year. Of the remainder, a

Speaker: NA
Text: considerable proportion would represent

Speaker: NA
Text: one domestic to the household, many

Speaker: NA
Text: of them being elderly persons who

Speaker: NA
Text: have been associated for many years

Speaker: NA
Text: with the family which employs them. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: my opinion there would be very little

Speaker: NA
Text: material of value to the war effort remain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in that class. Although it may be

Speaker: NA
Text: true that some persons in the community

Speaker: NA
Text: have unnecessarily, and for their own

Speaker: NA
Text: selfish ends, made use of domestic help,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister will find, on examination,

Speaker: NA
Text: that a great majority of the persons en-

Speaker: NA
Text: gaged in this way are helping large

Speaker: NA
Text: families, or invalid or elderly persons,

Speaker: NA
Text: who would not be able to look after them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves in a satisfactory manner. I

Speaker: NA
Text: assure the Minister that his announce-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of policy has created con-

Speaker: NA
Text: s re rn a tion and dismay, not only among

Speaker: NA
Text: those who employ domestic help, but also

Speaker: NA
Text: ques- among the people who are employed in

Speaker: NA
Text: this way and find their lives so violently

Speaker: NA
Text: shaken out of their normal routine. I

Speaker: NA
Text: know that that is happening to a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: people in war-time, and that it will

Speaker: NA
Text: happen to a great many more, but i f the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister requires more female labour for

Speaker: NA
Text: the war effort it is not right to select one

Speaker: NA
Text: particular class of females and impose

Speaker: NA
Text: conscription on them. By that act he

Speaker: NA
Text: cuts across the principle of fairness as we

Speaker: NA
Text: in this country understand it. Why

Speaker: NA
Text: should a woman whom circumstances

Speaker: NA
Text: have placed in domestic employment be

Speaker: NA
Text: put in a category of her own and sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: jected to a degree of conscription which

Speaker: NA
Text: women in other walks of life are not

Speaker: NA
Text: called upon to accept? The conscription

Speaker: NA
Text: of a particular class is a process which

Speaker: NA
Text: is new to this country and is certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: based on inequity. Before the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: makes a definite decision in regard to this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter I ask him to answer the following

Speaker: NA
Text: questions: What number of persons does

Speaker: NA
Text: he hope to secure for war.work through

Speaker: NA
Text: the policy of restricting domestic service?

Speaker: NA
Text: What is his estimate of the average

Speaker: NA
Text: age of these persons ? How many inspec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors does he think will be necessary to

Speaker: NA
Text: police the regulations which will have to

Speaker: NA
Text: be issued? Obviously, unless he is to

Speaker: NA
Text: rely upon the law-abiding sense of the

Speaker: NA
Text: community, there will have to be some

Speaker: NA
Text: investigation of the domestic needs of

Speaker: NA
Text: the families affected, and on that assump-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion inspectors will be necessary. Are

Speaker: NA
Text: they to go into Australian homes in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to find out how many hours the

Speaker: NA
Text: housemaid or the nursegirl or other do-

Speaker: NA
Text: mestic help works each day? I f that is

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister's intention, the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia ought to be told so. Finally,

Speaker: NA
Text: may I suggest to the Minister that

Speaker: NA
Text: his itch to interfere with the lives of

Speaker: NA
Text: the people has reached its zenith, or its

Speaker: NA
Text: nadir-dependin g upon the way we look

Speaker: NA
Text: at it-i n this proposal. He will commit

Speaker: NA
Text: a psychological blunder of the first order

Speaker: NA
Text: if he persists with it.

Speaker: NA
Text: sire to associate myself with those who

Speaker: NA
Text: have protested against the action of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Broadcasting Commission in

Speaker: NA
Text: banning the "Pleasant Sunday After-

Speaker: NA
Text: noon" broadcast from "Wesley Church,

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne. I t is true that i f the script

Speaker: NA
Text: of the proposed talk is in the hands of the

Speaker: NA
Text: commission 23 days before the proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: date of the broadcast, the commission may

Speaker: NA
Text: give permission for the broadcast to takt

Speaker: NA
Text: place. Of course, that is an impossible

Speaker: NA
Text: condition in these days of rapid transport.

Speaker: NA
Text: A man who might have been in America

Speaker: NA
Text: 23 days before would, perhaps, be a desir-

Speaker: NA
Text: able speaker, but unless he sent

Speaker: NA
Text: out before him it would be impossible for

Speaker: NA
Text: him to comply with the conditions laid

Speaker: NA
Text: down by the commission. Perhaps I

Speaker: NA
Text: have a personal reason for protesting,

Speaker: NA
Text: because I happen to have been the first

Speaker: NA
Text: person to whom the ban was applied. I

Speaker: NA
Text: spoke in Wesley Church last Sunday

Speaker: NA
Text: week. My script was in the hands of

Speaker: NA
Text: the commission's representatives in Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: toria about eight days before the talk

Speaker: NA
Text: was given, but that did not satisfy the

Speaker: NA
Text: commission. I t did not matter much to

Speaker: NA
Text: me, because what I had to say was broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: cast from station 3DB, and I have had an

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to judge how widely these

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasts are listened to by the people

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. I have received many letters

Speaker: NA
Text: from listeners, and others have ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proached me and told me that they lis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tened to the broadcast. Some of the let-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters were from Tasmania, which indicates

Speaker: NA
Text: that this is not a purely Victorian issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: The " Pleasant Sunday Afternoons" at

Speaker: NA
Text: Wesley Church have become a feature

Speaker: NA
Text: over a long period of years. I attended

Speaker: NA
Text: the public meeting in Melbourne which

Speaker: NA
Text: was called as a protest against the action

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian Broadcasting Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion in restricting the broadcasts. I

Speaker: NA
Text: wanted to hear what was said, and to

Speaker: NA
Text: judge for myself how much interest was

Speaker: NA
Text: taken in the matter. I reached the Town

Speaker: NA
Text: Hall about 7.55 p.m. and found, to my

Speaker: NA
Text: amazement, that the hall was full.

Speaker: NA
Text: People were then being directed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: choir gallery, and I obtained a place at

Speaker: NA
Text: the back of the stage. Afterwards, I

Speaker: NA
Text: was told that hundreds were turned away.

Speaker: NA
Text: That meeting was organized in a period

Speaker: NA
Text: of about fourteen days, and the attend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance showed clearly the great public in-

Speaker: NA
Text: terest taken in Melbourne in the subject.

Speaker: NA
Text: A collection was taken up and £106 was

Speaker: NA
Text: received from those present, which showed

Speaker: NA
Text: that, not only were the people interested,

Speaker: NA
Text: but also that they were prepared to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tribute to the expenses of organizing

Speaker: NA
Text: a protest. 1 do not subscribe to all the

Speaker: NA
Text: arguments used by speakers at the meet-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, but I believe that a protest was jus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tified. The Australian Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission was, in my opinion, badly

Speaker: NA
Text: advised. Its action was clumsy, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons given in letters to the press over

Speaker: NA
Text: the signatures of Mr Cleary and Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bearup were not convincing. One such

Speaker: NA
Text: his script letter was as follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commission has come to the conclusion

Speaker: NA
Text: that an arrangement such as that for the

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasting of Pleasant Sunday Afternoon

Speaker: NA
Text: services, involving regular programming over

Speaker: NA
Text: a long period of years, is not only an abdica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion from its responsibility for selecting its

Speaker: NA
Text: programme material and speakers, but is also

Speaker: NA
Text: calculated, as experience with you has shown,

Speaker: NA
Text: to set up in the mind of the person arranging

Speaker: NA
Text: the programme a vested interest so firmly en-

Speaker: NA
Text: trenched that any attempt to interfere with it

Speaker: NA
Text: may expose the Commission to a public charge

Speaker: NA
Text: of breach of faith or interference with the

Speaker: NA
Text: freedom of speech.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f that is the premise on which the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission's argument was based, then why

Speaker: NA
Text: of do we have race broadcasts every after-

Speaker: NA
Text: noon that race meetings are held?

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Broadcasting Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasts football matches throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: the season. I have no objection to

Speaker: NA
Text: the broadcasting of races, or football

Speaker: NA
Text: matches, or of any other event, sporting

Speaker: NA
Text: or otherwise, which is of public interest.

Speaker: NA
Text: A national programme must include

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasts of that kind. However, on

Speaker: NA
Text: Sunday, at least, and at the particular

Speaker: NA
Text: time of the day involved, I do not know

Speaker: NA
Text: of any subject which is of greater interest

Speaker: NA
Text: to listeners than this particular session.

Speaker: NA
Text: I should say that in popularity it ranks

Speaker: NA
Text: next to broadcasts of races and news. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is useless for the commission to say that

Speaker: NA
Text: it must retain control over this broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: cast when it knows that should it

Speaker: NA
Text: cease race broadcasts a public outcry

Speaker: NA
Text: would result. "Why, therefore, should not

Speaker: NA
Text: the commission study the desires of those

Speaker: NA
Text: listeners who are interested in this class

Speaker: NA
Text: of broadcast on Sunday? It is not a

Speaker: NA
Text: religious service. To some degree it may

Speaker: NA
Text: have a religious flavour. In any case, if

Speaker: NA
Text: it be welcomed by the public it should be

Speaker: NA
Text: continued. This broadcast is listened to

Speaker: NA
Text: by people throughout Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Fawkner ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Holt) has suggested that this is a matter

Speaker: NA
Text: which might be referred to tbe Broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casting Committee for inquiry. Tbat is

Speaker: NA
Text: a good idea ; if the commission is not

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to restore the broadcast without

Speaker: NA
Text: such an inquiry I believe that the

Speaker: NA
Text: commission will see the wisdom

Speaker: NA
Text: and fairness of doing so.

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, the Broadcasting Committee cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: deal with this n.atter unless it be referred

Speaker: NA
Text: to it by either the Minister or the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission. If the commission is not pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to admit that it has made a mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: take, and has committed a breach of faith

Speaker: NA
Text: with a large section of the public, whom

Speaker: NA
Text: it has deprived of a service that is useful

Speaker: NA
Text: and educational, some action should be

Speaker: NA
Text: taken by Parliament to force the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission to do justice in this matter. I

Speaker: NA
Text: feel very strongly on the subject. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not wish to say too much about it at this

Speaker: NA
Text: juncture, because I am hopeful that the

Speaker: NA
Text: commission will do the right thing. If it

Speaker: NA
Text: can be shown that great interest exists

Speaker: NA
Text: in the broadcast, and that it supplies a

Speaker: NA
Text: substantial public demand, the commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion should reverse its decision and re-

Speaker: NA
Text: store the broadcast. The commission can

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that the script shall be in the hands

Speaker: NA
Text: of its representative within a reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: time to permit of its being examined in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to see that it complies with the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission's requirements. I have discussed

Speaker: NA
Text: this subject with representatives of Wes-

Speaker: NA
Text: ley Church. They have assured me that

Speaker: NA
Text: au arrangement has been operating, and

Speaker: NA
Text: can be continued, whereby the script of

Speaker: NA
Text: the broadcast can be made available to a

Speaker: NA
Text: representative of the commission in tbat

Speaker: NA
Text: way. However, the contention that tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: script must be in the hands' of tbe com-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Barnard.

Speaker: NA
Text: mission 23 days in advance of the actual

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcast is nonsense. I n respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: many broadcasts which take place very

Speaker: NA
Text: frequently, it is impossible for the script

Speaker: NA
Text: to be made available to the commission

Speaker: NA
Text: even three days in advance of the actual

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcast. I join with other honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members who have protested against the

Speaker: NA
Text: action of the commission. I sincerely

Speaker: NA
Text: trust that wisdom and common sense will

Speaker: NA
Text: prevail in the matter, and that this public

Speaker: NA
Text: service will be restored.

Speaker: Mr MENZIES
Text: Kooyong) [11.6] - I

Speaker: NA
Text: The associate myself very warmly witb the

Speaker: NA
Text: protest which has been made about this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter, and I venture to hope that Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters, when they look at it, will come to the

Speaker: NA
Text: conclusion that a very great mistake bas

Speaker: NA
Text: pre- been made. I t is quite absurd for any

Speaker: NA
Text: one to suggest that the broadcasting of the

Speaker: NA
Text: " Pleasant Sunday Afternoon" session

Speaker: NA
Text: from Wesley Church is the broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: How- of something that is either sectarian or

Speaker: NA
Text: party. I t is very well known to all hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: orable members that people of every

Speaker: NA
Text: political colour have spoken there.

Speaker: NA
Text: Several members of the present Cabinet,

Speaker: NA
Text: as well as members of my own Cabinet,

Speaker: NA
Text: including myself, have spoken at what is,

Speaker: NA
Text: in reality, a very popular public forum

Speaker: NA
Text: on which non-political matters of im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portance can be discussed by public men.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, distinguished men from other

Speaker: NA
Text: countries have contributed to these

Speaker: NA
Text: programmes. As I see the correspond-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence in respect ot this matter, it is un-

Speaker: NA
Text: fortunate that the commission should

Speaker: NA
Text: have decided to impose this ban just after

Speaker: NA
Text: some slight controversy had occurred

Speaker: NA
Text: between the commission and Dr Irving

Speaker: NA
Text: Benson, who presides over Wesley Church

Speaker: NA
Text: in Melbourne.

Speaker: Sir FREDERICK STEWART
Text: I t is not

Speaker: NA
Text: only unfortunate,'but also significant.

Speaker: Mr MENZIES
Text: I t is unfortunate

Speaker: NA
Text: because it creates in the ordinary mind

Speaker: NA
Text: the impression that this ban arises from

Speaker: NA
Text: causes which find their roots in some

Speaker: NA
Text: resentment in the minds of the commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion. I n the course of a letter which

Speaker: NA
Text: the chairman of tbe commission wrote on

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter, he offered as his reason for

Speaker: NA
Text: the ban the view that the commission

Speaker: NA
Text: could not permit one denomination, or

Speaker: NA
Text: one church, or one institution, to secure

Speaker: NA
Text: a monopoly of the air. Tbat, I submit,

Speaker: NA
Text: ia a perfectly fatuous answer to the criti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cism of the commission. The chairman

Speaker: NA
Text: of the commission talks about a vested

Speaker: NA
Text: interest which he thought was being

Speaker: NA
Text: created by Dr Benson. Nothing more

Speaker: NA
Text: absurd could be imagined. There is no

Speaker: NA
Text: vested interest in Dr Benson, and no

Speaker: NA
Text: vested interest in "Wesley Church. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is only one vested interest, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: is in the listening public of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. I t is that vested interest to

Speaker: NA
Text: which the commission should direct its

Speaker: NA
Text: attention. For about eight or ten years,

Speaker: NA
Text: many honorable members have been in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vited, as I bave, once a year to be ,a

Speaker: NA
Text: speaker at that forum; and wherever I

Speaker: NA
Text: have gone, certainly in Victoria, and to a

Speaker: NA
Text: large degree i n Tasmania, I have spoken

Speaker: NA
Text: to a great many people who have said to

Speaker: NA
Text: me, " I have never met you before, but

Speaker: NA
Text: have beard you from Wesley". This is

Speaker: NA
Text: a great national broadcast in south-

Speaker: NA
Text: eastern Australia, and the people who

Speaker: NA
Text: listen to it, and pay their fees, have a

Speaker: NA
Text: vested interest in it. For that to be

Speaker: NA
Text: twisted round and presented as a vested

Speaker: NA
Text: interest represented by some gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: who presides over Wesley Church is

Speaker: NA
Text: absurd. With great sincerity I urge

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers to look at this matter,

Speaker: NA
Text: because they will find a very widespread

Speaker: NA
Text: feeling of resentment about what is

Speaker: NA
Text: regarded as an entirely unnecessary and

Speaker: NA
Text: officious act. And I suggest tbat when

Speaker: NA
Text: they bave had a look at it, they should

Speaker: NA
Text: use the influence they possess-an d I

Speaker: NA
Text: imagine i t is not small-wit h the Broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casting Commission to get it back on to

Speaker: NA
Text: sound ground. The national stations for

Speaker: NA
Text: which the people of Australia pay, and

Speaker: NA
Text: in which they bave a real interest

Speaker: NA
Text: should not hand over this programme,

Speaker: NA
Text: which has been a well recognized national

Speaker: NA
Text: feature for very many years, to some

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial station. On the face of

Speaker: NA
Text: it the proposal is absurd. No answer

Speaker: NA
Text: has been made in this case by the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission which would satisfy a child and,

Speaker: NA
Text: unless the commission is able to put for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward some answer which will satisfy, not

Speaker: NA
Text: only a child, but also a grown-up person,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government should itself talk to the

Speaker: NA
Text: commission and see that the right thing

Speaker: NA
Text: is done.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mx. POLLARD (Ballarat) [11.11] -

Speaker: NA
Text: support the request tbat consideration be

Speaker: NA
Text: given to tbe restoration to tbe pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: grammes of tbe Australian Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission of the " Pleasant Sunday

Speaker: NA
Text: Afternoon" from Wesley Church,

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne, from which I and other mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of the community have derived a

Speaker: NA
Text: great deal of pleasure over tbe years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since I have been a member of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament I have not had one letter of

Speaker: NA
Text: objection or heard one word of objection

Speaker: NA
Text: to the broadcasting of this programme.

Speaker: NA
Text: I disagree with the right honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Kooynong ( Mr Menzies) in one

Speaker: NA
Text: respect. I read with great thoroughness

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe letters exchanged between the chair-

Speaker: NA
Text: man of the Australian Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission ( Mr Cleary) and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Reverend Irving Benson regarding

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter, and I think that on logical

Speaker: NA
Text: reasoning Mr Cleary won on points.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nevertheless I do not consider that he

Speaker: NA
Text: gave sufficient reason why these broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casts should cease. I have listened to the

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorable member for Kooyong an-i

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Corio ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dedman) broadcasting in the "Pleasant

Speaker: NA
Text: Sunday Afternoon" programmes, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I quite conceive that a bigoted member

Speaker: NA
Text: of either political party could legitimately

Speaker: NA
Text: take exception to the views expressed by

Speaker: NA
Text: either of those gentlemen inasmuch as the

Speaker: NA
Text: material each broadcast was subtle pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: paganda for his political and economic

Speaker: NA
Text: view's. I do not think that tbat can be

Speaker: NA
Text: disputed. But the fact remains that 1

Speaker: NA
Text: know of no member of either party or of

Speaker: NA
Text: the listening public at large having raised

Speaker: NA
Text: any such objection. All this trouble has

Speaker: NA
Text: taken place because of what I considered

Speaker: NA
Text: to be a most excellent address by Pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: fessor Woodruff, on the liquor question.

Speaker: NA
Text: I concede, however, the right of the

Speaker: NA
Text: people who have vested interests in the

Speaker: NA
Text: liquor trade to object to such a broadcast

Speaker: NA
Text: being made without their being afforded

Speaker: NA
Text: the same facility to broadcast their view.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is unfortunate that the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Parramatta ( Sir Frederick

Speaker: NA
Text: Stewart) should impute motives to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Broadcasting Commission.

Speaker: Sir FREDERICK STEWART
Text: I imputed

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing; I definitely alleged it.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: that kind prejudice the case of those tike

Speaker: NA
Text: I myself who realize the propriety of the

Speaker: NA
Text: liquor trade's objection to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Broadcasting Commission being used to

Speaker: NA
Text: present only one side of tbe argument. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: is most unfortunate that the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member should have even imputed that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Broadcasting Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: has a bias towards the liquor trade. I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not know whether i t has or not, I

Speaker: NA
Text: hope it bas not. Mr Cleary, Mrs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ernestine Hill and Professor Medlow,

Speaker: NA
Text: who are members of the commission, are

Speaker: NA
Text: admirable citizens. Is it to be said that,

Speaker: NA
Text: they have a leaning towards the vested

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of the liquor trade? I sin-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerely hope not. I refuse to accept the

Speaker: NA
Text: suggestion that they have. Another un-

Speaker: NA
Text: fortunate matter is that the continuation

Speaker: NA
Text: of those broadcasts may have been further

Speaker: NA
Text: prejudiced by the implication in the

Speaker: NA
Text: utterances of no less a person tban the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: Moderator General of the Presbyterian

Speaker: NA
Text: Church, Dr Button, that some one of

Speaker: NA
Text: high authority on the Broadcasting Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission was actuated by ulterior motives.

Speaker: NA
Text: I say that with emphasis, notwith-

Speaker: NA
Text: standing that I am a member of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Presbyterian church, perhaps not a

Speaker: NA
Text: very good one. That sort of thing pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: judices the case of decent people who want

Speaker: NA
Text: to have the " Pleasant Sunday After-

Speaker: NA
Text: noon" broadcast restored to the commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion's programme, on its merits, but do

Speaker: NA
Text: not in any way impute motives. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: a public demand for these broadcasts

Speaker: NA
Text: which have made for the entertainment

Speaker: NA
Text: and education of the people of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: for a number of years. I t should be

Speaker: NA
Text: possible to devise means whereby a

Speaker: NA
Text: repetition of the unfortunate incident

Speaker: NA
Text: which brought them to an end could be

Speaker: NA
Text: avoided.

Speaker: NA
Text: direct the attention of the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Commerce ( Mr Scully) to a matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: major importance to Western Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I desire to know whether supplies of

Speaker: NA
Text: superphosphate should be carted to the

Speaker: NA
Text: farms while 'the wheat is being carted to

Speaker: NA
Text: the sidings. Under what conditions is the

Speaker: NA
Text: rationing of superphosphates occurring in

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia? Under what condi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions will the cropping of wheat be

Speaker: NA
Text: allowed to continue next year? Will i t be

Speaker: NA
Text: on the basis of the reduction of 33^ per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, that applies this year, or will it be

Speaker: NA
Text: on norma] licences-o n a basis similar to

Speaker: NA
Text: that on which every other wheat-grower

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia is operating? This matter

Speaker: NA
Text: needs clarifying at once because the

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat is being carted to the country sid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings at present and, as you know Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, i t is of paramount importance,

Speaker: NA
Text: in order to conserve petrol, rubber and

Speaker: NA
Text: man-power, that superphosphate should

Speaker: NA
Text: be taken to the farm as back-

Speaker: NA
Text: loading while carting of wheat is

Speaker: NA
Text: in progress. The wheat-growers of

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia are in a quandary

Speaker: NA
Text: as to the conditions under which they will

Speaker: NA
Text: be required to crop in the coming year,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I sincerely hope that tbe Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Commerce will take this opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: clarify their position. I f they are to be

Speaker: NA
Text: subjected to a reduction of 33-J per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: next year, I remind the Minister that

Speaker: NA
Text: tlie Western Australian farmers suffered

Speaker: NA
Text: that reduction this year, and there-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore lost, the beneficial effects of

Speaker: NA
Text: superphosphate on their land. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not desire to see tbat condition imposed

Speaker: NA
Text: in the coming year. I know that a cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain amount of rationing of superphos-

Speaker: NA
Text: phate is taking place, but I do not know

Speaker: NA
Text: on what basis the allocations are

Speaker: NA
Text: arrived at, and I should like the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: to clear the matter up 'this evening, if

Speaker: NA
Text: possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr LA2TGTRY (Riverina) [11.21] -

Speaker: NA
Text: I t was reported in the press a few days

Speaker: NA
Text: ago that the standard of f.a.q. wheat was

Speaker: NA
Text: fixed at 59 lb. to the bushel, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat weighing 58 lb. was docked 3d. a

Speaker: NA
Text: bushel. That amount of dockage is out

Speaker: NA
Text: of all proportion to the discrepancy. 1

Speaker: NA
Text: do not think there should be any dockage

Speaker: NA
Text: at 58 lb., or even 57 lb., because the loss

Speaker: NA
Text: of flour content is so slight as to be

Speaker: NA
Text: impossible to work out. The unfairness

Speaker: NA
Text: of the deduction should be brought imme-

Speaker: NA
Text: diately before the Wheat Board. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: could be started at i d . or i d . , and be

Speaker: NA
Text: increased as the weight goes down to 55

Speaker: NA
Text: lb. or 54 lb., which is well below stan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dard. Another important matter is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the farmer should be allowed to average

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole of his deliveries of wheat so

Speaker: NA
Text: far as the standard is concerned. I f he

Speaker: NA
Text: sends in 1,000 bags, of which 500 go 62

Speaker: NA
Text: or 63 lb. to the bushel, while the standard

Speaker: NA
Text: is fixed at 59 lb. to the bushel, he gets

Speaker: NA
Text: no premium whatever on it. I f his other

Speaker: NA
Text: 500 bags go under 59 lb., he is docked.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is unfair, because with 500 bags

Speaker: NA
Text: weighing 61 lb. to the bushel, and another

Speaker: NA
Text: 500 bags weighing 57 lb. to the bushel,

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole of his 1,000 bags averages stan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dard weight. The wheat is mixed up at

Speaker: NA
Text: the silo or i n the mill, and if he sends

Speaker: NA
Text: in wheat which averages 59 lb. to the

Speaker: NA
Text: bushel, he is entitled to the standard

Speaker: NA
Text: price for the whole of his delivery.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another injustice to the wheat-grower

Speaker: NA
Text: in every State is that he has to pay 3d.

Speaker: NA
Text: a ton for weighing on the weighbridge

Speaker: NA
Text: in addition to paying freight to the Rail-

Speaker: NA
Text: way Department, and in that way is pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing for the weighbridge two or three

Speaker: NA
Text: times over every year. No charge is made

Speaker: NA
Text: for weighing a load of wood or chaff,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the wheat-grower is harshly treated

Speaker: NA
Text: in having to pay this extra charge on

Speaker: NA
Text: every ton he puts over the weighbridge.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my town it runs to from £1,000 to

Speaker: NA
Text: £1,200 in a good year. The cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: weighing should be borne by the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Government which acquires

Speaker: NA
Text: the wheat, or by the State Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: which owns the railways and receives the

Speaker: NA
Text: freight, and not by the individual

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers. I hope the Minister will take

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter up with the Wheat Board, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Railway Commissioners or the State

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers for Agriculture, and do his

Speaker: NA
Text: best to have the charge for weighing

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat abolished. The three matters that

Speaker: NA
Text: I have mentioned should be at once

Speaker: NA
Text: attended to, and relief given to the

Speaker: NA
Text: farmer, who, in existing circumstances, is

Speaker: NA
Text: carrying the baby all the time.

Speaker: Mr HUTCHINSON
Text: Deakin) [11.25].

Speaker: NA
Text: - I support the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: Flinders ( Mr Ryan) and others who

Speaker: NA
Text: have appealed for the reconsideration

Speaker: NA
Text: rhe ban on the Wesley " Pleasant Sunday

Speaker: NA
Text: Afternoon " broadcasts. They have been

Speaker: NA
Text: the means for many years of allowing

Speaker: NA
Text: public to hear interesting speakers on

Speaker: NA
Text: sorts of subjects, and i t is safe to say

Speaker: NA
Text: many of the finest speeches made i n Austhat

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia have gone over to listeners from

Speaker: NA
Text: Wesley Church on Sunday afternoons.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not believe that any particular

Speaker: NA
Text: denomination should have a complete

Speaker: NA
Text: monopoly of broadcasts of this kind,

Speaker: NA
Text: I am sure that no one would claim it,

Speaker: NA
Text: because, obviously, any organization

Speaker: NA
Text: or section which had a monopoly

Speaker: NA
Text: of the air every Sunday would obtain

Speaker: NA
Text: certain definite advantages. I f requests

Speaker: NA
Text: have been made for broadcasts of equal

Speaker: NA
Text: importance on Sunday afternoons by

Speaker: NA
Text: other churches, they have every right to

Speaker: NA
Text: be considered by the commission. Tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: popularity of the Wesley Church broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casts shows that there is room every

Speaker: NA
Text: week for a pleasant Sunday afternoon

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcast of tbat kind. Whilst I would

Speaker: NA
Text: deny to any one church a monopoly of

Speaker: NA
