Text: this service, I have not heard of any

Speaker: NA
Text: request having been made by any other

Speaker: NA
Text: denomination to broadcast addresses of

Speaker: NA
Text: the kind that have come from Wesley

Speaker: NA
Text: Church. I have not heard in the course

Speaker: NA
Text: of years a complaint from any person, no

Speaker: NA
Text: matter what his politics or denomina-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, about the broadcasting, Sunday after

Speaker: NA
Text: Sunday, of the Wesley Church service.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Broadcasting Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: must definitely safeguard the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people from any organization, sect or sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion which would seek at any time

Speaker: NA
Text: to use the national stations for any

Speaker: NA
Text: form of propaganda aimed at advancing

Speaker: NA
Text: its own ends. I have not sufficient evi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence before me to form an opinion

Speaker: NA
Text: regarding the charge that that was

Speaker: NA
Text: attempted by Wesley Church. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: looked at the address which was the

Speaker: NA
Text: cause of all the trouble, but I am not

Speaker: NA
Text: aware of what took place previously.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am, therefore, not going to voice an

Speaker: NA
Text: opinion on something about which I know

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing. Even i f it were thought that

Speaker: NA
Text: similar views on the one subject were

Speaker: NA
Text: being broadcast too often from any par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular forum, surely it was a matter for

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiation in a gentlemanly way between

Speaker: NA
Text: for the commission and the church or

Speaker: NA
Text: organization concerned. Certainly there

Speaker: NA
Text: of was no need for so drastic a step as the

Speaker: NA
Text: banning of these broadcasts. The con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditions imposed to-day are so onerous as

Speaker: NA
Text: the to be tantamount to a complete banning

Speaker: NA
Text: all of the broadcasting of Wesley Church

Speaker: NA
Text: that " Pleasant Sunday Afternoons ". I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: further consideration will be given

Speaker: NA
Text: to the matter, and that before long we

Speaker: NA
Text: shall once again hear coming over the

Speaker: NA
Text: ether on Sunday afternoons, the enter-

Speaker: NA
Text: taining and very enlightening speeches to

Speaker: NA
Text: and which we have been accustomed.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish to bring to the attention of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government a matter affecting the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of the Interior. Land ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: quired for military or other purposes by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government is eventually settled for

Speaker: NA
Text: by that department. I receive repeated

Speaker: NA
Text: complaints about tbe slowness of the

Speaker: NA
Text: department in settling for lands so

Speaker: NA
Text: acquired. I am told that often delays

Speaker: NA
Text: occur owing to disputes between the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and tbe parties concerned,

Speaker: NA
Text: but in other cases, where there is no

Speaker: NA
Text: dispute whatever and the valuation of tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: land is accepted by the individual

Speaker: NA
Text: interested, payment for the land is de-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred for months. I n many instances

Speaker: NA
Text: the person whose property has been

Speaker: NA
Text: acquired has been forced to wait-

Speaker: NA
Text: months for a settlement and bas

Speaker: NA
Text: been compensated by a payment at tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: rate of only 3 per cent, per annum on the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount outstanding. This causes grave

Speaker: NA
Text: injustices. Properties are often mort-

Speaker: NA
Text: gaged and the mortgagee has to pay 5 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, or 5$ per cent, on his overdraft.

Speaker: NA
Text: Obviously if he receives only 3 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Government he is placed in a

Speaker: NA
Text: most unfair position. I therefore ask that

Speaker: NA
Text: steps be taken to ensure prompt settle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments and the payment of a more equit-

Speaker: NA
Text: able interest rate on outstanding amounts

Speaker: NA
Text: pending settlements.

Speaker: Mr COLES
Text: Henty) [11.32] - I asso-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciate myself strongly with the protest

Speaker: NA
Text: made by the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Flinders ( Mr Ryan) against the ban-

Speaker: NA
Text: ning by the Australian Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission of the " Pleasant Sunday

Speaker: NA
Text: Afternoon" broadcasts from "Wesley

Speaker: NA
Text: Church, Melbourne. I know of nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: that has happened recently in broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casting that has caused such widespread

Speaker: NA
Text: dissatisfaction among listeners. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: frequently listened to the "Pleasant

Speaker: NA
Text: Sunday Afternoon" broadcasts.

Speaker: NA
Text: have found them to be undenomina-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional and unsectarian. Subjects of

Speaker: NA
Text: all descriptions have been discussed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: various speakers and, in general, the

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasts have created great interest

Speaker: NA
Text: over a long period-. of years. Many

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of people throughout Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: have devoted their Sunday afternoons to

Speaker: NA
Text: listening to these broadcasts and they

Speaker: NA
Text: strongly resent what they regard as the

Speaker: NA
Text: unjustified discontinuance of them. The

Speaker: NA
Text: decision to ban tbe broadcasts appears

Speaker: NA
Text: to me to be thoroughly bad. I t seems

Speaker: NA
Text: that an official, or several officials, have

Speaker: NA
Text: attempted to. bolster up their authority

Speaker: NA
Text: and to exercise their prerogative to

Speaker: NA
Text: decide whatshall and what shall

Speaker: NA
Text: not be put on the air. I do not know

Speaker: NA
Text: what influence the Government can exert

Speaker: NA
Text: in the matter, but I hope that the fullest

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry will be made to ascertain why

Speaker: NA
Text: the broadcasts have been discontinued and

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure that they are restored as soon

Speaker: NA
Text: as possible. The broadcasts were of a

Speaker: NA
Text: high educational and entertainment

Speaker: NA
Text: value. Invariably the speakers put their

Speaker: NA
Text: case with cogency and effect. The fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that the " Pleasant Sunday Afternoon "

Speaker: NA
Text: entertainment is now being broadcast

Speaker: NA
Text: every Sunday afternoon by station 3DB

Speaker: NA
Text: fortifies my view that the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Broadcasting Commission made

Speaker: NA
Text: a thoroughly bad decision in ban-

Speaker: NA
Text: ning it. I t is unlikely that a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mercial station would broadcast the ses-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion i f it were not of a high value. Surely

Speaker: NA
Text: the people who pay their licence-fees to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Broadcasting Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion are entitled to some consideration.

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope that the Government will review

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole matter and take steps to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that listeners are provided with the

Speaker: NA
Text: programmes which they desire.

Speaker: NA
Text: I bring to the notice of the Minister of

Speaker: NA
Text: Commerce ( Mr Scully) certain factors

Speaker: NA
Text: associated with the discontinuance of the

Speaker: NA
Text: apple and pear acquisition scheme in Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: toria to which immediate attention should

Speaker: NA
Text: be given. There are some loose threads

Speaker: NA
Text: that need to be tied. The acquisition

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme has been in operation for about

Speaker: NA
Text: three years, during which period the

Speaker: NA
Text: orchardists have lost contact with the

Speaker: NA
Text: marketing facilities they formerly used.

Speaker: NA
Text: I understand that instructions have been

Speaker: NA
Text: given to the board that growers of apples

Speaker: NA
Text: I and pears in Victoria shall be provided

Speaker: NA
Text: with cases for the marketing of this year's

Speaker: NA
Text: crop. I f cases are not made available in

Speaker: NA
Text: this way the orchardists will .be placed in

Speaker: NA
Text: a very difficult position. I hope, too, that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister will give instructions that

Speaker: NA
Text: transport facilities, with appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: priorities, shall be provided. This is an

Speaker: NA
Text: urgent matter for the fruit will be coming

Speaker: NA
Text: on the market almost at once. I ask,

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore, that immediate attention be

Speaker: NA
Text: given to it.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: support the protest of the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Flinders ( Mr Ryan) against the

Speaker: NA
Text: banning of the " Pleasant Sunday After-

Speaker: NA
Text: noon " broadcasts from Wesley Church,

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne. I do not think it can be said

Speaker: NA
Text: that the morals of any citizen in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia have been prejudicially affected by

Speaker: NA
Text: these broadcasts. No complaints have

Speaker: NA
Text: been made against them. Some objection

Speaker: NA
Text: may have been taken to recent broadcasts

Speaker: NA
Text: on the liquor question, but these do not

Speaker: NA
Text: justify the banning of the broadcasts.

Speaker: NA
Text: The forum provided at Wesley Church

Speaker: NA
Text: on Sunday afternoons has been used by

Speaker: NA
Text: many distinguished visitors to Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The broadcasts are enjoyed by listeners

Speaker: NA
Text: all over the continent. I n Western Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia we frequently listen to them. I

Speaker: NA
Text: regard it as effrontery by the officials of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Broadcasting Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: to have banned this broadcast.

Speaker: NA
Text: I call the attention of the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Commerce ( Mr Scully) to certain un-

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfactory features associated with the

Speaker: NA
Text: shortage of potatoes in Australia and the

Speaker: NA
Text: steps taken to increase the supply. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government bas urged growers to do

Speaker: NA
Text: their best to increase their production so

Speaker: NA
Text: that ample supplies may be available for

Speaker: NA
Text: both the armed forces and the civil popu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation. Potato-growers from Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia were assured that contracts

Speaker: NA
Text: would be arranged, but when they tried

Speaker: NA
Text: to buy potato fertilizer they found i t was

Speaker: NA
Text: in short supply. This also has caused

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulty. The potato-growers of Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia were assured that they would

Speaker: NA
Text: receive a minimum of £8 10s. a ton for

Speaker: NA
Text: grade potatoes at railway sidings.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t has now been rumoured that the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trol of the potato industry is to cease, as

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government now finds the supply

Speaker: NA
Text: ample, and that only those who signed

Speaker: NA
Text: contracts with the Government are to be

Speaker: NA
Text: treated with. Growers in Western Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia without contracts are apparently

Speaker: NA
Text: to be thrown to the wolves, although until

Speaker: NA
Text: now they could not dispose of a potato,

Speaker: NA
Text: or even give one to their own people.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have been required to provide new

Speaker: NA
Text: bags for potatoes that are to be sold, and

Speaker: NA
Text: they have had to pay a high price for the

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary fertilizers. I have received

Speaker: NA
Text: from tbe Minister an intimation that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Potato Control Board will not cease

Speaker: NA
Text: operations, but that those who have not

Speaker: NA
Text: signed contracts will now be entitled to

Speaker: NA
Text: sell potatoes as they please or give

Speaker: NA
Text: them to their friends i f they desire

Speaker: NA
Text: to do so. The Government under-

Speaker: NA
Text: takes that i t will not use any surplus to

Speaker: NA
Text: flush the market and reduce the price

Speaker: NA
Text: below that which the Western Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: growers were assured they would receive.

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope that the Minister will remove the

Speaker: NA
Text: impression that has been gained because

Speaker: NA
Text: many growers who have not entered into

Speaker: NA
Text: contracts were urged by officials in

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia that they would

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly receive a minimum price of

Speaker: NA
Text: £8 10s, a ton i f they complied with all

Speaker: NA
Text: of the regulations of the board. The

Speaker: NA
Text: "board should therefore see that those

Speaker: NA
Text: growers who patriotically stepped into

Speaker: NA
Text: line in an effort to overcome the shortage

Speaker: NA
Text: of potatoes in Western Australia do not

Speaker: NA
Text: suffer by reason of their action.

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Text: Wimmera) [11.43] - I

Speaker: NA
Text: draw the attention of the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Army ( Mr Forde) to the efforts

Speaker: NA
Text: being made, witb little success, from time

Speaker: NA
Text: to time by persons who have ideas or

Speaker: NA
Text: patents which they think would in some

Speaker: NA
Text: way assist in the war effort. The Army

Speaker: NA
Text: Inventions Directorate seems to have a

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity for rejecting all ideas placed

Speaker: NA
Text: before it. I have noticed recently in the

Speaker: NA
Text: press that, in Germany, the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction is contemplated of a machine

Speaker: NA
Text: known as the "scythe of death"-tha t

Speaker: NA
Text: is a variation of the machine-gun prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciple employed in the form of an auto-

Speaker: NA
Text: matic traverse which traverses the fire

Speaker: NA
Text: of the gun horizontally and in various

Speaker: NA
Text: other ways, which would greatly improve

Speaker: NA
Text: the effectiveness of any machine gun or

Speaker: NA
Text: cannon. Becently, to my knowledge, an

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian who is a returned soldier

Speaker: NA
Text: from the last war, attempted to have

Speaker: NA
Text: this principle accepted by the Army I n -

Speaker: NA
Text: ventions Directorate. He was actuated

Speaker: NA
Text: only by a desire to give something to his

Speaker: NA
Text: country that would be effective in the

Speaker: NA
Text: prosecution of this war and in the defeat

Speaker: NA
Text: of the enemy; but like hundreds of others,

Speaker: NA
Text: he received a cold shoulder, and nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: was heard of his proposal. When a

Speaker: NA
Text: patent or a proposition is placed before

Speaker: NA
Text: the directorate the person who gives

Speaker: NA
Text: it is told that something will be done

Speaker: NA
Text: with it, and that he will be informed

Speaker: NA
Text: later whether it has been accepted. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: any information is asked for as to

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the invention is believed to have

Speaker: NA
Text: defects, no information is given as to

Speaker: NA
Text: what those defects may be, on the ground

Speaker: NA
Text: that that course is necessary for security

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons. We are slipping considerably in

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter. Any invention that has any

Speaker: NA
Text: possibility of success should be given a

Speaker: NA
Text: trial, and we should place at the disposal

Speaker: NA
Text: of those who are industrious enough to

Speaker: NA
Text: spend time and money in preparing

Speaker: NA
Text: models an opportunity to try them

Speaker: NA
Text: cut in a workshop. I f we got even

Speaker: NA
Text: 5 per cent, of successes, this course

Speaker: NA
Text: would be worth while. I impress

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Minister the necessity for giving

Speaker: NA
Text: some direction to this department to see

Speaker: NA
Text: that a careful scrutiny is given of all pro-'

Speaker: NA
Text: posals submitted, and that some oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity is afforded to test inventions. I

Speaker: NA
Text: know that there is a bias against new

Speaker: NA
Text: ideas because they may interfere with the

Speaker: NA
Text: production of particular lines already

Speaker: NA
Text: being made, but we must explore every

Speaker: NA
Text: avenue" i f we are to win the war as

Speaker: NA
Text: quickly as possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: I add my endorsement to what has been

Speaker: NA
Text: said to-night regarding the broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: of pleasant Sunday afternoon addresses

Speaker: NA
Text: at Wesley Church, Melbourne. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: is a popular session, and nobody

Speaker: NA
Text: is convinced ithat the reasons ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vanced by the Australian Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission for the prohibition of these

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasts are sound from a public point

Speaker: NA
Text: of view. I hope that some action will

Speaker: NA
Text: be taken quickly to restore these popular

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasts.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Melbourne) [11.48].

Speaker: NA
Text: - A big public meeting was held in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne Town Hall, presided over

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Lord Mayor of Melbourne, to

Speaker: NA
Text: protest against the action of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Broadcasting Commission in can-

Speaker: NA
Text: celling the Sunday afternoon broadcasts

Speaker: NA
Text: of addresses from - Wesley Church,

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne. Yesterday I introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: a deputation consisting of two Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne clergymen to the Postmaster-

Speaker: NA
Text: General (Senator Ashley) on this

Speaker: NA
Text: subject, and he is looking into the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter. The action of tbe commission in

Speaker: NA
Text: requiring 23 days' notice of the script to

Speaker: NA
Text: be read is unreasonable. Nobody as a

Speaker: NA
Text: regular routine could supply script at

Speaker: NA
Text: such long notice, particularly as many of

Speaker: NA
Text: the speakers are well-known public men

Speaker: NA
Text: who i n ordinary times would not be

Speaker: NA
Text: required to submit script at all. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are asked to submit it only because

Speaker: NA
Text: of tbe possibility that some of tbe matters

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned in their addresses might, for

Speaker: NA
Text: military or other reasons, be considered

Speaker: NA
Text: by the censorship authorities to be un-

Speaker: NA
Text: desirable. I believe that tbe matter is

Speaker: NA
Text: being reconsidered by the commission,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I hope that it will be favorably

Speaker: NA
Text: reconsidered. The commission has not

Speaker: NA
Text: said that these broadcasts are to be en-

Speaker: NA
Text: tirely prohibited, but i t bas laid down

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions which are onerous and in-

Speaker: NA
Text: capable of fulfilment. There is in Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne a very big body of public opinion

Speaker: NA
Text: which favours the continuation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasts. Many honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: have spoken from the platform of Wesley

Speaker: NA
Text: Church, and bave been listened to by a

Speaker: NA
Text: large audience in Melbourne and its

Speaker: NA
Text: environs. The commission is an inde-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendent body, and its independence was

Speaker: NA
Text: confirmed in the amending and consoli-

Speaker: NA
Text: dating legislation passed by this Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment early this year. The Minister has

Speaker: NA
Text: no power to direct the commission in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to its policy. Parliament, in its

Speaker: NA
Text: wisdom, considers that tbe commission

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be under parliamentary con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trol. The arguments in favour of its

Speaker: NA
Text: independence need not be recapitulated

Speaker: NA
Text: at this stage. Suffice it to say tbat in

Speaker: NA
Text: European countries in which Ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: control broadcasting instrumentalities,

Speaker: NA
Text: the party of the day has exclusive rights.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are ways in which Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters can discuss with the commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion tbe advisability of the restoration of

Speaker: NA
Text: this programme. I hope that the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission will see the wisdom of recogniz-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the strength of the case tbat bas been

Speaker: NA
Text: made out in this House to-night, and tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: volume of public feeling outside the Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other matter to which I wish to

Speaker: NA
Text: refer concerns the censorship. I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: mention several facts concerning recent

Speaker: NA
Text: articles written by Sir Keith Murdoch,

Speaker: NA
Text: who is required by a censorship order of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Victorian publicity censor under regu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation 16, sub-regulation 2B, issued under

Speaker: NA
Text: the National Security Act, to submit all

Speaker: NA
Text: his signed matter intended for publication

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Melbourne Herald. The censor who

Speaker: NA
Text: issued the instruction was Mr C. Burns.

Speaker: NA
Text: The submittal order was issued over two

Speaker: NA
Text: months ago. He bas failed, or refused, to

Speaker: NA
Text: comply with the press censorsbip

Speaker: NA
Text: authority by-

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) Publishing on the 6th October a

Speaker: NA
Text: signed article beaded " One

Speaker: NA
Text: Cause: One Army-Ne w

Speaker: NA
Text: Guinea Provides a Stern Argu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment". This article was sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitted only in part to the Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: torian publicity censor.

Speaker: NA
Text: part not submitted included

Speaker: NA
Text: references to the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Army ( Mr Forde) and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Curtin) ;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) Publishing on the 10th October,

Speaker: NA
Text: without having submitted it to

Speaker: NA
Text: censorship, a signed article

Speaker: NA
Text: headed: "Fight for the Bestr-

Speaker: NA
Text: Our Army is Our Supreme

Speaker: NA
Text: National E f f o r t ";

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) Publishing on the 16th October,

Speaker: NA
Text: again without submission, a

Speaker: NA
Text: signed article headed: " Tell All

Speaker: NA
Text: the News-th e Newspapers Do

Speaker: NA
Text: Their Duty ".

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not agree with that. I point out

Speaker: NA
Text: that even when a newspaper publisher or

Speaker: NA
Text: editor is not required by a specific order

Speaker: NA
Text: to submit material he must, under

Speaker: NA
Text: National Security Regulation 16, submit

Speaker: NA
Text: all doubtful matter. Sir Keith Murdoch's

Speaker: NA
Text: articles were certainly of this character,

Speaker: NA
Text: and contained many poisonous sentiments

Speaker: NA
Text: and censorship breaches. Recently, as

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members may recollect, there

Speaker: NA
Text: was a reshuffle in the Victorian publicity

Speaker: NA
Text: censorship, when Mr Burns retired.

Speaker: Mr MARWICK
Text: Ho w does the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member know that the articles were

Speaker: NA
Text: not submitted in full?

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Fro m information

Speaker: NA
Text: received-whic h in the police courts is

Speaker: NA
Text: accepted as evidence.

Speaker: Mr MARWICK
Text: Ca n the facts

Speaker: NA
Text: ascertained from the censor himself?

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: M y authority is un-

Speaker: NA
Text: impeachable. I have not the slightest

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt that the censor will be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: verify the facts, i f the Minister refers

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter to him. A former employee

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Melbourne Herald who had been

Speaker: NA
Text: a member of its staff for a period of

Speaker: NA
Text: eight and a half years, received the resul-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant appointment of Victorian publicity

Speaker: NA
Text: censor. His former employer is now

Speaker: NA
Text: treating him, in his new position, witb

Speaker: NA
Text: contempt. I object to tbat. Honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members will recall that when Sir Keith

Speaker: NA
Text: Murdoch's articles were discussed in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House some months ago, tbe Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Army, in reply to a question, said

Speaker: NA
Text: tbat they were signed and passed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: censor. I assure the honorable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: that that is not so. I bave the articles

Speaker: NA
Text: about which I complain, and the state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments tbat I make can be checked. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: The view of what I bave said, this gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: needs a good deal of watching by tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: censorship authorities. I am certain tbat

Speaker: NA
Text: the article published last night, about

Speaker: NA
Text: which I have complained, would not

Speaker: NA
Text: have been passed by any censor had i t

Speaker: NA
Text: been submitted to him. I t was not merely

Speaker: NA
Text: an expression of opinion; it was a deli-

Speaker: NA
Text: berate attempt to stir up strife in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country, to weaken the morale of the

Speaker: NA
Text: nation by dividing it. I t was a

Speaker: NA
Text: gratuitous insult to people of cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain blood who have played a

Speaker: NA
Text: distinguished part, in common with their

Speaker: NA
Text: fellow citizens, first in laying the foun-

Speaker: NA
Text: dations of thi3 country's greatness, and,

Speaker: NA
Text: secondly, in helping to build i t to its

Speaker: NA
Text: present strength. I regard Murdoch as a

Speaker: NA
Text: very dangerous man at large, and hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that the censor does not permit defiance

Speaker: NA
Text: by him. I trust that the Government will

Speaker: NA
Text: watch him very carefully; because, i f be

Speaker: NA
Text: is allowed to defy censorship instructions,

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no telling what great harm he

Speaker: NA
Text: may do. He wants to enter this Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in order to dominate it. He is

Speaker: NA
Text: anxious to oppose the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Kooyong ( Mr Menzies). He

Speaker: NA
Text: has cast covetous eyes upon the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia party blue ribbon seat of

Speaker: NA
Text: Fawkner; and he has ambitions i n regard

Speaker: NA
Text: to supplanting the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Henty ( Mr Coles). The best place for

Speaker: NA
Text: him is outside the councils of this nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have noticed that he desires to treble

Speaker: NA
Text: be the membership of this Parliament,

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously for the purpose of trebling his

Speaker: NA
Text: chance of entering it. The Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Army will be failing i n bjs duty i f he

Speaker: NA
Text: does not do something very definite about

Speaker: NA
Text: the articles which Murdoch i3 publish-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in the press of Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout its many ramifications. But

Speaker: NA
Text: what is worse, he is cabling these poison-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous articles to America and England

Speaker: NA
Text: without the censorship authorities having

Speaker: NA
Text: seen them. He is trying to cause trouble

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Government of this country, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the nation, by telling the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: America things tbat ought not to be

Speaker: NA
Text: allowed to pass out of Australia. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: described him to-night as a fifth

Speaker: NA
Text: columnist. I consider tbat he is a megalo-

Speaker: NA
Text: maniac, who cannot help himself. His

Speaker: NA
Text: desire is for notoriety and domination,

Speaker: NA
Text: and he has to be restrained. I f present

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers cannot restrain him, they ought

Speaker: NA
Text: to make way for others who will. I f he

Speaker: NA
Text: be not restrained, I bave not the slightest

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt that he will do all he can to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring our democratic institutions into

Speaker: NA
Text: disrepute.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: member know what Sir Keith Murdoch

Speaker: NA
Text: thinks of him ?

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Eve n if he thinks as

Speaker: NA
Text: badly of me as I do of him, I am con--

Speaker: NA
Text: fident tbat public opinion throughout this

Speaker: NA
Text: country is much more likely to support

Speaker: NA
Text: me than -they are likely to support him.

Speaker: NA
Text: Any honorable member whom he may be

Speaker: NA
Text: oppose for election to this Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: will be lucky in his opposition, because

Speaker: NA
Text: it will be one of the easiest victories he

Speaker: NA
Text: is every likely to win. I f he wishes to

Speaker: NA
Text: dispute my membership of this Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for the blue ribbon seat of Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne, I believe that, by the grace of

Speaker: NA
Text: -God and the sturdy common sense of at

Speaker: NA
Text: least 51 per cent, of the electors, I shall

Speaker: NA
Text: still be a member of this Parliament for

Speaker: NA
Text: many years to come.

Speaker: NA
Text: Friday, 11 December, 194£.

Speaker: Mr CONELAN
Text: Griffith) [12 mid-

Speaker: NA
Text: night] - I wish to bring before tbe House

Speaker: NA
Text: a matter which is causing great concern in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate. I have received an S 0 S

Speaker: NA
Text: from nine families, in which they state

Speaker: NA
Text: that either tbe Government or the Army

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities propose to take over their

Speaker: NA
Text: homes. I understand that the buildings

Speaker: NA
Text: will be used by the American Army for a

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital of some kind. Why cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: the American Army acquire land and

Speaker: NA
Text: erect buildings thereon, as the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Army does? Three of the nine homes in

Speaker: NA
Text: question are occupied by wives of men

Speaker: NA
Text: in the fighting services, and another by

Speaker: NA
Text: the mother of a soldier. I n two other

Speaker: NA
Text: cases persons working in a munitions

Speaker: NA
Text: factory are concerned.

Speaker: Mr FORDE
Text: I n what suburb are the

Speaker: NA
Text: homes situated?

Speaker: Mr CONELAN
Text: The y are situated

Speaker: NA
Text: in the suburb of Ekibin. The occupants

Speaker: NA
Text: of the homes are probably not supporters

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Labour party, but that does not

Speaker: NA
Text: affect the position so far as I am con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned. I received a telegram on this

Speaker: NA
Text: subject yesterday, and to-day I received

Speaker: NA
Text: a long letter stating that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed to take this action under

Speaker: NA
Text: National Security Regulations. The occu-

Speaker: NA
Text: pants of the homes have been requested

Speaker: NA
Text: to make arrangements to band over tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: buildings to the Chief Engineer, Base

Speaker: NA
Text: Section No. 3, United States Army. Tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for the Army ( Mr Forde)

Speaker: NA
Text: will know tbat i t is impossible to

Speaker: NA
Text: obtain other homes in these suburbs at

Speaker: NA
Text: the present time. The compensation

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed to be paid is far less than these

Speaker: NA
Text: people would have to pay for other houses

Speaker: NA
Text: in the same locality, even i f they could be

Speaker: NA
Text: obtained, and they are precluded by

Speaker: NA
Text: regulation from building other homes.

Speaker: NA
Text: For some time I bave urged tbat acquisi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and compensation committees be set

Speaker: NA
Text: up to deal with the hiring of properties

Speaker: NA
Text: that are being taken over by tbe military

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities. I have bad in mind particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly the many secondary schools which

Speaker: NA
Text: have been taken over without regard to the

Speaker: NA
Text: educational needs of the children affected.

Speaker: NA
Text: In many instances, compensation adjust-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments have not been made in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: properties taken over several months ago.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is time that steps were taken to pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vent a continuance of these acts.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although we are pleased to have the

Speaker: NA
Text: Americans here, they should be placed

Speaker: NA
Text: on the same basis as tbe Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Army in connexion with properties

Speaker: NA
Text: required, by them. Instead of turning

Speaker: NA
Text: nine families out of their homes, it would

Speaker: NA
Text: be better for the Government to acquire

Speaker: NA
Text: vacant land and provide temporary

Speaker: NA
Text: accommodation of the kind required by

Speaker: NA
Text: the American authorities. The Allied

Speaker: NA
Text: Works Council is erecting numerous

Speaker: NA
Text: buildings throughout Queensland for the

Speaker: NA
Text: men under its control, and something of

Speaker: NA
Text: the same kind should be done in this

Speaker: NA
Text: instance. When we reflect that in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: of four of the nine homes relatives

Speaker: NA
Text: of men in the fighting services and tbat

Speaker: NA
Text: in two other instances munitions workers

Speaker: NA
Text: are concerned, it will be seen that the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed action will seriously affect persons

Speaker: NA
Text: who are rendering valuable service to the

Speaker: NA
Text: community. I t is not right that while

Speaker: NA
Text: men are fighting overseas on our behalf

Speaker: NA
Text: their dependants should be turned out

Speaker: NA
Text: of their homes, and inadequate compen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sation be offered to them. I implore the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister to take action -which will stop

Speaker: NA
Text: this sort of thing. I n my opinion, the

Speaker: NA
Text: occupants of these homes should defy the

Speaker: NA
Text: hirings administration; but should they

Speaker: NA
Text: be turned out, the Government should

Speaker: NA
Text: provide accommodation for them and see

Speaker: NA
Text: that they do not suffer any monetary

Speaker: NA
Text: loss. Most of the families concerned are

Speaker: NA
Text: purchasing their homes, and have bought

Speaker: NA
Text: furniture and furnishings to suit them.

Speaker: NA
Text: . I f they are forced to rip up wall-to-wall

Speaker: NA
Text: carpets they will suffer monetary loss if

Speaker: NA
Text: they try to fit them to new premises.

Speaker: NA
Text: Should they have to vacate their homes

Speaker: NA
Text: the compensation payable to them should

Speaker: NA
Text: be adequate to meet all losses incurred.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f there be no alternative, and these

Speaker: NA
Text: people have to be turned out of their

Speaker: NA
Text: homes, the Government should purchase

Speaker: NA
Text: the buildings outright, and enable their

Speaker: NA
Text: owners to purchase other homes else-

Speaker: NA
Text: where, as it is practically impossible to

Speaker: NA
Text: rent other homes in the locality. I ask

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister to ensure that these people

Speaker: NA
Text: are not victimized.

Speaker: Mr SCULLY
Text: Gwydir-Ministe r for

Speaker: NA
Text: Commerce) [12.7 a.m.] - I shall reply

Speaker: NA
Text: briefly to several matters which have been

Speaker: NA
Text: raised. I am indebted to the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Swan ( Mr Marwick) for

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioning-the subject of superphosphate.

Speaker: NA
Text: I agree with him that it is essential that

Speaker: NA
Text: supplies of this commodity shall be made

Speaker: NA
Text: available so that it can be carted to the

Speaker: NA
Text: farm as back-loading when wheat is being

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered. I shall take tbe matter up

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately with the Superphosphate

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee with a view to making sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: plies available.

Speaker: Mr MARWICK
Text: I t is not only a matter

Speaker: NA
Text: of supplies. "We also wish to know the

Speaker: NA
Text: basis on which supplies will be made

Speaker: NA
Text: available.

Speaker: Mr SCULLY
Text: Ther e is a definite

Speaker: NA
Text: rationing basis. I thought that I had

Speaker: NA
Text: advised the Government of Western Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia that for 1943-44 the policy followed

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1942-43 will be continued.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr SCULLY
Text: I t will be followed as

Speaker: NA
Text: to tbe 33^ reduction and also in regard

Speaker: NA
Text: to compensation. Owing to the great

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus of wheat that is being accumu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lated in Western Australia, the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment intends to continue the 33£ per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction of the area to be sown with

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat.

Speaker: Mr MARWICK
Text: Wh y not place super-

Speaker: NA
Text: phosphate on the same basis i n Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia as in tbe other States?

Speaker: NA
Text: Wheat lands in Western Australia are

Speaker: NA
Text: deteriorating.

Speaker: Mr SCULLY
Text: I agree with the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member, and I shall take that

Speaker: NA
Text: aspect of the case into consideration at

Speaker: NA
Text: the earliest opportunity. The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Riverina ( Mr Wilson)

Speaker: NA
Text: raised the subject of f.a.q. standards and

Speaker: NA
Text: dockages. I shall have the matter investi-

Speaker: NA
Text: gated, and referred, immediately to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Wheat Board. I shall also

Speaker: NA
Text: refer to the board the matter of weigh-

Speaker: NA
Text: bridge weights.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Deakin

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Hutchinson) mentioned tbe resump-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of land by the Department of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Interior, and the payments made for it.

Speaker: NA
Text: I shall bring his remarks to the

Speaker: NA
Text: notice of the Minister for the Interior,

Speaker: NA
Text: who will give the matter his prompt

Speaker: NA
Text: attention.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Henty

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Coles) mentioned the acquisition of

Speaker: NA
Text: apples and pears in Victoria. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: indebted to the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: having raised the subject. There must

Speaker: NA
Text: necessarily be some dislocation upon the

Speaker: NA
Text: cessation of the scheme for acquisition,

Speaker: NA
Text: but steps will be taken to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: growers receive supplies of cases, and

Speaker: NA
Text: that transport is made available.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Forrest

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: mation regarding potatoes which was

Speaker: NA
Text: news to me. I t is certainly not the inten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the Government to inflict injustice

Speaker: NA
Text: on any section of the community. I f the

Speaker: NA
Text: primary producers bave been patriotic

Speaker: NA
Text: enough to meet the wishes of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, the Government will see that they

Speaker: NA
Text: are not victimized.

Speaker: Mr FORDE
Text: Capricornia-Ministe r

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Army) [12.15 p.m.] -Honor -

Speaker: NA
Text: able members on both sides of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: have pressed for the restoration of broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casting facilities to the Wesley Church

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities in Melbourne. Ministers have

Speaker: NA
Text: been greatly impressed by the speeches

Speaker: NA
Text: made, and I shall take the matter up with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Postmaster -.General (Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Ashley). As has been pointed out, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Broadcasting Commission bas

Speaker: NA
Text: been given, by Parliament, complete con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trol over broadcasting. The action of the

Speaker: NA
Text: commission was not taken at the instiga-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the Government; the commission

Speaker: NA
Text: has exercised the powers given to i t by

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament. There has been friction for

Speaker: NA
Text: some time, but I feel sure that the matter

Speaker: NA
Text: could be smoothed out after consultation

Speaker: NA
Text: between the commission and Dr Irving

Speaker: NA
Text: Benson, the minister in chaTge of Wesley

Speaker: NA
Text: Church. I have met this gentleman, and

Speaker: NA
Text: know him to be a very fine Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: citizen. He has provided facilities for

Speaker: NA
Text: public men of all political parties, and

Speaker: NA
Text: distinguished visitors from other coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries, to occupy the public forum in his

Speaker: NA
Text: church on Sunday afternoon. The Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment wishes to be just to all sections

Speaker: NA
Text: of the community. Although full power

Speaker: NA
Text: was given to the Australian Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission, it is within the province of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Postmaster-General and other Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters to discuss matters of this kind with

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the commission, and I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that, as a result of such discussion, a

Speaker: NA
Text: solution of the difficulty will be found.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Wimmera

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Wilson) mentioned the Army I n -

Speaker: NA
Text: ventions Directorate, and said that proper

Speaker: NA
Text: encouragement was not given to inven-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors. I shall take the matter up with the

Speaker: NA
Text: directorate, a body which was set up by

Speaker: NA
Text: me because the previous Inventions Board

Speaker: NA
Text: was not working satisfactorily.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Ho w many inventions

Speaker: NA
Text: have been approved by the directorate?

Speaker: Mr FORDE
Text: I cannot say offhand,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I could get the figures. Honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members will understand tbat probably

Speaker: NA
Text: 99 per cent, of the inventions offered are

Speaker: NA
Text: found to be of no real value. Neverthe-

Speaker: NA
Text: less, it is in the interests of the nation

Speaker: NA
Text: that encouragement should be given to

Speaker: NA
Text: inventors, particularly in war-time. I

Speaker: NA
Text: know, as Minister for the Army, that

Speaker: NA
Text: many helpful ideaB regarding military

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment have been offered from time

Speaker: NA
Text: to time by inventors. The Army I n -

Speaker: NA
Text: ventions Directorate consists of some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the most eminent engineers and scientists

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia.

Speaker: Mr MARWICK
Text: The y are very staid

Speaker: NA
Text: in their outlook.

Speaker: Mr FORDE
Text: I t would be difficult to

Speaker: NA
Text: appoint a directorate that would satisfy

Speaker: NA
Text: every body. A man whose idea is

Speaker: NA
Text: rejected usually bas a grievance.

Speaker: Mr MARWICK
Text: I f a politician gets on

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe job after an invention bas been re-

Speaker: NA
Text: jected, the directorate will send an

Speaker: NA
Text: urgent wire to the inventor asking him

Speaker: NA
Text: to send over his invention immediately

Speaker: NA
Text: for examination.

Speaker: Mr FORDE
Text: I n some cases, the

Speaker: NA
Text: directorate has borne the expense of

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing not only the invention, but also

Speaker: NA
Text: the inventor, from other States, paying

Speaker: NA
Text: the inventor's fare and expenses, while

Speaker: NA
Text: to the inspection is being carried out. Its

Speaker: NA
Text: members are actuated by the highest

Speaker: NA
Text: motives. They are doing a great service

Speaker: NA
Text: to the country.

Speaker: Mr MARWICK
Text: I shall have some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing more to say on the matter on the

Speaker: NA
Text: motion for the adjournment to-morrow.

Speaker: Mr FORDE
Text: I suggest that the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: orable member should discuss the matter

Speaker: NA
Text: with me in my office.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Griffith

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Conelan) raised the matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: houses being taken over at Ekibin

Speaker: NA
Text: Heights, Brisbane, by the American

Speaker: NA
Text: Army authorities for use as hospitals.

Speaker: NA
Text: [ shall have inquiries made into tbat

Speaker: NA
Text: matter. There is a Central Hirings Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mi'ltee and a Hirings Committee operates

Speaker: NA
Text: in each State. State committees consider

Speaker: NA
Text: all applications from the services for

Speaker: NA
Text: accommodation of various kinds. I n some

Speaker: NA
Text: cases, public schools, or buildings of other

Speaker: NA
Text: kinds, are taken over for use by the

Speaker: NA
Text: services. Following Japan's entry into

Speaker: NA
Text: the war, it became necessary immediately

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide additional hospital accommo-

Speaker: NA
Text: dation far beyond anything previously

Speaker: NA
Text: considered necessary. We do not have

Speaker: NA
Text: time to erect new buildings. Existing

Speaker: NA
Text: buildings bad to ibe taken over; and tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: inconvenience caused to occupants was

Speaker: NA
Text: unavoidable. The Government, so far as

Speaker: NA
Text: it could do so, discouraged the taking over

Speaker: NA
Text: of public schools, but these buildings,

Speaker: NA
Text: which contained large dormitories, were

Speaker: NA
Text: the only available .buildings suitable for

Speaker: NA
Text: base hospitals.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Som e serious mistakes

Speaker: NA
Text: have been made.

Speaker: Mr FORDE
Text: I do not propose to go

Speaker: NA
Text: into details. I shall not say tbat no

Speaker: NA
Text: mistakes have been made; but it is ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: visable to hear both sides of the question

Speaker: NA
Text: before one decides tbat a mistake has been

Speaker: NA
Text: made.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Wesle y College and

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne Grammar School, Melbourne,

Speaker: NA
Text: should never have been taken over.

Speaker: Mr FORDE
Text: Tha t is the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman's opinion. However, at that

Speaker: NA
Text: time, additional accommodation had to be

Speaker: NA
Text: provided without delay. The Japanese

Speaker: NA
Text: were knocking at the door; our Army

Speaker: NA
Text: was expanding threefold, and

Speaker: NA
Text: Americans were coming

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands. Accommodation had. to be

Speaker: NA
Text: found f or their staffs and equipment.

Speaker: Mr MARWICK
Text: I n those days, people

Speaker: NA
Text: were only too glad to get away to the bush

Speaker: NA
Text: as quickly as possible.

Speaker: Mr FORDE
Text: Ther e were evacuations

Speaker: NA
Text: f r o m all capital cities, particularly f r o m

Speaker: NA
Text: those on the eastern coast, and at tbat

Speaker: NA
Text: time the occupants of these buildings

Speaker: NA
Text: were glad to hand them over to the m i l i -

Speaker: NA
Text: tary authorities. However, when the posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion became calmer, and tbe danger of

Speaker: NA
Text: Japanese invasion became less probable

Speaker: NA
Text: many of these people were desirous of re-

Speaker: NA
Text: occupying the buildings. The Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has always been sympathetic towards

Speaker: NA
Text: these people to whom inconvenience has

Speaker: NA
Text: been caused i n 'that way; and i t is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's desire to vacate the build-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings to them as soon as possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, our paramount

Speaker: NA
Text: tion must be the

Speaker: NA
Text: the defences of the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Hirings Committee i n each State decides

Speaker: NA
Text: which buildings shall be taken over and

Speaker: NA
Text: the compensation or rental to be paid.

Speaker: NA
Text: Should the owners, or occupants, of any

Speaker: NA
Text: building which is taken over feel that

Speaker: NA
Text: they are not being dealt with f a i r l y , they

Speaker: NA
Text: can appeal to the Compensation Board i n

Speaker: NA
Text: each State. I t is impossible to please

Speaker: NA
Text: every body i n this matter, but I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that machinery has been set up to give

Speaker: NA
Text: equitable treatment to all concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: I shall bring the subject of censor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship raised by the honorable member commodities

Speaker: NA
Text: for Melbourne ( Mr Calwell) to the

Speaker: NA
Text: notice of the Prime Minister.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Abou t Sir Keith

Speaker: NA
Text: Murdoch ?

Speaker: Mr FORDE
Text: A t this late hour I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not propose to go into details. The Goorable member's

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment desires that tbe press shall be

Speaker: NA
Text: as free as possible. I t does not stand f o r

Speaker: NA
Text: political censorship. Tbe principle upon referred

Speaker: NA
Text: which tbe censorship is conducted

Speaker: NA
Text: already been set out by the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Sir K e i t h Murdoch is

Speaker: NA
Text: obliged by law to submit his articles to

Speaker: NA
Text: the censor. W h y should he be given

Speaker: NA
Text: preferential treatment because he is

Speaker: NA
Text: irresponsible ?

Speaker: Mr FORDE
Text: I am not conversant

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe with the censorship restrictions.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Sir K e i t h Murdoch is

Speaker: NA
Text: obliged to submit his material to tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: censor. W i l l the Minister see tbat he

Speaker: NA
Text: obeys the censor's instructions?

Speaker: Mr FORDE
Text: Th e honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber's remarks w i l l be brought to the notice

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Prime Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved i n the affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: House adjourned at 12.27 a.m.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: WESTERN AUSTRALIA: IMPORTATION or

Speaker: NA
Text: MERCHANDISE.

Speaker: Mr NAIRN
Text: the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Transport, upon notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Whether the Government is aware of the

Speaker: NA
Text: considera- grave shortages in Western Australia of re-

Speaker: NA
Text: efficiency of placement stocks and materials essential for

Speaker: NA
Text: The carrying on manufacture in that State?

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. What steps have been taken to prevent

Speaker: NA
Text: the continuing transport west of goods which

Speaker: NA
Text: are or can readily be made available in that

Speaker: NA
Text: State from local sources?

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. Who determine what goods are to be

Speaker: NA
Text: carried by train?

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. At what points of consignment is super-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision exercised?

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. Have instructions been given that in

Speaker: NA
Text: allotting priorities regard should be had to

Speaker: NA
Text: public requirements in Western Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than the value or convenience of the

Speaker: NA
Text: goods as freight?

Speaker: NA
Text: 6. Do the railway authorities co-operate with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Shipping Board?

Speaker: NA
Text: 7. Does any civil authority keep check on

Speaker: NA
Text: brought into Western Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: by or at the direction of the military?

Speaker: NA
Text: 8. What persons, officers or boards constitute

Speaker: NA
Text: the central authority which directs and regu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lates the importation of merchandise into

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia?

Speaker: Mr LAWSON
Text: Tb e answers to tbe hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: questions are as

Speaker: NA
Text: follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. I-had no knowledge of the grave shortages

Speaker: NA
Text: to.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Preference is given to essential require-

Speaker: NA
Text: bas ments defence and civil.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. The order of priority by rail is determined

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Land Transport Board under the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Security (Land Transport) Regula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions.

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. At the point of consignment.

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. Priority is determined by the essential

Speaker: NA
Text: nature of the requirements and freight value

Speaker: NA
Text: plays no part in the decision.

Speaker: NA
Text: 6. The Commonwealth Department of Trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: port co-operates closely with the Shipping

Speaker: NA
Text: Control Board.

Speaker: NA
Text: 7. The Department of the Army (Movement

Speaker: NA
Text: Control) determines the priority for Navy,

Speaker: NA
Text: Army and Air Force requirements.

Speaker: NA
Text: 8. This matter is one for the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: War Organisation of Industry.
